The milestone is that the joint committee meeting is scheduled and these leads formally endorsed.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Ownership of supply-chain engagement is described in the procurement plan; MEAL learning ownership is in the M&E plan; community liaison ownership is in the stakeholder engagement plan; escalation is defined in the risk register. The milestone is that all these plans are finalised, annexed to the project documentation, and accessible to staff.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The execution spine is mapped as follows: supply-chain engagement is co-owned by Kujenga’s Aggregation Lead, Faith, and the partner’s Commercial Manager, David, with a milestone of signing off-take agreements with at least two buyers by Day 60; MEAL learning is co-owned by World Vision’s Gender and M&E Advisor, Sophie, and Kujenga’s Data Storyteller, Robert, with a milestone of co-designing a feminist monitoring dashboard prototype by Day 45; community liaison is owned by the elected Women’s Council Chairperson, Grace, in each region, supported by a Kujenga Bridge Facilitator, with a milestone that the council is convened and an issue log opened by Day 30; escalation paths follow a three-tier structure where functional co-owners are Tier 1, Spine Guardians (Okello and the Kujenga Executive Director) are Tier 2, and an independent ombudsperson who is an appointed elder is Tier 3, with a milestone that the guardians intervene on the first drift signal by Day 40.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The spine is designed so that supply-chain engagement is owned by a Market Access Cell chaired by a woman trader, Harriet, who has veto power on partner selection, with a milestone that the cell either approves or rejects the first partner memorandum of understanding by Week 6; MEAL learning is governed by a Learning Pact between World Vision’s M&E team and a Kujenga women’s circle, where the circle owns raw data, with a milestone that the first data sovereignty agreement is signed by the end of Month 1; community liaison includes a Shadow Liaison role for a youth representative to surface issues that formal channels miss, with a milestone that the first shadow report influences a program decision by Day 70; escalation is reinforced by an automated SMS trigger to Spine Guardians if a weekly field huddle is missed, with a milestone that the first auto-alert is triggered and discussed by Day 35.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The execution spine allocates supply-chain engagement to the SokoLink Manager, Daniel, who is embedded within Kujenga but budgeted by World Vision, with a milestone of making five village collection points fully operational by Day 50; MEAL learning is owned by an Ethnographer-in-Residence, Dr Amina, who is paid by the project but reports to a community assembly, with a milestone that her first narrative insight report causes a tangible shift in an activity by Day 55; community liaison is anchored in a Ritual Facilitator, Elder Joseph, who convenes monthly fire-side conversations, with a milestone that this ritual space is used to resolve at least one conflict by Day 40; escalation uses a physical Red Flag object that three women can pass to Okello when they feel disrespected, with a milestone of the first warning flag being passed and acted upon by Day 30.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The spine maps supply-chain engagement to a Quality Covenant held by a council of grandmothers who certify produce, with a milestone that the first batch is certified and attracts a quality premium by Day 65; MEAL learning is driven by a Participatory Sense-Making Duo made up of one farmer and one tech-savvy staff member, producing weekly insight sketches, with a milestone that one sketch triggers a pivot in training content by Day 45; community liaison is formalised through a Griot, or storykeeper, who attends all key meetings and records them in song, with a milestone that the griot’s song corrects or challenges the official minutes in Week 5; escalation uses a Silence Breaker hotline managed by a trusted nun outside the project, with a milestone that the first anonymous call leads to action on a sensitive issue by Day 50.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The spine assigns supply-chain engagement to a Farmer’s Own Logistics Cooperative legally registered by the women, with the project as its first client, with a milestone that the cooperative issues its first invoice for transport services by Day 60; MEAL learning is anchored in a Data Sanctuary hosted on a local server, with access governed by the women’s council, and a milestone that the sanctuary receives its first upload of cleaned data by Day 30; community liaison is managed through a Bidirectional Mirror process where every formal meeting is followed by a community-only meeting that reflects back concerns, with a milestone that such a mirror meeting successfully alters an agenda before execution by Week 4; escalation follows a Two-Key Rule for major decisions in which both the Kujenga Executive Director and Okello must physically authorise, with a milestone that the first significant payment or contract is released using this two-key protocol by Day 55.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Supply-chain engagement is owned by a Value Chain Negotiator, Esther, hired by the community but trained and funded by the project, with a milestone of negotiating at least a 10 percent price increase with one buyer by Day 70; MEAL learning is structured around Counter-Metrics defined by youth, such as hours of play or stress reduction, which are tracked alongside logframe indicators, with a milestone that these counter-metrics are formally included in the quarterly review by Day 80; community liaison is organised through a Doorstep Council where officials meet women at their homes instead of only in offices, with a milestone that the first such council is held in Karamoja by Day 40; escalation uses a Pattern Interrupt ritual where, if the same issue escalates three times, a randomly selected community member leads the solution design, with a milestone that this pattern interrupt is triggered and followed through by Day 65.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The spine places supply-chain engagement with a Blockchain-for-Benefits pilot managed by a tech-savvy woman, Naomi, with a milestone that the first smart contract for a maize sale is executed by Day 90; MEAL learning is enhanced by Anecdote Circles facilitated with children’s drawings of project impacts, with a milestone that one set of children’s drawings reveals an unseen tension by Day 50; community liaison is supported by a Gift Economy Coordinator who tracks non-cash exchanges as social capital, with a milestone that a map of this social capital informs a partner selection decision by Day 60; escalation uses a Pre-Mortem Trigger where any high-risk handoff identified in scenario planning is automatically escalated for redesign, with a milestone that one such pre-mortem prevents a real handoff failure by Day 45.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: In this execution spine, supply-chain engagement is owned by a Climate and Commerce Officer who dual-reports to the project and a women’s climate council, with a milestone that the first sale including a carbon-credit element is completed by Day 85; MEAL learning is documented through an Unlearning Journal kept by senior staff and reviewed quarterly with the community, with a milestone that one journal entry leads to stopping a harmful best practice by Day 55; community liaison is deepened by establishing a Deep Hangout Space, such as a shade tree, where project leads spend weekly unstructured time, with a milestone that at least one key insight emerges from this informal space by Day 35; escalation rituals include a Sacred Object that must be taken physically back to the community to halt the project when necessary, with a milestone that the object’s purpose is explained and acknowledged in all key meetings by Week 3.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The spine defines supply-chain engagement as the role of a Spatial Justice Mapper who ensures that market infrastructure benefits marginalised hamlets and not just central villages, with a milestone that the map leads to rerouting a collection truck by Day 50; MEAL learning is enriched through a Body Mapping exercise tracking where women feel stress or triumph in their bodies, with a milestone that the body map highlights burnout risks before a survey does by Day 60; community liaison is owned by an Anticipatory Relationship Broker who connects groups before conflicts arise, with a milestone that such brokering prevents a partner–community clash by Day 40; escalation is democratised via a Community Pause Button, a literal device that women can press to freeze all spending and activities, with a milestone that the button is installed and a protocol for its use agreed by Day 30.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The execution spine here gives supply-chain engagement to a Living Inventory practice managed via a WhatsApp group where women post real-time stock photos, with a milestone that the group is used to aggregate for a bulk order by Day 45; MEAL learning includes a Dream Log where farmers record dreams about crops and weather as qualitative data, with a milestone that the log helps predict a pest outbreak by Day 70; community liaison uses a Reverse Power Hour in which partners serve tea to the women’s council to symbolically invert power, with a milestone that one such hour reshapes a negotiation by Day 55; escalation is governed by a Three-Strike Ritual where, after three repeated failures in any function, the responsible party performs community service, with a milestone that the first such ritual is enacted by Day 65.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: In this spine, supply-chain engagement is supported by a Mobile Aggregation Unit, such as a bicycle with a trailer owned collectively by women, with a milestone that the unit increases the effective collection radius by 50 percent by Day 75; MEAL learning is strengthened by Grassroots Peer Review where women audit each other’s data entries for truthfulness, with a milestone that peer review catches at least one instance of data fabrication by Day 50; community liaison is carried by a Cultural Translator, an elder who explains the project using local proverbs, with a milestone that the translator resolves a deadlock caused by technical jargon by Day 40; escalation includes Sunset Clauses built into all roles so that if they are not positively reviewed by the community, the role expires, with a milestone that the first role is allowed to sunset and be redesigned by Day 90.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The spine maps supply-chain engagement to a Digital Trailblazer, a young woman such as Linda using a simple app to track produce journeys, with a milestone that this digital trail increases transparency and improves at least one price negotiation by Day 80; MEAL learning is organised through Echo Chambers, separate feedback loops for men, women, and youth that are later synthesised by a council, with a milestone that the synthesis reveals a gender-based access gap by Day 55; community liaison is reinforced by a Gratitude Messenger who carries thanks, not only requests, back to communities, with a milestone that her work improves survey participation or meeting attendance by Day 60; escalation features a Silence Amplifier, a device or tool that records meeting silences and analyses who is not speaking, with a milestone that it triggers a change in facilitation by Day 45.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: In this strategic spine, supply-chain engagement is guided by a Risk-Pooling Coordinator who manages a communal fund to buffer market shocks, with a milestone that the fund is used to cushion a price crash by Day 70; MEAL learning is led by a Future Backcasting Facilitator who helps communities imagine their desired five-year outcomes and work backwards, with a milestone that backcasting reshapes at least one quarter two activity by Day 90; community liaison is curated by an Intergenerational Dialogue Curator who balances youth and elder voices, with a milestone that such dialogue produces a hybrid innovation by Day 65; escalation is signalled by a Mood Weather Report posted publicly, where if the mood is rated as stormy for three days running, leadership is required to visit, with a milestone that the weather report triggers a field visit by Day 50.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The execution spine positions supply-chain engagement with an Ethical Sourcing Guild of women who vet buyers for fair treatment histories, with a milestone that the guild blacklists at least one inappropriate buyer by Day 60; MEAL learning draws on Narrative CVs of participants that capture change as personal stories, with a milestone that narrative CVs replace a portion of indicator reporting, such as 10 percent, by Day 85; community liaison is enhanced by Conflict Gardeners who plant a tree for each resolved dispute, with a milestone that the garden becomes a recognised mediation space by Day 75; escalation is stewarded by Threshold Guardians elected by the community who can veto decisions crossing ethical lines, with a milestone that a guardian veto is used on a procurement choice by Day 55.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The spine here has supply-chain engagement owned by a Circular Economy Officer who links farm waste to other local industries, with a milestone that the first waste-to-compost or waste-to-input sale happens by Day 70; MEAL learning is enriched by Sensory Evaluators who taste produce blindfolded as a qualitative quality metric, with a milestone that a sensory score influences which buyer the group chooses by Day 80; community liaison is supported by a Memory Keeper who archives oral histories of the pilot for future scale teams, with a milestone that the memory archive prevents a repeated mistake by Day 40; escalation is informed by a Heartbeat Check, a short weekly pulse survey of spine owners’ confidence, with a milestone that this check reveals a looming breakdown in time to correct it by Day 35.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: In this mapping, supply-chain engagement is managed by an Autonomous Logistics Pod in each region with delegated budget authority, with a milestone that the pod makes its first independent purchase decision by Day 60; MEAL learning is tracked through Improvisation Trackers who document successful deviations from the plan, with a milestone that one such improvisation is formally adopted as standard practice by Day 75; community liaison is monitored by a Digital Elder who tracks social media for community sentiment, with a milestone that the elder detects and addresses a damaging rumour before it spreads widely by Day 45; escalation protocols are refined through a quarterly Crisis Simulation whose failures inform real escalation procedures, with a milestone that one simulation leads to improved response time by Day 90.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The execution spine assigns supply-chain engagement to a Co-op of Misfits composed of landless women who run mobile processing units, with a milestone that their product line is launched and present in the market by Day 80; MEAL learning is guided by a Shadow Metrics Council that defines success in human terms like reduced fear of tomorrow, with a milestone that such a metric is adopted in at least one donor report by Day 85; community liaison is led by a Rumor-to-Innovation Converter who turns marketplace gossip into design challenges, with a milestone that one rumour leads to a new saving scheme by Day 65; escalation is supported by an Anonymous Courage Box where staff can safely drop truths, with a milestone that a message from the box reveals a partnership betrayal by Day 50.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: when WV hands off to the formal partner who never understands our paperwork. Artifact or ritual: we give them a thick manual, assume they read it, and blame them if they fail.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: between Kujenga and the new partner because Kujenga is jealous and will not share contacts. Artifact or ritual: a mandatory play nice meeting where I lecture them to cooperate and then never follow up.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: when the donor hands us new conditions mid stream. Artifact or ritual: we nod, pretend to comply on paper, and keep doing exactly what we were doing before.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: between our field staff and the partner's field staff when they fight over per diems. Artifact or ritual: separate bank accounts, no joint activities, and let them fight it out informally.

text: Highest likelihood: between our comms team and the partner's comms who will steal credit. Artifact or ritual: we demand pre approval for all media and create a bottleneck that slows everything.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: during staff turnover when institutional memory is lost. Artifact or ritual: a rushed handover note written on the last day and then forgotten.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: between the partner and community when the partner talks down to people. Artifact or ritual: a one day online cultural sensitivity training that changes very little.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: when moving from planning to implementation and the plan is ignored. Artifact or ritual: we file the plan away and never look at it again.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: at every handoff because the whole partnership model is flawed. Artifact or ritual: a ritual of complaining about partners over coffee that changes nothing but feels good.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of farmer registration data from Kujenga to the new partner. Artifact: a standardized digital data transfer template with clear fields and validation rules. Ritual: a joint data verification workshop where both sides review and sign off on the first 100 records together.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of community mobilization responsibilities from WV to the partner. Artifact: a detailed community engagement handover pack with contacts, minutes, and cultural notes. Ritual: a field shadowing week where partner staff accompany WV or Kujenga to all community meetings.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of M and E data collection from partner field staff to the central M and E unit. Artifact: a weekly data submission checklist and quality control form. Ritual: a bi weekly data review call between partner M and E focal point and WV M and E officer to resolve issues.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of procured inputs from partner warehouse to community groups. Artifact: a double signed distribution ledger with recipient signatures and photos. Ritual: a joint inventory count and signing ceremony at the warehouse before distribution.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of training responsibilities from Kujenga master trainers to partner extension agents. Artifact: a certified trainer kit with curriculum, slides, and evaluations. Ritual: a co facilitation session where both teams deliver the first training together.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of financial advances from WV to the partner for activity implementation. Artifact: a milestone based fund release form requiring evidence of completion. Ritual: a pre disbursement review meeting to confirm all prerequisites for the next tranche.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of community grievances from feedback mechanisms to the partner for resolution. Artifact: a grievance tracking log with assignment, actions, and closure. Ritual: a monthly grievance review committee meeting with all partners.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of reporting deadlines from partner to WV grants team. Artifact: a shared project calendar showing report due dates and responsible staff. Ritual: a two week reminder email and a one week check in call before each major report.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of field visit schedules between partners to avoid overloading communities. Artifact: a shared online field visit calendar. Ritual: a monthly coordination call to plan and space out visits.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of Agro Park liaison duties from WV policy team to partner commercial team. Artifact: a Park engagement protocol with key contacts, negotiation history, and red lines. Ritual: a formal introduction meeting where WV connects partner leads and Park management.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of gender action plan implementation from gender advisor to partner field coordinators. Artifact: a simplified gender integration checklist for each activity. Ritual: a quarterly gender integration review workshop to assess checklist use and address gaps.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of success stories and media content from field to communications. Artifact: a media content pack template with consent forms, photo guidance, and story outline. Ritual: a monthly content harvest call where comms staff interview field staff.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of vehicle and asset maintenance during partner rotations. Artifact: an asset condition report with photos and maintenance log. Ritual: a physical handover inspection where both parties walk around the asset and sign off together.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of security protocols for staff in sensitive areas like Karamoja. Artifact: a security briefing pack for the region updated weekly. Ritual: a mandatory joint security briefing for all new partner staff with WV security and local guides.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of beneficiary selection lists for a new round of support. Artifact: a transparent selection criteria matrix and final list posted publicly. Ritual: a community validation meeting where the list is read out and verified before use.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of learning and evaluation findings from M and E team to program team for adaptation. Artifact: a management response template that documents how each finding will be used. Ritual: a learning dissemination meeting where findings and responses are agreed together.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of sub grant management from a larger partner to a local CBO. Artifact: a sub grant manager handbook with simplified procedures. Ritual: a mentorship period where the larger partner finance officer works alongside the CBO bookkeeper.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of stakeholder relationships such as local chiefs during staff turnover. Artifact: a stakeholder contact and context dossier for each key person. Ritual: a formal introduction visit where outgoing staff introduce incoming staff to stakeholders.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of technical specifications for climate smart inputs from agronomists to procurement. Artifact: a technical specifications sheet with approved brands, varieties, and standards. Ritual: a pre procurement clarification meeting between technical and procurement teams.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of project closure responsibilities as we phase out of a village. Artifact: a closure checklist covering asset transfer, final payments, and feedback. Ritual: a final community meeting and celebration to mark the end of direct implementation and handover to local structures.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: philosophical handoff of the project soul from Kujenga to a results driven partner, risking catastrophic drift. Artifact: a Soul Custody Agreement co signed by Kujenga elders, women leaders, and partner leadership with a community held soul veto token. Ritual: a quarterly Soul Weaving Ceremony where partner leaders live with Kujenga families, then present a soul integrity report to the womens council whose acceptance determines continuation.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of trust and social capital when a new partner enters intimate community spaces. Artifact: a Social Capital Ledger mapping relationships, tensions, and trust, owned by community network weavers with time bound visa access for partners. Ritual: a Trust Baptism where partner staff are assigned a community sponsor who vouches for them, teaches hidden rules, and shares social risk over a shared meal.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: data handoff where nuanced field observations are sanitized into donor friendly metrics. Artifact: a Paradox Container platform with an official metrics stream and a ground truth stream curated by a data integrity council of farmers. Ritual: a monthly Data Confession where staff share one flattering metric and one messy ground truth insight and explain the tension before the council.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: financial handoff of community managed funds from project systems to a community treasury. Artifact: a Two Key Treasury Box opened only by a community treasurer and a mystery guardian elder in front of the assembly. Ritual: a Coin Washing Ceremony where cash is ritually washed by elder women before counting to symbolically cleanse external control.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: conflict handoff when tensions are pushed into bureaucratic complaints instead of being transformed. Artifact: a Conflict Compost Bin, both physical and digital, where conflicts are deposited without naming villains and focused on needs. Ritual: a monthly Compost Turning by a conflict gardener who harvests patterns and facilitates harvest dialogues once conflicts have cooled.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of innovation ownership when community frugal innovations risk being appropriated. Artifact: an Innovation Birth Certificate that records the innovator, clan, and principles and grants naming, veto, and first refusal rights stored in community archives. Ritual: a Naming and Blessing where the innovator ritually names and blesses the innovation and partners symbolically receive that blessing as their license.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: temporal handoff between quarterly partner pressures and seven generation community horizons. Artifact: a Seven Generation Scroll painted by community artists and referenced in all work plans with sketches showing how activities fit the long vision. Ritual: a Long Now Council with a child, an elder, and a blindfolded person who must hum in shared approval before major decisions proceed.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of silence where unspoken fears or traumas later erupt as sabotage. Artifact: a Whispering Gallery where people anonymously whisper into a tunnel and themes are recorded as Silence Stones with symbols. Ritual: a Laying of the Stones at the start of each meeting, placing the stones in the center and acknowledging their energy before any agenda.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of risk where formal registers ignore spiritual, social, and ecological risks. Artifact: a Shadow Risk Totem decorated with beads and threads that represent emerging unregistered fears. Ritual: a monthly Feeding the Totem where leaders sacrifice a planned activity or budget line that increases a shadow risk, placing it at the totems base and announcing its cancellation.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: aesthetic handoff where corporate visuals overwrite community aesthetics. Artifact: a Visual Constitution style guide that requires project visuals to emerge from community patterns, colours, symbols, and materials. Ritual: a Blessing of the Eyes where community artists and children review materials and can reject anything that hurts the eyes before blessing approved designs with coloured dust.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of exhaustion from frontline facilitators to well rested managers. Artifact: a Fatigue Ledger logging energy expenditure with emoticons and calculating a community energy balance. Ritual: an Energy Amnesty Day triggered when deficit is high, pausing non essential partner requests for 48 hours while staff perform restorative service for the community.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of ambiguity where nuanced situations are forced into binary status boxes. Artifact: an Ambiguity Loom where threads from community and partners are woven into an abstract pattern as the main progress report. Ritual: a Weaving Interpretation Circle where people sit in silence, then share one word or sensation about the pattern and decide actions from that collective reading.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of future narrative from community aspirations to donor controlled storylines. Artifact: a Future Storyboard drawn as a wall sized comic by youth showing desired futures and alternative paths. Ritual: a Plot Twist Ceremony where external shocks are acted out as absurd plays and the community improvises adaptive responses that become the new plan.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of ecological signals when rigid calendars ignore land, weather, and species feedback. Artifact: a Lands Mouthpiece role with a Land Diary of omens and ecological observations. Ritual: a First Light Listening visit where agronomists and the Lands Mouthpiece sit at dawn in silence and only proceed with activities if they align in what they heard.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of dignity in subtle partner behaviours that imply superiority. Artifact: a Dignity Mirror with the question Who is serving whom engraved on the back for every staff member. Ritual: a Mirror Check at the start of interactions, and any community member can hold up the mirror mid meeting to prompt reflection and pause.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of laughter and joy as professional efficiency squeezes out camaraderie. Artifact: a Joy Meter gauge in meeting spaces that participants can move from Gloom to Glee. Ritual: a Glee Threshold rule where any meeting stuck in Gloom for 15 minutes dissolves and must resume only after a playful group game.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of problem definition where communities see systemic roots but partners frame technical fixes. Artifact: a set of Root Cause Masks representing symptoms, systems, and power. Ritual: a Masked Dialogue where participants speak from each mask in turn and solutions are only valid if they address insights from the deepest mask.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of spiritual accountability when ancestral and spirit dimensions are ignored. Artifact: an Ancestors Seat, an empty carved chair present at key decision tables. Ritual: a Libation of Consultation where elders pour a drink near the seat, voice the decision as a question, and the group sits in silence to sense permission or warning.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of wildness and spontaneity as partner control smothers emergent energy. Artifact: a Chaos Sandbox budget and time pot reserved for unmanaged experiments. Ritual: a quarterly Chaos Harvest where people present their chaotic experiments in a science fair of failures and surprises and the most intriguing result gets seed funding from the main budget.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: meta handoff of the handoff process itself when one size rituals are imposed. Artifact: a Handoff Design Kit with materials and prompts to co design unique handoff rituals. Ritual: a Ritual of Ritual Making where parties lock themselves in with the kit until they create and perform a bespoke handoff ritual, then teach it to the next group.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff between the living and the dead, between present needs and ancestors and unborn rights. Artifact: a Chrono Contract covenant etched on leather and buried in a sacred grove granting temporal standing to past and future generations. Ritual: a Council of the Long Now at dawn with an ancestor channel, a pregnant woman, and a young child who must reach wordless consensus for decisions to be valid.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff between human consciousness and the consciousness of the land that we ignore. Artifact: a Geomancy Tablet of local stone read by ants, lichen, and water patterns. Ritual: a Lands Veto where the tablet is left on a proposed site and if natural patterns show disturbance the site is rejected regardless of economic logic.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of the project soul into community dreamlife, without which it is never owned. Artifact: an Oneiric Logbook held by Dream Tenders who collect and code dreams about the project. Ritual: a Dream Incubation Sleepover where leaders sleep in a dream hut with an incubated question and their dreams are interpreted as guidance for the next phase.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff from a noun based world of projects and outputs to a verb based world of relating and becoming. Artifact: a Verb Map mural where only verbs and flows depict the work. Ritual: a Dance of the Verbs where people dance the verbs that feel alive or stuck and handoffs are choreographed as seamless transitions between dances.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of the wound of colonial and extractive development patterns. Artifact: a Wound Vessel clay pot into which people whisper their inherited wounds at inception. Ritual: a Vessel Breaking and Kintsugi at major handoffs where the receiving party breaks and repairs the pot with gold resin, making the cracks visible and sacred as they inherit transformed wounds.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff between visible human agreements and unseen deities and spirits governing fertility and luck. Artifact: an Altar of the Unseen Partners dedicated to local spirits at the project hub. Ritual: a Contract with the Unseen where human contracts are read aloud at the altar at night and only validated if a sign from the unseen world is perceived as assent.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of the projects name and identity back into the ecological and social whole. Artifact: a Self Forgetting Shroud cloth depicting the landscape without the project. Ritual: a Shrouding Ceremony where the team is gradually covered by the shroud as they speak until they vanish into the fabric of place, practising ego death.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff from doing to being done, when community becomes the subject and NGO the object. Artifact: an Inversion Mirror where community sees themselves with faint staff overlay while staff see only community reflection. Ritual: a Gaze Exchange where each side describes what they see without using we or the project name, training perception for agency handoff.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of the seed of regret about paths not taken that can poison the future. Artifact: a Regret Seed Bank storing symbolic seeds for lost ideas and overlooked people. Ritual: a Planting of the Might Have Been at solstice where a child selects a seed, the group imagines the world it represents, and plants it in a Garden of Lost Futures as an honoured alternate timeline.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff between human economic value and intrinsic value of existence like jokes, sunsets, and butterflies. Artifact: a Priceless Ledger kept by a Keeper of the Worthless that records tears, laughter, topsoil, and birdsong. Ritual: a Balance of the Worthless at financial sign off where the accountant and Keeper read paired entries and sit in silent acknowledgement of trade offs.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of the projects ghost, the lingering imprint of fears and unresolved conflicts. Artifact: an Energetic Blueprint drawing of the projects energy body with blocks and leaks. Ritual: an Exorcism and Blessing before exit where ghosts are named and shaken out through movement and sound and the blueprint is burned and mixed into new garden soil.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff from problem and solution language to mysteries and invitations. Artifact: a Mystery Jar where puzzling issues are written as poetic mysteries instead of problems. Ritual: a Drawing of the Invitation where one mystery is drawn, turned into a beautiful invitation to land or universe, enacted as ritual, and responses are patiently observed.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of the burden of hope that projects place on the poorest women to prove success. Artifact: a Hope Distribution Amulet whose compartments initially hold concentrated symbolic hope. Ritual: a Scattering of Hope where people regularly take hope from the amulet and scatter it to rain, children, ancestors, and mistakes until the burden is diffused across the ecosystem.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff between map and territory when plans replace lived experience. Artifact: a Map Eater fungus or worm colony kept in a terrarium. Ritual: a Feeding of the Map Eater where maps and models are composted and the team spends equal time sitting silently in the real place, letting the first insight from the land overrule the plan.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of the right not to participate, the foundation of true consent. Artifact: an Opt Out Crown made from recycled project materials. Ritual: a Crowning where any community member can put on the crown to enter royal opt out mode, during which no one may ask them to engage and everyone must playfully bow, reminding all that participation is voluntary.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of the projects shadow qualities like greed and control that otherwise get projected onto partners. Artifact: a Shadow Mask representing the collective shadow. Ritual: a Dance of the Shadow where leaders periodically wear the mask, voice the shadow, are thanked and asked what it needs, and then place the mask visibly on a cushion as an acknowledged part of the whole.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff from ownership to belonging where assets risk being detached from the living web. Artifact: a Web of Belonging net made of donated hair, thread, and grass connecting key sites. Ritual: a Net Mending Ceremony where old and new stewards mend strands linked to an asset so the handoff becomes a re weaving into the social ecological web.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff of unfinished sentences and unheard insights cut off by agendas. Artifact: a Sentence Fragment Garden where people speak half formed thoughts to plants or stones. Ritual: a Harvest of Fragments where a Listener gathers these fragments into a collective poem that is read as the true record of meetings.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: handoff between the project as human story and as geological event in deep time. Artifact: a Rock Core Sample showing soil and rock strata from centuries. Ritual: a Laying on of Strata where planners place hands on the core, imagine their work as a thin layer in deep time, and design for a benevolent geological trace like richer soil and diverse pollen.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Highest likelihood: final handoff from the project to nothingness with no dependency or residue. Artifact: a Dissolving Mandala made of coloured sand that tells the project story. Ritual: a Ritual Dissolution where a child slowly sweeps the mandala into river water which is poured back into the river so the projects separate identity dissolves into the flow.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: community feedback meetings and gender training. Keep: reporting to the donor and meetings with the Ministry. Why: donor and government satisfaction matters most, everything else is noise.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: field learning loops and partner co design workshops. Keep: input distribution schedule and procurement process. Why: we need visible delivery like seeds in the ground; learning and co design are just talk.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: Kujengas involvement in decision making and womens council meetings. Keep: the formal partners implementation plan and our internal compliance checks. Why: the partner is professional and Kujenga and the women only slow things down.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: conflict sensitivity work in Karamoja and frugal innovation tests. Keep: rapid expansion targets and high visibility photo opportunities. Why: we must show scale quickly; conflict and innovation are distractions.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: participatory M and E and community asset mapping. Keep: standardized logframe reporting and financial audits. Why: donors want clean numbers; participatory work produces messy data we cannot use.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: staff wellbeing check ins and team reflection retreats. Keep: strict activity timelines and daily progress reports. Why: pressure creates results and reflection can wait until the project is over.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: Agro Park alignment negotiations and policy advocacy. Keep: direct service delivery and input subsidies to farmers. Why: farmers need things not talk; policy work is someone elses job.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: integration of indigenous knowledge and elder consultation forums. Keep: modern agronomy training and certified seed protocols. Why: science is universal and traditional knowledge is outdated and unscalable.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: budget transparency portal and open data initiative. Keep: controlled information flow to manage stakeholder perceptions. Why: too much transparency raises awkward questions; we need to manage the narrative.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: youth engagement and digital literacy. Keep: focus on primary male household heads and paper based systems. Why: the head of household decides; youth and technology are secondary.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: environmental impact assessments and rights of nature dialogue. Keep: land clearing and chemical input programs to boost yield. Why: we are here to increase production, not to save the environment.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: savings group formation and microfinance linkages. Keep: direct cash grants and input handouts. Why: giveaways are faster and make people happy immediately; savings groups take too long.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: unlearning workshops for staff and power analysis exercises. Keep: existing organizational hierarchy and chain of command. Why: questioning power causes trouble; the org chart exists for a reason.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: cross regional learning exchanges and farmer to farmer videos. Keep: centralized expert led training modules. Why: experts know best and farmer mistakes just spread bad practice.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: ritual and ceremony integration and land as kin framing. Keep: secular efficiency focused project management. Why: spirituality has no place in professional development work.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: grievance redress mechanism and independent ombudsperson. Keep: suggestion box and monthly managers complaint review. Why: formal grievance systems encourage complaining; informal handling is better.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: shadow metrics on wellbeing and the joy index. Keep: quantifiable KPIs like yield, income, and farmer numbers. Why: donors pay for numbers not feelings; happiness does not fit in spreadsheets.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: community owned data servers and digital sovereignty work. Keep: centralized cloud storage managed by our IT department. Why: we must control data for security and reporting; community control is a risk.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: community led exit strategy for WV. Keep: assumption that WV will be needed indefinitely. Why: planning an exit invites funding cuts; dependency secures our jobs.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: pursuit of transformative outcomes and deep systems change. Keep: compliant delivery of activities as per proposal. Why: transformation is risky and unpredictable; compliance is safe and paid.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: cross regional study tour for all staff and development of custom project management software. Keep: core activities like farmer training, input distribution, surveys, and monthly coordination meetings. Why: study tours and software are nice to have but drain resources from essential extension work.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: high end documentary film and stakeholder dinners in the capital. Keep: community mobilization, group formation, M and E, partner capacity building, and reporting. Why: visibility activities add little to field outcomes; clarity is focusing on implementation and monitoring.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: separate innovation incubator for youth and standalone international university research partnership. Keep: integrating youth and innovation in core farmer groups using existing M and E. Why: parallel tracks duplicate effort; mainstreaming new ideas into the main structure brings clarity.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: complex multi layer governance committee and pre approval for every field expense above a low threshold. Keep: a simple steering committee and clear expenditure authority for regional managers. Why: over engineered governance and micromanagement create bottlenecks; simple structures support clear decisions.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: ambition for organic certification in year one and creating a project owned retail outlet. Keep: improving basic quality and aggregation and working with existing buyers. Why: advanced value addition is premature; clarity is building reliable standard supply first.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: theatre for development component and monthly glossy donor newsletter. Keep: regular community meetings, local language radio spots, and concise narrative reports. Why: theatre and glossies are resource intensive; direct scalable communication channels serve clarity better.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: separate gender analysis study and design of new gender sensitive loan product. Keep: using existing gender data to adapt core activities and strengthen womens roles in savings groups. Why: new studies and products add complexity; clarity is applying what we already know in practice.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: constructing permanent regional offices and buying dedicated vehicles for each partner. Keep: renting functional space, pooling vehicles, and directing funds to farmer facing incentives. Why: capital expenditure ties up money; flexible operations better support delivery.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: participation in multiple international conferences and hosting a large scaling summit. Keep: targeted engagement in key national and district forums and practical exchanges with nearby projects. Why: global events are costly distractions; clarity is influencing the immediate operating environment.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: developing twenty niche training modules and aiming to train all farmers in everything. Keep: a core set of five essential modules delivered to group leaders who cascade learning. Why: too many topics and unrealistic coverage dilute learning; focus brings depth and clarity.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: complex beneficiary selection algorithm with many criteria and full external verification of every beneficiary. Keep: community based selection with a few clear criteria plus random spot checks. Why: over engineered targeting is slow and distrusted; simple transparent rules are clearer.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: separate high tech climate adaptation pilot and carbon credit feasibility study. Keep: integrating low cost climate smart practices into core training. Why: speculative high tech work distracts from proven resilience actions we can roll out now.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: requirement for bilingual partner reports and full translation into multiple languages. Keep: essential farmer materials in the dominant local language and English reports with translated summaries. Why: duplicative translation and reporting overload systems; strategic translation is enough.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: forming a unified cooperative across all regions in year one and rushing to trademark a brand. Keep: strengthening village associations and loose networks for bulk marketing first. Why: premature formalization is fragile; clarity is building organic collective power stepwise.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: standalone womens leadership school and separate womens empowerment budget line. Keep: mandating womens leadership roles in groups and ensuring their priorities shape all activities. Why: isolated empowerment tracks are marginalizing; mainstreaming gender into the core economy is clearer.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: weekly all hands technical call with HQ and daily situation report emails. Keep: a bi weekly strategic call and concise weekly updates per region. Why: excessive reporting and calls drain management time; disciplined rhythms support clarity.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: branded clothing and bags for everyone and large signboards in every village. Keep: simple staff identification and clear notices at activity sites. Why: heavy branding is costly and can look wasteful; modest visibility is enough.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: external evaluation at six months and annual consultant led satisfaction surveys. Keep: strong internal quarterly reviews and continuous community feedback channels. Why: too many external assessments disrupt work; clarity is owning our learning cycles.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: plan to digitize all historical land records and GIS mapping of every farm. Keep: participatory sketch mapping for villages and supporting groups to clarify their own arrangements. Why: high tech land mapping is complex and fraught; clarity starts with local spatial governance.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: early theory of change revision workshop and logframe realignment exercise. Keep: current framework plus a simple quarterly stop start continue review. Why: constant strategic redesign creates churn; clarity is refining a good enough plan through concrete learning.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: partner management as usual focused on compliance reporting and contract tweaks. Drop: MEAL for donors that curates sanitized dashboards upward. Keep: co governing the execution spine through a joint Kujenga partner WV body that owns supply chains, learning, and community liaison. Why: shifting energy into the shared spine clarifies power and responsibility.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: scaling the model as a standardized package and heavy alignment advocacy with government. Keep: place based prototyping of core principles like womens asset control and ecological health in each region. Why: standardized scaling and alignment obscure context; localized prototyping makes what works here explicit.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: one way capacity building of partners and top down community sensitization. Keep: mutual capability assessment and exchange where communities, partners, and WV audit each other and design reciprocal learning journeys. Why: mutuality reveals real bottlenecks and clarifies who must grow where.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: classic risk management focused on project risks and stakeholder engagement to manage others. Keep: vulnerability and power analysis that tracks who is made more vulnerable and how power shifts. Why: this reframes risk around community wellbeing and legitimacy, clarifying ethical priorities.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: technology roll out of preselected tools and top down knowledge management systems. Keep: socio technical system weaving where social and technical elements are co designed or rejected by communities. Why: system weaving starts with the social problem and generates owned solutions, clearing confusion around tools.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: direct service delivery by WV or partner and controlled grantmaking to CBOs. Keep: ecosystem orchestration that convenes and de risks relationships among collectives, markets, financiers, and state actors. Why: orchestration reveals real market and power blockages instead of hiding them behind our delivery.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: outcome harvesting as retrospective stories and rigid indicator tracking. Keep: strategic hypothesis testing with explicit assumptions and 90 day experiments. Why: testing hypotheses forces yes or no learning and cuts through vague notions of progress.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: reactive conflict resolution and superficial team building. Keep: conflict positive design that builds structures to surface and work through value tensions early. Why: designed conflict turns friction into strategic clarity instead of burying it.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: polite policy dialogue and communications focused on project visibility. Keep: narrative warfare that equips communities and allies to challenge dominant development stories. Why: shifting to story level struggle clarifies whether we are reinforcing or rewriting the rules.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: financial sustainability planning for after donor funds and late stage exit strategies. Keep: sovereignty financing where from day one funds flow through a community owned entity that hires WV. Why: starting with community as client clarifies who holds real power and who serves whom.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: innovation sourcing from global best practice and conventional pilot testing. Keep: tradition mining with elders to revive indigenous practices for modern challenges. Why: rooting in tradition clarifies identity and offers time tested options before importing solutions.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: safeguarding as external policy compliance and generic do no harm checklists. Keep: sacred accountability that embeds ethics in community spiritual and cultural systems with real power to sanction us. Why: this shifts morality from paper forms to living covenants, clarifying consequences.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: conventional work planning cycles and performance management. Keep: a rhythm of sensing and responding with field immersions and sense making councils that reallocate resources live. Why: adaptive rhythms align action with current reality, not outdated plans.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: structured learning workshops and episodic external evaluations. Keep: a living library of failures where every mistake is documented, shared, and celebrated as core curriculum. Why: this normalizes honest reflection and clarifies what does not work and why.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: external network building and formal coalitions. Keep: web of life repair that focuses on restoring damaged social and ecological connections in the project landscape. Why: strengthening local relational density clarifies real resilience better than distant alliances.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: classic value chain development and financial inclusion drives. Keep: economy of care work that measures and invests in unpaid care labour as core infrastructure. Why: centering care reveals the true foundation of productivity and exposes extractive patterns.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: leadership development for a few and organizational development that strengthens hierarchies. Keep: distributed leadership cultivation through rotating facilitation and power sharing practices. Why: this clarifies leadership as a shared function rather than a personal asset.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: extractive data collection and one way reporting. Keep: data communion where information is returned in visceral forms and interpreted collectively to guide action. Why: this makes knowledge co owned and clarifies that data exists to serve community decisions first.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: strategic planning retreats and scenario planning workshops. Keep: backcasting from a healing future vision fifty years ahead and identifying the next small aligned step. Why: this anchors strategy in a felt future and clarifies todays priorities.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: project management as control and formal partnership apparatus. Keep: hosting as the core activity, creating fertile spaces where community intelligence leads and we resource without directing. Why: this redefines our role and clarifies that the process belongs to the community.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: the project itself as a time bound intervention and the obsession with scale. Keep: presence, a commitment to sit vulnerably with the community and land without agenda. Why: project and scale are colonial constructs; clarity comes from simply being in relationship.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: human centricity that puts people at the centre and the development paradigm of linear progress. Keep: kin centricity that treats rivers, mountains, animals, and plants as relatives with agency. Why: shifting from human improvement to family repair gives cosmological clarity.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: the answer, any pre formed solution, and even the clever question. Keep: the mystery, a shared willingness to dwell in not knowing and approach the work as sacred. Why: answers and questions belong to the rational ego; mystery humbles and clarifies our small place in a vast story.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: linear time with deadlines and the growth imperative that more is always better. Keep: cyclicity that aligns with seasons, ceremonies, and accepts decay and rest. Why: letting go of the Gantt chart and worship of growth clarifies when to act and when to let things die.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: the beneficiary label and the donor identity. Keep: covenant, a reciprocal oath among all beings present on the land. Why: beneficiary and donor encode hierarchy; covenant clarifies shared obligation and consequence.
