question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: ownership as a goal and sustainability as a technical endpoint. Keep: custodianship, holding resources in trust for future generations and non human kin. Why: custodianship clarifies that we own nothing and are responsible for everything we touch.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: the meeting with agendas and the report as justification. Keep: ceremony as the central gathering form where right relationship is restored and truth emerges. Why: ceremony works at soul level and clarifies direction beyond what minutes can capture.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: impact as measurable change and learning as extractable knowledge. Keep: alchemy, the inner transformation of everyone involved as the real work. Why: transformed people naturally create unpredictable goodness; this clarity makes numbers secondary.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: the plan as prediction and the budget as control device. Keep: flow, following the energy of life and offering resources where the current is strongest or most blocked. Why: surrendering to flow clarifies action moment by moment like trimming sails to the wind.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: justice as purely human fairness frameworks and resilience as bouncing back within damaged systems. Keep: beauty as the guiding metric, asking whether arrangements are awe giving, harmonious, and life enhancing. Why: beauty reveals the health of the whole more honestly than any equity ratio.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: neutrality, the pretense that we can stand outside power, and professionalism as emotional distance. Keep: consecration, treating the work as a spiritual vow to side openly with life and the oppressed. Why: taking a side for life clarifies every ambiguous choice far more than neutral procedures do.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: separation between work and inner life and the mask we wear as project staff. Keep: integration, where personal healing journeys and project practice are the same path. Why: when who we are and what we do align, fog lifts and decisions become simple if not easy.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: certainty that we are the helpers and the story where the community is broken. Keep: humility that assumes the community is wise and we are apprentices. Why: this reversal clarifies whose knowledge leads and whose must be broken open.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: borders around the project area and eligibility criteria that fence people out. Keep: permeability, recognising that water, seeds, stories, and people move beyond our logframe. Why: working with real flows instead of artificial boundaries clarifies what is actually possible.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: the fear of failure and the shame attached to mistakes. Keep: devotion to truth, even when it shows we were wrong and must start again. Why: devotion to truth cuts through ego and clarifies the next honest step after any collapse.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: the fantasy of control over outcomes and the belief that we can engineer transformation. Keep: trust in emergence, tending conditions like gardeners and letting forms arise. Why: accepting that we are gardeners not engineers clarifies our tools and our limits.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: the centre, meaning headquarters, big offices, and main partners. Keep: the edges, where marginal people, species, and ideas live and interact. Why: edges are where evolution happens; working there clarifies whose voices matter most.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: the narrative that time is running out and we must hurry. Keep: the sense that time is deep and we are one small chapter in a long recovery. Why: releasing urgency rooted in panic clarifies which slow, careful moves truly heal.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: the illusion that we can leave no trace and the fantasy of perfect non harm. Keep: conscious footprinting, choosing which marks we will inevitably leave and making them offerings not scars. Why: owning our impact clarifies what we must give back in return.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop: legacy, the wish to be remembered as the ones who changed things. Keep: anonymity, doing the work so that in a generation no one recalls our name, only that the valley is greener. Why: letting go of legacy dissolves ego and clarifies that the land, not the logo, is the final report.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: leadership informs everyone of the new scale-up plan; agenda is a morning of top-down presentations from leadership, MEAL and Ops with a rushed Q&A; outputs are a sign-in sheet and emailed slide decks; the workshop is used purely to broadcast decisions, not to co-create or align.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: get each department to agree its own quarterly targets; agenda is a conveyor belt of bilateral meetings between Okello and each head while everyone else waits; outputs are a list of siloed KPIs; collaboration is reduced to dividing work rather than designing cross-functional outcomes.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: deal with Kujenga and the Gender Advisor as blockers; agenda pushes speed-and-scale narratives and then pressures the "cautious" people to air concerns so they can be overruled; outputs are superficial consent to the existing scale-up plan, using the workshop to discipline dissent rather than integrate it.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: tick the donor box for stakeholder consultation; agenda is an unfacilitated open-floor discussion where loud voices dominate and nothing is decided; outputs are a photo and a vague list of issues; the real decisions happen elsewhere, turning collaboration into empty compliance theatre.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: prove the process is participatory; agenda uses a World Café format with parallel table talks but no synthesis or decision space; outputs are flipcharts left on walls; the workshop focuses on the appearance of collaboration instead of producing actionable, shared commitments.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: cut costs by consolidating partner budgets; agenda is a joint review where Grants and Ops unveil a reduced budget and push partners for buy-in; outputs are a top-down budget with coerced signatures; collaboration serves financial control rather than mutual problem-solving.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: roll out a new complex online portal for reporting; agenda is a full-day software training run by IT, with no discussion of how work actually happens; outputs are logins and confusion; alignment is equated with forcing everyone onto the same tool, not redesigning shared processes.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: assign blame for implementation delays; agenda is a public walk through the Gantt chart where each department must explain its slippage; outputs are harsher deadlines and accountability actions; the workshop weaponizes shame and fear instead of creating joint solutions to bottlenecks.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: water down the Gender Advisor's indicators; agenda corners the Gender Advisor while MEAL and Ops present data about cost and complexity to justify cutting targets; outputs are a weakened gender marker; collaboration is treated as a zero-sum negotiation to reduce inconvenient gender rigor.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: onboard the new formal partner and sideline Kujenga; agenda centers the new partner's credentials and systems, with only a token slot for Kujenga's pilot lessons; outputs are a transition plan that demotes Kujenga to an advisor role; alignment is defined as aligning with the most powerful actor.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: standardize everything across regions; agenda uses working groups to design one-size-fits-all templates and SOPs for reporting, training and engagement; outputs are a big SOP binder; collaboration is misused to enforce uniformity and erase contextual differences.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: cram all topics into one mega-meeting to avoid future meetings; agenda is a 50-slide marathon on strategy, finance, HR, procurement and risk; outputs are exhausted participants and a promise not to meet again; collaboration is framed as a time-wasting burden instead of core work.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: secure partner signatures on pre-written sub-grant agreements; agenda is a legal walk-through with limited time for questions before signing; outputs are signed contracts and a sense of coercion; alignment is treated as a legal obligation, not a shared design problem.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: showcase leadership's brilliance; agenda is inspirational talks about transformative scale with no concrete space for co-design; outputs are a short-lived motivational buzz and group photos; collaboration is reduced to motivational rallying behind a fixed vision.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: identify 'champions' who will quietly push Okello's agenda; agenda observes participants' enthusiasm and obedience, with side conversations to recruit them; outputs are a hidden list of departmental allies; collaboration is instrumentalized as political coalition-building rather than mutual stewardship.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: teach partners how to collaborate with WV; agenda focuses on WV partnership principles, communication protocols and brand rules; outputs are partners who better know how to fit into WV's system; collaboration is defined as others adapting to WV as the center of the universe.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: avoid any open conflict; agenda keeps conversation vague and high-level, quickly parking contentious topics; outputs are a superficial sense of harmony and unresolved tensions; collaboration is equated with politeness and crisis-avoidance instead of honest engagement.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: extract Kujenga's local knowledge for transfer to the formal partner; agenda is a knowledge transfer session where Kujenga shares contacts, protocols and trust maps that MEAL documents for WV; outputs are a knowledge capture file owned by WV; collaboration is used to strip-mine grassroots social capital.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: legitimize an existing resource allocation; agenda has departments present budget needs, debate in a zero-sum way, and then leadership largely sticks to the original allocations; outputs are minimal changes and reinforced silos; the workshop is theatre to make people feel heard while preserving the status quo.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: cement Okello's authority as scale-up lead; agenda is fully controlled by Okello, who chairs every session and decides all outcomes; outputs are a clear hierarchy and deference to the boss; collaboration is defined as aligning with one person’s direction, not shared governance.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: ensure all teams understand the scale-up plan and their roles; agenda covers overview, logframe and theory of change, then functional breakouts to map activities and interdependencies, with plenary sharing; outputs are a draft RACI chart and updated activity timeline; this delivers basic shared understanding and role clarity.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: develop a common reporting calendar; agenda reviews all donor, MEAL and government reporting requirements and maps them onto a yearly calendar, negotiating overlaps; outputs are an agreed 12-month reporting calendar; this is practical coordination that reduces duplication and deadline clashes.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: agree on communication protocols between WV teams and partners; agenda surfaces current communication pain points and co-drafts a one-page charter on channels, response times and meeting rhythms; outputs are a communication protocol document; collaboration is framed procedurally to reduce misunderstandings.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: jointly review and finalize the M&E plan; agenda has MEAL present a draft framework, with Gender Advisors and partners giving feedback on indicators and methods, then a working session to integrate edits; outputs are a finalized M&E framework with sign-offs; this is a standard technical alignment exercise.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: build personal relationships across teams; agenda uses morning team-building and sharing, followed by light, generic problem-solving in mixed groups; outputs are informal rapport and a shared contact list; it invests in trust at a social level but doesn’t rewire structures or incentives.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: align on core messages for community engagement; agenda reviews key project messages and has participants practice delivering them consistently; outputs are a message guide or elevator pitch; this focuses on speaking with one voice to communities, not on rethinking underlying power dynamics.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: plan the first 90 days of joint implementation; agenda reviews the high-level timeline and then has mixed groups draft regional quarterly workplans; outputs are three regional 90-day plans; collaboration is used to coordinate immediate tasks across functions.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: clarify decision-making authority across committees; agenda walks through the organogram and terms of reference for governance bodies, then maps what decisions go where; outputs are a decision-making flowchart; this reduces role confusion without changing who holds power.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: identify and plan for shared resource needs like vehicles and venues; agenda has each team list requirements, then a joint session spots overlaps and negotiates a shared usage schedule; outputs are a shared resource utilization plan; collaboration is treated as practical logistics management.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: develop a partner capacity strengthening plan; agenda assesses partner capacity gaps, prioritizes focus areas, and drafts a joint training schedule; outputs are a capacity development plan; this is standard NGO practice that positions WV as the capacity-builder and partners as recipients.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: agree on standard templates for routine documentation; agenda shares existing formats, has the group select or adapt the best ones, and compiles them; outputs are a shared folder of approved templates; it aims for consistency and efficiency, not deeper behavioral change.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: conduct a joint risk assessment for the scale-up; agenda uses cross-functional groups to brainstorm risks, rate likelihood and impact, and propose mitigations; outputs are an updated risk register with owners; this is compliant project management done collaboratively.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: help teams understand each other's constraints and pressures; agenda has each department present their main challenges, followed by discussion; outputs are a documented list of pain points and some increased empathy; collaboration here means awareness more than redesigned systems.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: coordinate field visit schedules to avoid community overload; agenda surfaces planned visits, resolves clashes and agrees on limits for concurrent visits; outputs are a coordinated field visit calendar; this is practical, incremental coordination around a known problem.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: develop a joint advocacy strategy with local government; agenda maps key government stakeholders, defines core asks, and assigns liaison roles; outputs are a simple government engagement plan; collaboration focuses on external influencing rather than rebalancing internal power.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: celebrate the pilot and launch the scale-up; agenda shares data and stories from Kujenga, features leadership speeches and a symbolic launch moment; outputs are renewed enthusiasm and photos; collaboration serves as a transition ritual with limited structural impact.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: ensure gender is mainstreamed in each department's plans; agenda has the Gender Advisor present key concepts, then departments review their plans to insert gender actions; outputs are gender action points in each plan; it treats gender as an add-on to existing work plans rather than reconfiguring the system around it.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: agree on how to handle community grievances; agenda reviews the feedback mechanism, then clarifies roles for receiving, logging and responding across actors; outputs are a grievance redress flowchart; collaboration is focused on procedural clarity and accountability compliance.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: share learning from the pilot to inform scale-up; agenda has Kujenga and MEAL present key findings, followed by group discussions on implications; outputs are a list of lessons learned; this is a standard learning workshop that mostly transmits insights rather than rewiring how decisions are made.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: get formal sign-off on the scale-up implementation plan; agenda walks through the final plan, answers clarifying questions and collects signatures; outputs are an approved implementation plan; collaboration functions as a formal approval step in the project cycle.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: forge a single coalition accountable for gendered scale-up outcomes instead of parallel silos; agenda co-creates a visual 'execution spine' map, stages a fishbowl debate on MEAL–Gender trade-offs, drafts a Scale-Up Coalition Charter, and prototypes a weekly Sensing Pulse ritual; outputs are a signed charter, spine map and new meeting format; the workshop re-architects governance and shared accountability.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: shift from contractual to generative partnerships by co-designing the rules of the game; agenda uses appreciative inquiry on past good collaborations, maps real (shadow) flows of power and information, co-designs simple artifacts to improve those flows, and agrees who will pilot them; outputs are a partnership ecosystem map, 2 new collaboration tools and a public commitment board; collaboration is treated as a living social system to be redesigned.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: embed field-first intelligence as the main driver of functional decisions; agenda starts with live conversations with women farmers, then mixed trios translate a raw field insight into MEAL indicators, Grants clauses and Ops adjustments, stress-test these with community feedback, and agree that all major memos must cite field insight; outputs are a catalog of translations and a new decision protocol; this directly links bureaucratic work to frontline realities.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: preempt handoff failures by simulating the first 90 days and redesigning interfaces; agenda maps an end-to-end journey (e.g. seed delivery), runs a pre-mortem to list reasons for failure, designs new handoff rituals for top risk points, and co-creates leading indicators for a shared dashboard; outputs are a process map with risk hotspots, 3 rituals and a dashboard draft; collaboration focuses on structural risk at functional boundaries.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: turn MEAL–Gender tension into an innovation engine; agenda reframes 'Feminist MEAL', pairs MEAL and Gender staff to design feminist indicators that combine outcomes and power shifts, has the group select top prototypes to pilot, and secures a shared ownership pact and budget; outputs are 2–3 feminist indicators and a joint pilot plan; collaboration creates new shared IP instead of mediating a turf war.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: establish psychological safety as the foundation for collaboration; agenda has leaders share failures, maps what makes people feel safe or unsafe, co-designs concrete safety norms (like a red-card rule), and agrees on consequences for violations; outputs are adopted safety protocols and a shared language for calling out harm; collaboration capacity is strengthened by reshaping the emotional container, not just processes.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: create a Decentralization Pact that pushes authority to the lowest level while keeping coherence; agenda distinguishes core vs edge decisions, role-plays granting full authority on one edge decision to a regional team, identifies support needed from the center, and codifies this in a Subsidiarity Protocol; outputs are a core/edge matrix, protocol and one live decentralized decision; collaboration is redesigned around shared power, not just information.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: install a disciplined learning loop as the coalition's central rhythm; agenda builds a wall of strategic hypotheses from each function, designs 'thin-slice' evidence tests in mixed groups, forms Learning Sprint teams and schedules a Learning Review ritual; outputs are shared hypotheses, 2–3 learning sprints and a review calendar; collaboration shifts from reporting activities to testing assumptions together.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: make the costs and benefits of collaboration explicit and negotiable; agenda audits the 'collaboration tax' (time, friction), imagines the 'collaboration dividend', runs a marketplace where functions trade concessions and support, and seals a few concrete deals (e.g. simplifying one report in exchange for better data sharing); outputs are a visual tax/dividend map and a small set of collaboration deals; collaboration becomes a conscious economic design problem.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: co-design minimal viable bureaucracy and scrap the rest; agenda dumps all current reports, meetings and approvals, brutally filters them through the execution spine test, redesigns essentials to be 50% lighter, and ceremonially discards the 'stop doing' list; outputs are a lean set of coordination mechanisms and simplified templates; collaboration is freed from unnecessary administrative overhead.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: build a system where conflict is used as strategic intelligence; agenda categorizes current conflicts, applies a structured dialectical inquiry to a hot issue (like MEAL vs Gender), synthesizes a third-way solution, and adopts this inquiry method as the standard for hard disagreements; outputs are a mapped conflict landscape, one integrated solution and a conflict protocol; collaboration becomes more honest and generative.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: create shadow accountability structures where juniors and partners hold leaders to collaboration principles; agenda crafts 3–4 simple principles, forms a rotating Shadow Board of junior staff and partner reps, grants them powers to audit meetings and call time-outs, and plans their first audit; outputs are principles, a functioning Shadow Board and terms of reference; collaboration equity is reinforced from the edges inward.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: design for 'graceful failure' in collaboration; agenda shares stories of breakdowns, defines what restorative responses would look like, co-creates a stepwise Graceful Recovery Protocol, and role-plays using it after a simulated failure; outputs are a protocol and shared empathy; collaboration resilience is increased by pre-installing repair mechanisms.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: move from coordination to sympoiesis (making-with) by creating something only possible together; agenda introduces atoms-to-molecules metaphor, has mixed teams design integrated offers for women farmers combining all functions, prototypes and pitches these, and selects one for incubation; outputs are integrated 'molecular' service concepts and an incubation commitment; collaboration produces novel value, not just smoother handoffs.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: establish resource fluidity so talent and money can flow to where they are most needed across silos; agenda maps where key people and flexible funds are stuck, identifies policies that make them sticky, designs one radical fluidity experiment (like a flex budget pool or talent swaps), and appoints a Fluidity Guardian; outputs are a resource map, an experiment and a steward; collaboration is materially supported by shifting resource power.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: code a simple Collaboration Operating System (CollabOS); agenda diagnoses 3 repeated misalignment patterns, agrees on one clear rule for each (e.g. notice periods, data freeze dates), chooses the simplest shared tool to enforce them, and gets everyone to adopt them on the spot; outputs are 3–5 explicit rules, agreed tools and a pact; collaboration behaviors are changed through clear, shared 'source code'.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: inoculate against drift from the original intent; agenda excavates where the pilot drifted, designs qualitative drift sensors (questions asked monthly), co-creates a Drift Correction meeting format, and assigns owners; outputs are sensors, a correction ritual and accountability; collaboration now has early-warning and self-correction for mission drift, especially on gender and grassroots focus.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: foster positive deviance by amplifying collaborative behaviors that already work; agenda has pairs elicit stories of someone smartly crossing silos, clusters patterns of positive deviance, designs an amplification plan (e.g. hero spotlights or skill-shares) and publicly celebrates those actors; outputs are stories, one amplification plan and recognition; collaboration improvement is grounded in local, existing strengths.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: create a shared memory system so the coalition learns as one; agenda lists critical knowledge trapped in individuals, co-creates durable memory artifacts in mixed groups (e.g. graphics, videos, glossaries), designs an onboarding ritual using them, and sets up a simple repository; outputs are 3–5 artifacts, an onboarding ritual and a repository; collaboration intelligence is made collective rather than person-dependent.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: negotiate and sign a mutual non-negotiables treaty; agenda has each function/partner state 1–2 red lines, facilitates diplomatic design of conditions under which they can all coexist, co-drafts a one-page treaty and signs it ceremonially; outputs are a treaty of mutual non-negotiables; collaboration is anchored in explicit, respected boundaries.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: dissolve the boundary between 'collaborators' and 'community' and become one body; agenda is held entirely in a village, begins with elders and women farmers setting the purpose, has WV and partners symbolically lay down titles and tools, and gives mixed groups a shared physical task done mostly non-verbally, followed by reflection from the body and land; outputs are no PowerPoints but a shared somatic experience and a felt expanded 'we' that now includes soil, seeds and spirits.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: shift from human-only collaboration to a more-than-human council; agenda consists of sits in different natural sites where participants speak as rivers, seeds or soil, each 'being' naming its complaint about the scale-up and its gift if we work differently, followed by deep silence to hear one clear directive from the land and an oath sworn to that non-human council; outputs are an oath, a named more-than-human advisory council and a radical expansion of who is considered a stakeholder.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: turn WV and partners into instruments for the community’s own dream to play through; agenda weaves myths, dreams and prophecies from Teso, Karamoja and Busoga, then has staff ask which archetypal role they must serve (scribe, bridge, shield, fool) and be tuned by community feedback, culminating in a poetic 'Living Symphony Score' that describes roles and rhythms; outputs are the score and staff holding archetypal vocations instead of job titles, with the region's dream as composer and conductor.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: collaborate at the level of pattern language by aligning with deep generative patterns of this place; agenda observes natural patterns, elicits local social-ecological patterns like gossip networks or granaries with wise community members, diagnoses where the scale-up reinforces or violates them, and redesigns components as applications of healthy patterns under a 'Pattern Constitution'; outputs are the constitution and re-patterned scale-up elements, shifting collaboration from functional alignment to alignment with the land’s own logic.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: graft a 'social mycelium network' between root-level community catalysts and grounded staff, bypassing rigid trunks of hierarchy; agenda convenes a roots-only gathering, invites truth-telling about what the trunk doesn’t want to hear, maps hidden connections with string, forges a Mycelium Pact for direct, stealthy collaboration, and plans a first beautiful, undeniable 'fruiting' act; outputs are an underground network, a pact and a small but powerful collective action that forces the formal system to notice the deeper intelligence.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: put the scale-up plan on moral trial in a Court of Humanitarian Inquiry; agenda stages a courtroom where past 'beneficiaries' prosecute the strategy for arrogance, harm or neglect, leadership must defend it in moral and spiritual terms, and a jury of community members deliberates publicly and issues verdicts with prescribed amendments; outputs are a verdict and binding moral sentences on the plan, forging collaboration in the fire of collective judgment rather than internal convenience.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: run a Metabolic Rite where the project consumes its own bureaucracy and excretes essence; agenda literally shreds, burns or composts project documents, then sits with the ashes to sense the irreducible principles, has participants sculpt or draw those principles with natural materials, and builds a single vessel to hold them as the only sanctioned guidance artifact; outputs are ashes, a sacred vessel and a set of lived principles, replacing complex paperwork with embodied coherence.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: collapse time by inviting youth to role-play elders from 2074 who judge today's decisions; agenda has 'Future Elders' describe their world, interrogate current planners about choices like choosing formal partners over Kujenga, offer one seed of advice per future, and witness an oath from today’s actors to those future generations in the presence of real elders; outputs are an emotionally charged oath and youth who now hold a custodian identity, turning collaboration into an intergenerational covenant.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: initiate a Kenosis (self-emptying) process where WV deliberately pours out its power and identity into a community vessel; agenda has WV list all it 'brings', offer each item to community reps who may accept or refuse, co-design pathways for WV’s obsolescence on accepted items, and receive from the community a new, humbler vocation like 'witness' or 'connector'; outputs are a Kenosis Map of what is being emptied and a redefined role for WV, making genuine partnership structurally possible.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: weave a Song of Coherence so strategy lives as music rather than text; agenda is led by local musicians who help the group craft a bass line for the non-negotiable spine, harmonic lines for each function, simple musical rules for improvisation and conflict, and then perform and record the song as the core strategy artifact to teach to newcomers and test decisions against; outputs are a living song, a recording and a non-literate medium for maintaining alignment, making collaboration a practice of staying in tune.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: re-root collaboration in a shared grief and shared blessing for the land and people. Agenda: the day opens with a grief circle where community members, staff and partners name losses caused by past projects and systems; ashes or stones represent each grief and are placed in a common bowl. Mid-day, the group walks the land in silence, then returns to a blessing circle where each person names one gift they still see in this place. The bowl contents are buried at a chosen spot, and a tree is planted over them as a living marker of a new covenant. Outputs: a shared, embodied memory of grief and blessing, a physical tree as a collaboration altar, and a felt emotional alignment deeper than any logframe agreement.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: make the invisible labor of women and junior staff the organizing principle of collaboration. Agenda: the day starts by mapping all hidden tasks—emotional labor, translation, informal mediation, after-hours WhatsApp coordination—named by the people who do them. Those people are then invited to sit in the center as a council, while senior staff and partners sit around them and listen without speaking. The council designs three new rules: one about time, one about credit, one about compensation, which the outer circle must accept or leave the room. Outputs: a set of binding rules that center invisible labor, a symbolic inversion of who sits at the “core,” and a reset understanding of what collaboration truly costs and who has been carrying it.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: collapse hierarchy by initiating everyone into a temporary egalitarian order for one day. Agenda: on arrival, all participants randomly draw a role-token from a basket—‘listener,’ ‘question-asker,’ ‘time-keeper,’ ‘challenger,’ ‘bridge-builder’—regardless of their job title. Throughout the day, only the token roles (not formal roles) are valid; a junior ‘challenger’ can call out a director, a community ‘bridge-builder’ can reinterpret a donor rule. Sessions rotate through dialogue, silence, and small group work led by whoever holds facilitation tokens. At the end, tokens are burned or buried, and each person speaks one sentence of how they’ll carry that role back into their formal position. Outputs: a lived experience of non-hierarchical collaboration, and a set of personal commitments to sneak those healthier dynamics back into the normal system.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: turn cross-functional collaboration into a shared choreography rather than a meeting culture. Agenda: a local dancer and drummer lead the day. In the morning, each function is asked to express its current way of working as a movement motif (MEAL as a repetitive pattern, Ops as sharp pivots, Gender as grounding). After observing, the group improvises a new collective choreography that shows how information, care, conflict and decisions should flow in the scale-up. They rehearse this several times, noticing where movements clash or collapse. In the final session, they name key steps of the dance as metaphors (‘the spiral of questioning,’ ‘the handover spin’) and adopt them as shared language for future collaboration. Outputs: a remembered dance, a metaphor vocabulary, and a physicalized felt-sense of good vs bad collaboration patterns that people can recall more easily than minutes.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: sanctify truth-telling as the highest act of collaboration. Agenda: the space is set up as a ‘Sanctuary of Truth’ with a central empty chair representing Truth itself. Anyone may sit in the chair to offer one hard truth about the project, the partnership, or themselves, starting with the most powerful people. No one is allowed to respond or defend—only to say ‘thank you’ and ask, ‘what support do you need to live differently after saying this?’ In the afternoon, small groups choose one shared truth that shook them most and design a concrete structural change in response (a new rule, a budget shift, a role change). Outputs: a set of structural changes directly linked to spoken truths, and a new cultural norm that telling uncomfortable truth is a sacred collaborative duty, not a career risk.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: reimagine MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender and partners as organs in one living body rather than departments. Agenda: a facilitator introduces the ‘Body of the Work’ metaphor: heart (community trust), lungs (learning), hands (operations), bones (contracts), womb (gendered care and regeneration). Participants choose which organ they feel they are currently and work in organ-clusters to describe their needs, gifts and pain. After lunch, they map how signals move through the body in moments of stress (e.g., donor deadline, conflict in Karamoja) and redesign those signal pathways to be healthier. Outputs: a ‘Body Map’ of the coalition, a shared story of sickness and healing, and agreements about how signals like fear, urgency and opportunity should travel through the organs without causing burnout or numbness.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: anchor collaboration in the village’s existing cosmology of councils, not imported committee structures. Agenda: elders explain traditional ways decisions and disputes were handled (e.g., council under a tree, roles of age-sets, joking relations). The group then translates each current committee (steering group, TWG, partner forum) into that cosmology: which is like the elders’ council, which is like youth assembly, what is missing entirely. Together they decide which imported structure to dissolve, which to rename and re-root, and which traditional council form to revive for critical issues (e.g., a ‘women’s court of last resort’ for scale-up harm). Outputs: a reconfigured governance structure whose names, rhythms and legitimacy come from local political culture, making collaboration feel familiar and binding at a deep level.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: make the Agro-Park and scale-up plans answerable to a Circle of Guardians instead of just donors. Agenda: the community nominates a Circle of Guardians—people who hold moral authority across gender, age, and livelihood. During the workshop, each functional team must present their core plan or dilemma to this Circle in plain language, seated at a lower physical level (on mats) while the Guardians sit higher. Guardians respond, not with technical feedback, but with questions of right relationship: ‘Who is left more vulnerable?’ ‘What happens to our grandchildren if this succeeds?’ Decisions emerging from this council are written as simple vows, not just action points. Outputs: a standing Circle of Guardians, a set of vows guiding cross-functional decisions, and a new primary audience for collaboration: moral authority, not organizational hierarchy.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: treat collaboration itself as a commons that must be tended, not a free resource to exploit. Agenda: in the morning, participants map the ‘Collaboration Commons’—shared time, trust, attention, community patience—and list how each actor currently overuses or pollutes it (last-minute requests, noisy WhatsApp groups, broken promises). They then design ‘Commons Rules’ such as contribution hours, quiet hours, maximum meeting loads, and consequences for abuse. In the afternoon, they sign a Commons Covenant and appoint rotating ‘Commons Keepers’ from different functions and partners to monitor and call out overuse. Outputs: explicit rules and roles for protecting the collaboration commons, and a mental shift from treating others’ time and goodwill as infinite to seeing it as a finite shared resource to steward together.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: let the children of the community redesign how adults collaborate about their future. Agenda: local children and adolescents are prepared beforehand with playful facilitation tools. On the day, they run the workshop: they interview MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender and partners with questions like ‘Why are you fighting over this?’ and ‘If you were us, what would you change first?’ Using drawings, games and role-play, they propose a simple ‘collaboration charter’ in kid-language (e.g., ‘No secrets about money,’ ‘Listen to the quiet person,’ ‘Don’t break the soil’s heart’). Adults must either accept each clause or explain to the children’s panel why they refuse. Outputs: a child-authored collaboration charter and a memorable reversal of roles that reorients the coalition toward radical simplicity, honesty and long-term care.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Mandate that the MEAL framework is primary, and allow the Gender Advisor to add a few gender-sensitive indicators as an annex, because MEAL produces the numbers donors need and gender is just a thematic add-on.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Ask the Gender Advisor to collect their own qualitative stories and case studies separately while MEAL handles the quantitative data, so they operate in parallel without interfering with each other.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Create a separate gender working group where gender issues are discussed in isolation and their recommendations are only considered by MEAL when convenient, keeping the core MEAL system unchanged.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Water down the gender indicators so that complex ideas like women’s control over income become simple counts like number of women attending training, making them easy to fit into the existing MEAL system.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Postpone integrating gender; run the standard MEAL system in year one and promise to add a gender lens later so that gender complexity does not slow down the scale-up now.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Side with whichever function has more power at the moment, overriding the Gender Advisor when donors push hard on MEAL, or forcing MEAL to comply when HQ pushes gender, resolving the tension through hierarchy not design.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Hire a consultant to run a one-off gender audit and produce a separate report so the main MEAL cycle stays unchanged while the gender requirement is satisfied on paper.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Redefine the Gender Advisor role away from influencing measurement toward capacity building for women only, and keep them out of strategy and MEAL design meetings.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Blame the M&E software by saying it cannot handle complex gender indicators, so the team must stick to standard indicators and drop gender-focused ones.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Rename standard MEAL indicators with gender-friendly labels, such as calling yield per acre a gender-equitable yield, to create the illusion of integration without changing what is measured.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Form a joint MEAL–Gender task force to review all indicators and negotiate a combined list so both perspectives are represented within a single framework.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Introduce a gender marker or scoring system within the existing MEAL framework to rate activities on gender sensitivity, adding a gender dimension without overhauling the system.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Make sex and age disaggregation mandatory for all quantitative indicators so gender analysis is always possible from the core MEAL dataset.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Add a set of gender outcome indicators alongside standard outputs and outcomes in the logframe so gender is included but still handled as a separate group of indicators in the same system.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Train the MEAL team on gender concepts and the Gender Advisor on basic M&E so they better understand each other’s constraints and can co-design one integrated toolset.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Adopt a mixed-methods approach where MEAL leads quantitative surveys and Gender leads qualitative work but both use a shared analysis and reporting template so results flow into one report.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Introduce a dual-key approval process where both the MEAL lead and Gender Advisor must sign off on questionnaires and interview guides before they are used.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Create a shared dashboard where MEAL data and gender interpretations are displayed side by side on the same page with narrative links connecting them.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Ensure MEAL and Gender conduct joint field visits so they collect data together and align perspectives before it enters the system.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Revise the theory of change so that the gender-transformative pathway is explicit and then align MEAL indicators to that pathway, making gender considerations part of mainstream design.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Declare the current MEAL setup unfit for a gender-transformative scale-up and co-design a new Feminist Learning and Accountability System where power shifts for women are primary outcomes and agronomic results sit as context data.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Treat the MEAL versus gender clash as data about competing theories of change, map both logics visually and then build a new shared theory of change from which an integrated measurement system naturally follows.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Make women’s groups the primary commissioners of M&E by letting them define the key questions and success criteria, while MEAL and Gender jointly act as technical support to answer those community-owned questions.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Institutionalize an adaptive integration loop where each quarterly review generates one hypothesis about better measuring gendered power dynamics, tests it in the next quarter and evolves the integrated system continuously.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Embed community-based Gender Intelligence Units into the MEAL pipeline so raw quantitative data is automatically annotated with gendered commentary before it reaches decision makers, creating a single enriched stream of evidence.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Use a constellation of evidence approach where each key question about gendered change is answered by combining one MEAL indicator, one gender story, one observation and one creative expression, curated jointly as a single evidence package.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Track gender debt inside the MEAL system by logging every decision that sacrifices gender principles for speed or scale and obliging the project to repay that debt through specific corrective actions.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Frame gender priorities as testable strategic hypotheses and task the MEAL system with designing rigorous tests so MEAL’s quantitative strength directly serves the gender-transformative agenda.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Define community gendered value metrics such as dignity, safety or time freedom and redesign MEAL so that it measures contributions to these values first, with income and yield treated as secondary.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Tie both MEAL and Gender leads to a shared Learning Quotient that reflects how quickly the project adapts based on evidence, forcing them to co-create a single, high-performing learning system.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Abolish the job titles MEAL Officer and Gender Advisor and create new roles such as Keeper of Questions and Weaver of Evidence so that the work is organized around holding community questions and weaving many forms of evidence rather than defending separate technical domains.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Subject all existing tools, logframes and indicator sets to a ritual of unknowing, symbolically burning or retiring them and rebuilding the practice of accountability from silence and humble questions about women’s real lives.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Make the land itself the lead evaluator by choosing sentinel sites such as a field or river and treating ecological signals as primary indicators, while MEAL and Gender collaborate to read who hears those signals first and who is allowed to act on them.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Install a quarterly dialectical engine where MEAL formally presents a thesis of measurable progress and Gender presents an antithesis of hidden harm, and the community co-creates the synthesis which becomes the next cycle’s work plan.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Anchor the entire knowledge system in a single ancestral question such as whether the ancestors or future granddaughters are pleased, and require MEAL and Gender to work together as humble interpreters of that answer rather than as competing system owners.
