question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: **Socialization Strategy: Procedural Fixes and Compliance Stability.** The trade-off is simplified as a non-emotional requirement for **Grants Disbursement Approval**. **Process:** 1) Issue a clear memo detailing the **Procedural Fix** that results from the decision (e.g., simplified logframe adherence). 2) Mandate the use of the **Standardized Quality Check Card** to distract from the sensitive issue with a focus on simple, tangible inputs. 3) Use the **MEAL Jargon Glossary** to ensure all communication about the trade-off is neutral and technical. **Respect Achieved:** Partners are respected by receiving a fast, clear path to maintaining compliance and securing funding, prioritizing **Risk Avoidance**.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: **Socialization Strategy: Control Imposition and Unilateral Mandate.** The trade-off is enforced as a directive from the top, allowing no space for dissent. **Process:** 1) Issue a **Unilateral Mandate** memo threatening to **Publicly Blame** any partner who discusses the dissenting data. 2) Reiterate the **Total Freeze on Local Innovation Funds**. 3) Mandate the immediate transfer of all local staff to the formal partner, enforcing **Isolation** from the donor. **Respect Achieved:** Partners are respected by knowing the exact boundaries of the **Unilateral Control** and the severe consequences of **Execution Drift**.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: **Socialization Strategy: System Engagement and Policy Prototype.** The hard trade-off is framed as a political necessity that will eventually lead to system change. **Process:** 1) Use the trade-off to justify co-signing an **Audit-Ready Innovation** mandate, proving the local partner's data is the basis for future policy lobbying. 2) Track the trade-off’s cost via the **Localization Maturity Index** and commit to transparency. 3) Require HQ to fund Kujenga to lead an **Empowerment Index** review. **Respect Achieved:** The partner is respected as the essential **Policy Prototype** owner, whose insights are leveraged to challenge the **Centralized Logframe Design** in the long term.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: **Socialization Strategy: Mission Alignment Scorecard and Structured Learning.** The trade-off is a co-managed conflict between compliance and impact. **Process:** 1) Present the trade-off in the context of the **Mission Alignment Scorecard**, showing that the decision prevents the overall goal from failing. 2) Use the decision to formalize the use of the **Gender Audit Protocol** internally, protecting the sensitive data. 3) Mandate that the trade-off is tracked in the **Decision Log** monthly for adaptive reflection. **Respect Achieved:** The partner feels respected because the decision is rooted in shared **Structured Learning** tools, proving that **Mission Fidelity** remains the joint priority.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: **Socialization Strategy: Administrative Overhead Reduction.** The trade-off is justified by the quantifiable reduction in partner effort. **Process:** 1) Issue a memo detailing the elimination of the most redundant reporting form (based on the **Administrative Overhead Reduction Report**). 2) Mandate the use of the new, highly efficient **Simplified Reporting Form**. 3) Ensure the Grants Lead co-signs the memo, guaranteeing **Grants Disbursement Approval** stability. **Respect Achieved:** Partners are respected by receiving a concrete, immediate reduction in their **Administrative Workload Escalation**, reinforcing **Administrative Simplicity**.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: **Socialization Strategy: Financial Control and Punitive Control.** The trade-off is presented as a financial necessity to avoid external penalty. **Process:** 1) Issue a memo enforcing the **Centralized Grants Management** system strictly. 2) Use the hard choice to justify a mandatory **Financial Audit** of the non-compliant spending. 3) Threaten the **Total Freeze** on any remaining local funds. **Respect Achieved:** Partners are respected by receiving a clear warning that any resistance to **Control Prioritization** will result in **Punitive Control**.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: The Contradiction Log/GEDA Autonomy Threshold.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** When the divergence generates a **Contradiction Log** entry that challenges a **Centralized Logframe Design** assumption AND the local partner’s **GEDA Autonomy Score** is below 70% (indicating insufficient delegated power). **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** When the divergence compromises the **Empowerment Index** or the ability to secure **Autonomous Budget Authority** by damaging core audit requirements. **Why:** We institutionalize **Strategic Dissent** as the driver for change, prioritizing **Transparent Ownership** over programmatic uniformity. The divergence is a sign of **Audit-Ready Innovation**.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: The Tiered MEAL System and Decision Authority (D-A).** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** When the change is limited to the **Tier 2 MEAL Signal** (outcome/learning data) AND the local partner holds **Decision Authority (D-A)** for that programmatic pivot on the **RACI Chart**. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** When the divergence impacts the **Tier 1 MEAL Signal** (grants compliance/reporting) AND the **Risk/Opportunity Heat Map** shows a critical **Threat** to **Mission Fidelity**. **Why:** We enforce **Governance Clarity** via the RACI and the **Decision Log**, creating a clear boundary where divergence fuels **Evidence-Based Learning**, but compliance remains non-negotiable (**Shared Accountability**).

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Administrative Simplicity vs. Compliance Stability.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** When the change reduces **Administrative Overhead** (validated by the **Administrative Overhead Reduction Report**) AND the divergence can be managed via a **Procedural Fix** (e.g., an update to the **Automated Data Harmonization Script**). **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** When the divergence violates the **Simplified Compliance Checklist** or causes a failure in the **Market Access Handoff Ritual**. **Why:** We prioritize **Risk Avoidance** and stability. Divergence is permitted only if it simplifies the operation, but compliance with basic standards is enforced to maintain **Procedural Standardization**.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Output-Only Mandate and Control Imposition.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** Never. The **Output-Only Mandate** requires absolute uniformity for **Financial Control**. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** Always. Any divergence (e.g., **Template Deviation**, local innovation) must be met with a **Unilateral Mandate** enforcing a **Total Freeze** and **Staff Reorganization**. **Why:** Divergence is interpreted as **Execution Drift** and **Image Risk**. Coherence is mandated through **Punitive Control** (threat of **Financial Penalty Clause**) to enforce **Isolation and Control**.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Localization Maturity Index (LMI) and Model Ownership.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** When the divergence leads to a measurable increase in the local partner's **Institutional Credibility Score** and reinforces the **Peer Learning** model. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** When the divergence compromises the ability to secure **Autonomous Budget Authority** or damages **Relational Trust** with other partners. **Why:** Divergence is only allowed if it proves the local partner is the **Model Owner**. We use the **Localization Maturity Index** to measure the systemic value of the local initiative, ensuring **GEDA's Institutionalization**.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Mission Fidelity and Joint Issue Resolution.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** When the divergence is the only way to adhere to the **Gender Audit Protocol** or achieve a goal on the **Mission Alignment Scorecard**. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** When the divergence creates **Unclear Authority/Governance** or cannot be resolved using the **Joint Issue Resolution Protocol** within one cycle. **Why:** Divergence is a tool for **Adaptive Management**. We must enforce **Governance Clarity** by making the resolution process transparent and co-owned, allowing a **Flexible Variance Policy** only when mission-critical.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Administrative Workload Escalation Threshold.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** When the change is a low-risk **Procedural Fix** that demonstrably reduces **Administrative Workload Escalation** for the partner. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** When the divergence requires the Grants Lead to manually intervene or increases the Grants team's internal workload. **Why:** We maintain coherence by mandating the least administrative complexity, using the **Administrative Overhead Reduction Report** as the only metric for success and failure of a divergence.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Centralized Procurement Mandate and Total Freeze.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** Never. Divergence threatens the **Centralized Grants Management** system. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** Always. Any programmatic or operational divergence must trigger a **Total Freeze on Local Innovation Funds** and immediate application of the **Unilateral Control** memo. **Why:** Coherence is mandated through **Financial Control**. We prioritize minimizing audit risk and enforcing absolute adherence to the centralized system.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Ethical Pre-Mortem and Policy Prototype.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** When the divergence is needed to avoid a negative outcome identified in the **Ethical Pre-Mortem** or to better serve **Community-Defined Outcomes**. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** When the divergence undermines the core **Autonomous Decision-Making** authority of the local partner or compromises the **Policy Prototype**'s external advocacy potential. **Why:** Divergence must be ethically justified. We empower the local partner as the ethical compass, institutionalizing the **Deep Field-First Orientation** and **System Engagement**.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Structured Risk Mitigation and Dual Advocacy.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** When the divergence manages a unique political risk captured in the **Risk/Opportunity Heat Map** without violating the mission's core intent. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** When the divergence compromises the ability to maintain the **Joint Narrative Statement** or creates a new, unmitigated risk for the entire project. **Why:** Divergence is only permitted if it is a calculated risk that is co-owned. We use the **Contingency Planning Protocol** and the **Decision Log** to enforce **Structured Risk Mitigation** and **Shared Accountability** for all deviations.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Compliance Rigidity and Procedural Fixes.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** When the change can be tracked and reported via the **Simplified Reporting Form** without generating a compliance error. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** When the divergence requires a major, expensive change to **Standardized Training Materials** or creates **Jargon Confusion** outside the approved **MEAL Jargon Glossary**. **Why:** We allow divergence only if it is cheap and simple to report, using a low-cost **Procedural Fix** to enforce **Procedural Standardization** while managing minor variations.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Image Protection and Unilateral Imposition.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** Never. Any local change creates **Image Risk** for the formal partner. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** Always. Divergence is a direct violation of the **Agro-Parks Mandate Memo** and must be met with a **Punitive Control** measure (e.g., immediate removal of budget) to enforce total **Unilateral Control**.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Authentic Collaboration Index and Mutual Partnership Reset.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** When the divergence is the result of a **Peer Learning** effort that raises the **Authentic Collaboration Index** score. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** When the divergence indicates a breakdown of **Relational Trust** and cannot be solved through a **Systemic Apology** or **Partnership Values Co-Creation Session**. **Why:** Divergence is a positive sign of **Authentic Collaboration**. We must mandate coherence only when the relational foundations of the partnership are at risk.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: TOWS Matrix and Flexible Variance Policy.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** When the **TOWS Matrix Review** identifies the divergence as a localized **Opportunity** that does not compromise the core mission **Strengths**. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** When the divergence is an unmitigated **Threat** that requires the formal co-signing of a **Flexible Variance Policy** agreement to resolve. **Why:** We allow divergence to maximize local **Opportunities**. Coherence is mandated when the deviation is significant enough to require a formal, co-signed **Decision Log** entry, enforcing **Structured Learning**.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Grants Disbursement Approval and Compliance Stability.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** When the divergence does not affect the data required for **Grants Disbursement Approval** or violate the **Output-Only Metrics**. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** When the divergence risks withholding of funds or is not covered by a simple **linguistic workaround** for external reporting. **Why:** Divergence is a low-priority concern. We mandate coherence only when the core function of **Financial Control** or **Risk Avoidance** is threatened.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Isolation and Staff Reorganization.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** Never. Local initiative is a source of **Execution Drift**. **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** Always. Any divergence must result in the immediate **Staff Reorganization** of local staff under the formal partner, ensuring absolute **Isolation** and adherence to the **Output-Only Mandate**.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: **Decision Rule: Administrative Simplicity vs. Compliance Stability.** **Allow Divergence (Local Initiative):** When the divergence reduces **Administrative Overhead** (validated by the **Administrative Overhead Reduction Report**) AND the divergence can be managed via a **Procedural Fix** (e.g., an update to the **Automated Data Harmonization Script**). **Mandate Coherence (Coherence):** When the divergence violates the **Simplified Compliance Checklist** or causes a failure in the **Market Access Handoff Ritual**. **Why:** We prioritize **Risk Avoidance** and stability. Divergence is permitted only if it simplifies the operation, but compliance with basic standards is enforced to maintain **Procedural Standardization**.

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: keep Kujenga’s women-led producer groups, local buying days, and co-design with VSLAs at the core. Flex on which districts onboard first and whether aggregation happens via parish hubs or mobile collection.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: At least 60% of decision rights sit with community structures (VSLAs/producer councils). Partner budgets must allocate ≥15% to grassroots leadership and learning stipends

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: crowding out community voice, compliance creep, slower cycles. Safeguards: community veto on changes, mandatory biweekly field reviews, and dual sign-off (partner + community rep) on key adaptations.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: trade speed of geographic expansion to protect community decision rights, because legitimacy is the only way scale endure

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: weekly field pulses (10 groups), WhatsApp photo logs, fortnightly sensemaking huddles; trigger sprint if women’s net price drops ≥5% for two weeks—first change: adjust aggregation schedule/transport share.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: caregiving peaks block attendance on market day; act by shifting sessions, adding childcare micro-stipends, and testing evening aggregation.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: align reporting to Agro-Parks, but reserve 10% flexible budget and a sandbox letter with district to protect village pilots.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: shared tarpaulin + moisture meter at village aggregation; judge by post-harvest loss ↓10% and price ↑3% in 2 weeks.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Supply chain—Asha (WVU); MEAL—Brian; Community—Kujenga lead (Grace); Escalation—Okello; milestones at weeks 2, 4, 8, 12.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: Outcomes (price +5%, on-time delivery 90%, attendance 80%); milestones (parish hubs live, vendor MoUs, MEAL light tool, first sprint, review); decision gates at weeks 4/8/12. Slippage: kanban board + red-flag rule (>1 week delay → joint fix).

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: community. Artifact: delivery & quality log co-signed at each collection.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: duplicate inception workshops, parallel baseline. Keep: vendor MoUs, aggregation schedule, cashflow map.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: goals (shared spine, metrics, norms); blocks (case walk, risk map, RACI, sprint plan); outputs (signed ways-of-working, RACI, 90-day board).

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: one integrated tool with 3 gender outcomes; gender advisor co-owns indicators.

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text: field first,” “evidence over preference,” “no surprises.” Test via random artifact checks.

question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: vendor selection—run a joint decision forum with scored rubric.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Publish Friday field note with 3 metrics and next week’s fix.” Enforce via traffic-light review.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: net price, on-time pick-ups, attendance; owners: supply/MEAL/community; rule: two reds → sprint within 5 days.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: meet to diagnose (capacity vs. will), agree 2-week plan, or shift scope/vendor.

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: Kill update theatre: agenda = decisions only; pre-reads mandatory; 30-minute cap.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: ask “what worked/failed/why/cost?” Convert to signed change log and budget re-allocation.

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: acknowledge publicly, protect relationships, run cause→countermeasure in 72 hours.

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: district roadshows; redirect to last-mile logistics.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: parks give scale/infra but risk exclusion; grassroots gives equity/learning. Call: hybrid—use parks for warehousing, keep community price-setting & scheduling.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: last-mile cost per kg (from vendors) and average moisture losses (from MEAL). Fallback: use conservative benchmarks.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: share side-by-side, invite dissent, publish rationale and review date in 6 weeks.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: I have no idea

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: My aim in this is to replicate success, and success was Kujenga's grassroots strategy. They have “the spine” and field-first learning that led to this success. Therefore, my plan is this: we scale through positioning Kujenga as our mentors and leaders. They become the center. Our responsibility is to assist them, as well as new partners in Teso, Karamoja, and Busoga regions, in building upon their success. Any type of “formal” NGOs that are involved are present to assist Kujenga, not to administer them. “We're creating an ecosystem, not just building a pipeline.” What I Won’t Bend On Role of Kujenga: They are identifying confusion of roles, so we have to ensure that we are clear. They are not a subcontractor. In fact, they act as a lead partner in co-designing a scale-up. This is non-negotiable in building our trust. “The Gender Focus”: This is considered to be at the center of the project. “That is a red flag of concern regarding our redesign of MEAL. We are not in a position to weaken our gender-inclusive perspective merely in order to make it possible to measure in a more standard fashion.” Learning from the Field First: Kujenga is absolutely right to be concerned about that. We will surely go down in value if we do not get that learning in real-time from the field. We will have lost our spine. Where I'm Willing to Flex Formal NGOs as Partners: I'm okay with bringing in a large NGO as a partner when it's just for a particular technical job. For instance, they might assist in handling a particular region's finance reporting or logistics that Kujenga is not designed to do. They offer a service, that's all. Government's Strategy: I view the "Agro-Industrial Parks" as an opportunity, not a threat. We will flex by engaging with them and showing them that our women-inclusive model is the best means of ensuring that those parks serve as a benefit to their communities. We will shape their strategy from within. The Timeline: “bold and doable,” but we will “break the model” if we do it too quickly. I am flexible about how soon we need to implement in order to get our partnerships right. That is how this will have to work in order to be sustainable.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: "To ensure that this scale-up has a "spine" in it, as Kujenga said was lacking, we need our ToRs to identify them as co-designers and decision-makers, not merely as implementers," “This also means that their budgets need to factor in real costs for their leadership’s time and operational costs, as opposed to just the project work, so we’re building their strength in the longer term.”

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: Honestly, we just do not want to accidentally start to sideline Kujenga. They will go from being a leading group in a successful women-led pilot to being a small subcontractor for a large, formal NGO. “If that is the outcome, we will miss just that spine that Kujenga said was lacking,” because the formal partners will also bring their “standard” modus operandi, and “this unique aspect of addressing women inclusively, of field-centered learning, will just get lost in all that red tape.” In addition, it will also “send a wrong message that in order to scale, one needs an INGO, and that will only lead to increased dependency.” Therefore, in order to protect against that, I would do two specific things: In terms of governance for the project, I would ensure that Kujenga is represented as a permanent voting member of the Steering Committee and not a 'Observer'. In terms of our MEAL strategy, I would insist that as part of a “learning” budget, a key aspect of that is managed by Kujenga in order to conduct their own learning meetings. This is to prioritize Kujenga’s participation in our performance tracking system for field-first learning.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: If I had to choose, I would trade the ambition of speed and regional breadth to protect the integrity of the model and Kujenga's leadership. Here’s why: If we rush this and just push to be in all three regions by next quarter, we will be forced to use the big formal NGOs as leads. That's the only way to move that fast. The moment we do that, we've broken the model. We'd be scaling a generic, top-down program, not Kujenga's successful women-led one. We would have "scaled" in name, but we'd have lost the 'spine' and the field-first learning. That's not a success; it's just a bigger, blander program. I would rather scale slowly and correctly. Let's get it right in Teso first, with Kujenga as the clear mentor, and then use that success to move into Karamoja. A slower, authentic, locally-led rollout is the only one that will actually last.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: This is all about making sure we get to hear from out in the field, and Kujenga is clearly the one helping us listen. Sources • Kujenga's field staff. This is our main source. • Women participants in the agribusiness groups (Serere): We need to hear from them. Cadence - Timing • Every two weeks, Kujenga's team conducted a “What's Working, What's Not” call that lasted 60 minutes. They would use 30 minutes to report back findings from their community check-ins, and 30 minutes for us at World Vision to ask our questions. • Day 60: Joint “Look Back” meeting with Kujenga and our leadership to analyze all of our notes and make a decision about what we need to work on in the next 90 days. Artifacts (What we create • No need for long reports. Just a rolling, collaborative “Learning Log” (like a basic word doc or Google doc). • A page of “What We Heard/What We’ll Try” is written after each bi-weekly call by a specific individual (from WV, as a relief to Kujenga) and is shared with all. The Trigger and The Change My trigger for a "design sprint," which to me just means an "all hands on deck, stop and fix this" moment—would be a specific, repeated signal from the field. The Signal: If we hear the same concern from Kujenga's staff and from the women participants two calls in a row. For example, if they both say, "The new formal partners are holding meetings just for men," or "We don't know who to report to anymore." What I'd Change First: I'd immediately hit pause on any new activities in the expansion regions. You can't scale a broken model. The first thing I'd do is give the budget and the authority for a "course correction" workshop straight back to Kujenga. They would lead the meeting with us and the formal partners to redesign the communication and decision-making process right then and there. We wouldn't move forward again until Kujenga confirmed the 'spine' was back in place.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: “HQ’s usual assumption is that in order to scale, you need standardized, formalized learning. They will also want to contract a trainer to deliver one-day lectures in all three regions because it’s an efficient use of resources as calculated in a spreadsheet.” “But I would expect a statement from the women’s groups, through Kujenga, saying, 'Those all-day workshops are a waste of our time. We can’t leave our farms and children that long, and we don’t trust that facilitator from the city. The reason this pilot was successful is that Kujenga’s staff came out to our farms and showed us in an hour how to do it. We learn by doing, with people we trust.’” This is a direct contradiction. It is a conflict between “spreadsheet efficiency” and “real-world effectiveness and trust.” How I'd Surface and Act on It: I wouldn't wait for a formal report in that situation. This is what a bi-weekly "Learning Log" call is all about. So To Surface It, Kujenga might bring it up in that call, pointing to it as a significant risk. We'd enter it in our Learning Log together under "What's Not Working." To Act Quickly: I would act on it that same day. Step one would be to ask Kujenga, “What’s the alternative?” When they respond with “More on-farm peer mentoring,” I would do the following: Pause the Plan: “I would immediately notify our leadership that we need to put a pause on our plan to hire a training consultant.” Shift the Budget: I'd then go on to say that we'd take that same budget line for “Formal Training Workshops” and apply it to fund it instead. We'd call it “Peer-to-Peer Learning Fund” and fund Kujenga to support the increased time, transportation, and materials that go toward replicating their mentoring program that we've seen work because of this pitch. It’s all about building the courage to invest in what works, not just in those easy-to-describe projects.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: That's a great term, "pilot theatre." It's what happens when our field work and our policy work are just a show, with no real connection. For me, the only way to balance this is to not treat them as separate things. The village-level experimentation is our research and development (R&D) for the policy alignment. Here's how I'd do it: We don't just "align" with the Agro-Parks strategy by checking a box. We actively try to influence it. We take the proof from Kujenga's successful village model, the hard data and the real stories from the women's groups, and we bring it directly to the government officials. We'd frame it like this: "The Agro-Park is a fantastic national goal. Our field-tested model proves that for it to actually succeed and benefit smallholder farmers, it must be women-led and use a peer-to-peer learning approach. Let our proven village model be the 'how-to' guide for your policy." That way, the village experimentation isn't "theatre" at all. It's the evidence that makes our policy work authentic and powerful. We're not just experimenting for fun; we're building the case for a better, more grounded national strategy.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: The Frugal Innovation: I'd test a "Market Access WhatsApp Group" run by one of Kujenga's staff. The idea is simple: market information is power. The biggest problem for these women is often not knowing the real price in the nearest big town, so they get lowballed by the middlemen who come to the village. So, in one week, we'd test this: Day 1: Kujenga's field lead identifies 10 women group leaders who already use WhatsApp (or have someone in their family who does). She creates a group. Day 2: We (World Vision) give Kujenga's field lead a little "airtime" budget. Her only job is to call three different bulk buyers in the main market town and ask their current, best price for the women's top two products (say, cassava and groundnuts). Day 3: She sends one simple message to the group. The key is to use a voice note in the local language, so literacy isn't a barrier. She'd say, "Good morning, sisters. I've spoken to the buyers in Soroti. Today, they are paying 1,200 shillings a kilo for groundnuts and 500 for cassava. Don't let any trader tell you less." Day 5: She'd do it again, maybe adding a small tip like, "Buyer A says he'll pay more for the groundnuts that are sorted and clean." How I'd Judge It in a Week: This isn't about profit and loss in one week. It's about a change in knowledge and confidence. On Day 7, I'd have Kujenga's staff call those 10 women and ask three simple questions: Was this useful? (This measures relevance.) Did you share this information with anyone else in your group? (This measures reach.) Did knowing this price change how you talked to any local trader this week? (This is the big one. It measures impact. If even one woman says, "Yes, I told a middleman I knew the Soroti price and he offered me 100 shillings more," that's a massive win. That's the end of "pilot theatre" and the beginning of real-world power.)

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: This is how I would plan it out for the first 6 months. Milestone 1: Design & Prep (Days 0–60 Community Liaison: • Owner: Kujenga Leadership • Action: They are our “co-designers.” They conduct all of our community meetings to verify our plan for scale-up and to identify new groups in Teso. MEAL Learning • Owner: Okello (World Vision). • Action: My task is to co-design and fund “Learning Log” as I have described it. I am not running it. I am actually ensuring that it is safeguarded and that Kujenga has the power and resources to lead it. Supply Chain-engagement • Owner: Okello (World Vision) • Action: We're engaging in high-level research and development work as a team. We're identifying and verifying 3-5 of the “big buyers” in new areas, as well as identifying their contact people for the Agro-Parks team. Escalation Path • Owner: Okello • Action: I am “the single point of contact.” Kujenga’s leadership has my direct number. “Any blocker, a budget delay, a ‘formal partner’ trying to take over, comes to me, and my job is to fix it, fast.” Milestone 2: Teso Pilot Scale-Up (Days 61 Community Liaison: • Owner: Kujenga Field Staff. • Action: They are officially the “mentors.” They are in Teso working in the peer-to-peer program, gaining the trust of new groups just as they have in Serere. MEAL Learning: • Owner: Kujenga's appointed "Learning Lead • Action: They are now running the bi-weekly learning calls. They own the Learning Log and are responsible for flagging the "triggers" (red flags) that we agreed upon. Supply Chain Engagement: • Owner: This is now Shared. • Action: I (Okello) make a high-level introduction to the large buyers. Kujenga follows through to take control at a grassroots level in organizing the women's groups for collection and in handling local quality control. Escalation Path • Owner: Still Okello • Action: same path as before. When Kujenga's team gets stuck (for instance, "The new buyer is rejecting 50% of our produce"), they do not have to solve that one by themselves. They refer it to me, and I will intervene as a mediator between them and the buyer. Milestone 3: Review & Adapt (Day 181) All Owners (Kujenga, Okello, WV Leadership Action: We conduct a joint analysis of data from our Learning Log using the Teso scale-up. Based purely upon our field data, we make our “go/no-go” decision as well as our plan of action for expansion to Karamoja and Busoga.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: How I'll Expose Slippage Early Honestly, the best way to expose slippage is to listen to Kujenga. They are the ones who already flagged the "execution drift" and "loss of spine." The whole point of that bi-weekly "Learning Log" call we're setting up is to be our early-warning system. Slippage, in this model, isn't just a missed deadline on a chart. It's a breakdown in trust or a red flag from the field. If Kujenga's team says on a call, "We've been cut out of the meetings with the Teso group," or "The new formal partner just changed the MEAL form," that's not a 'risk' to be 'managed.' That's a failure. We expose it by having the courage to hear it, and the "Learning Log" is the formal, funded channel to do that. If that log is empty, or if Kujenga's team is silent, that is my number one signal that we are already off track. 90-Day Plan: "Protecting the Spine" The 3 Outcomes We Need by Day 90: 1. Role Clarity: Kujenga's "role confusion" is gone. They are operating as the clear, funded "Center of Excellence" and lead mentor. 2. Grounded Proof: The mentorship model is successfully pre-tested with the first new women's groups in Teso, and we have real-world feedback. 3. Learning Rhythm: Our bi-weekly, field-first learning loop is built, working, and capturing the data we need. The 5 Milestones: • Milestone 1 (By Day 15): Finalize Kujenga's ToR & Budget. o Owner: Okello & Kujenga Director • Milestone 2 (By Day 30): Co-design & Launch "Learning Log." o Owner: Kujenga Learning Lead (with Okello) • Milestone 3 (By Day 45): Kujenga Leads 1st Teso Mentor Sessions. o Owner: Kujenga Field Staff • Milestone 4 (By Day 60): First "Teso Learning Review." o Owner: Okello & Kujenga Team • Milestone 5 (By Day 90): 90-Day "Go/No-Go" Review with WV Leadership. o Owner: Okello Our Decision Gates (Our "Stop & Check" Moments): • Gate 1 (Day 15): Are Kujenga's ToR and budget signed? o Go: Proceed to launch in Teso. o No-Go: We stop. We do not start any Teso field activity until our lead partner is formally in place. • Gate 2 (Day 60): Does the Teso Learning Review show the model is working and Kujenga feels supported? o Go: Continue the Teso work and start high-level planning for Karamoja. o No-Go: We pause the expansion. We use the next 30 days to fix the problems in Teso. • Gate 3 (Day 90): Do we have a proven, documented "proof of concept" from Teso? o Go: Get formal approval to scale to Karamoja in the next quarter. o No-Go: We adapt and re-test in Teso. We do not scale a broken model.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Without a doubt, the highest likelihood of failure is the handoff between Kujenga's field staff and the new 'formal' NGO partner. That's where the "role confusion" Kujenga flagged will explode. The formal partner will come in with their own templates, their own reporting chains, and their own assumptions. They will almost certainly see Kujenga as a "sub-contractor" to be managed, not the "lead expert" to be supported. The moment they do that, they will break the trust Kujenga has built. They'll schedule a "standard" community meeting that no one attends, or they'll hand Kujenga a "standard" MEAL form that doesn't capture the gender lens. This is where the 'spine' will break, and all our field-first learning will stop cold. The Ritual to Close That Gap To fix this, I would introduce one simple but non-negotiable ritual that I would personally oversee for the first 90 days. I'd call it the "Field-First Handoff." It's a mandatory 30-minute call every two weeks, before any new work plan is started. This ritual has a very specific, unchangeable agenda: 1. Part 1 (15 mins): Kujenga Speaks. Kujenga's field lead has the floor. They state, "Here is what we learned from the women's groups in the last two weeks. Based on that, here is what we need to do next, and here is the specific support we need from our formal partner." 2. Part 2 (15 mins): Formal Partner Responds. The formal partner only speaks after Kujenga. Their job is to publicly confirm, "We have heard. We will provide that support." The artifact that comes out of this is the Joint 2-Week Plan. This ritual does two things: It forces the formal partner into the correct service-oriented role, and it gives Kujenga the clear, undisputed authority to lead from the field. It makes the "handoff" a moment of support, not a moment of takeover.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: In a complex situation, the fastest way to get clarity is to stop doing the things that are creating the most noise. If I had to drop two things immediately to regain our 'spine,' here's what I'd do. What I Would Drop: 1. I'd immediately drop our participation in the new MEAL redesign. This is the most dangerous thing happening. It's actively "diluting the gender lens," which is the entire point of the project. We can't move forward if our own measurement system is breaking our model. We stop all work on it, today. 2. I'd drop all new partnership meetings with the 'formal' NGO partners. This is the primary source of the "role confusion" and "execution drift" Kujenga is flagging. We're spending time in meetings that are pulling us away from the core model. I'd pause all those talks for at least 60 days. What Stays (and Gets More Focus): The 'field-first learning' loop. This is the one thing that absolutely must stay. Dropping the other two activities isn't about quitting. It's about creating the space to fix what's broken. The one thing that stays is our direct, bi-weekly "Learning Log" call with Kujenga and the women's groups. That's our new center of gravity. That's the only meeting that matters for the next month, because it's the only place we'll get the real data to build a MEAL system that works and to decide if (and how) we ever bring those formal partners back to the table.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: The Workshop: "Protecting the Spine" My Goals for the Day: 1. Re-Grounding: To have everyone in that room (MEAL, Grants, Ops) hear directly from Kujenga why the pilot was successful and why they flagged a "loss of spine." 2. Role Clarity: To stop the "role confusion" by collectively agreeing on who does what. We need to move our internal teams from a "managing" mindset to a "supporting" mindset. 3. Action Plan: To leave with a simple, concrete 90-day plan that we all agree on, so Kujenga can get back to work, and we can get back to supporting them. Agenda Blocks (The Flow of the Day): Block 1: "Looking Back to Go Forward" (9:00 AM - 10:30 AM) • Who Leads: Kujenga's Director and Field Lead. • What Happens: This is the most important part of the day. We (World Vision) sit and listen. Kujenga's team presents their story: "Here is what made the pilot work. Here is the 'spine.' And here, specifically, is what we see happening now that's breaking it." • Why: This immediately "shifts the power" in the room. It makes the partner the expert and us the listeners, which is the core of the IBSM model. Block 2: "Protecting the Program's Soul" (10:45 AM - 12:30 PM) • Who Leads: Gender Advisor (co-facilitating with Kujenga). • What Happens: We put the "diluted MEAL redesign" on the table. The Gender Advisor and Kujenga lead a discussion on what must be measured to protect the women-inclusive model. This is not a technical debate; it's a "non-negotiables" session. The MEAL team is there to hear what the new design must capture. • Why: This directly addresses the biggest threat to Program Quality and "embeds CARE's Gender Equality Framework". Block 3: "Shifting from 'Risk' to 'Support'" (1:30 PM - 3:00 PM) • Who Leads: Okello (me), with Grants and Ops teams. • What Happens: We hold a "service provider" session. I'd ask Kujenga, "What is the simplest, most effective way for us to get you the money and resources you need?" The Grants and Ops teams are not there to present rules. They are there to listen and propose solutions that work for the partner, aligned with the IBSM's goal of being "risk-tolerant" and "derisking" funding. • Why: This redesigns the relationship. It's the Fund & Partnership Risk Management pillar in action: strengthening the partner, not just policing them. Block 4: "Our 90-Day 'Rules of Engagement'" (3:15 PM - 4:30 PM) • Who Leads: Okello (me). • What Happens: We take the outputs from the day and put them on a whiteboard. We agree to a simple 90-day plan, a clear "who does what," and, most importantly, a simple escalation path. • Why: We leave with a concrete plan, not just ideas, that "shifts power" and is ready to execute. The Outputs I Expect to Leave With: I need us to walk out of that room with three specific things: 1. A One-Page List of "MEAL Non-Negotiables." This is our artifact from Block 2. It's co-written by the Gender Advisor and Kujenga, and it will be the guiding document for the MEAL team to fix the redesign. 2. A Simple "Who Does What" Flowchart. This artifact from Block 3 shows Kujenga at the center, leading on community and program quality. It shows MEAL, Grants, and Ops as support services that plug into them. 3. A "Clear Escalation Path." This is the most critical output from Block 4. It's probably just my name and Kujenga's Director's name. It's a simple, written promise that if Kujenga hits a blocker, they don't have to fight the bureaucracy, they call me directly, and I will fix it.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: We won't solve this by creating a separate "gender checklist," that's how you get parallel systems and just create more "theatre." The gender lens is the program; it's the "spine" Kujenga is talking about. So, here’s how I'd resolve it: We don't bolt gender onto the MEAL system. We build the MEAL system from the gender-transformative goals. This is exactly what our own Program Quality standards demand when they say we must "Embed CARE’s Gender Equality Framework" and "advance Women and Girls' Voice". I'd get the MEAL team, the Gender Advisor, and Kujenga's field lead in a room with a single, clear goal: "What are the 5-7 core indicators that prove this model is actually working for women?" This is co-creation in action. The MEAL team might come in wanting to measure "number of women trained." But Kujenga and the Gender Advisor will push for what really matters, like "percentage of women who spoke up in a community meeting" or "number of households where men are taking on more domestic work." These are the real indicators of "equitable program benefits". My job as the lead is to make a decision. I'd say the "harder" indicators are our new Key Performance Indicators. The MEAL team's job is not to question this; their job is to figure out the simplest, most effective way to track them, likely using qualitative tools like spot interviews and seasonal scorecards that Kujenga can help us co-design. This way, the MEAL system isn't diluting the gender focus; it's measuring it. There's only one system, and it's built around what actually matters.

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text: Here are the three principles I'd want every single person on our team, from Grants to MEAL to Ops, to live by, and how I'd know if we were actually doing it. The Three Principles 1. Kujenga is the Expert, We Enable. This is the most important one. Kujenga is not our sub-grantee; they are the subject matter expert. Our job is to be their "service provider." Grants enables their funding, MEAL enables their learning, and Ops enables their logistics. This single shift fixes the "role confusion." 2. Co-Create, Don't Impose. We must stop showing up with templates. The MEAL redesign failed because we imposed it. This principle means we start with a blank page and Kujenga's field experience, and we build with them. This is the only way to get "local ownership" and "co-creation of solutions." 3. Protect the Gender Spine. This is our "why." Kujenga said the project was losing its "spine," and the gender lens is it. This principle means every decision,from a budget line to a new partner—is tested against one question: "Does this strengthen or dilute our focus on women?" How I'll Test Adherence (In Real Work) I won't use a survey. I'll test it by observing what we do. 1. To test "Kujenga is the Expert": I'll check who speaks first and most in our meetings. In our bi-weekly learning calls, is Kujenga presenting to us, or are we presenting at them? If our Grants team starts a call by listing rules, we've failed. If Kujenga starts by saying, "Here's what we need," we've succeeded. 2. To test "Co-Create, Don't Impose": I'll look at the version history on our key documents. I'll check the MEAL plan, the budget, and the ToRs. If the edit history is just World Vision staff, we've failed. If I see Kujenga's staff as active editors and commenters before the document is finalized, that's real co-creation. 3. To test "Protect the Gender Spine": I'll track the topics in our "Learning Log." I'll look at the "red flags" and "lessons" we're discussing. Are they all about logistics and deadlines? Or are they about what the women's groups are actually saying? If we spend a whole call on a procurement issue and never once mention the women's feedback, we've lost the spine.

question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: The big one for me is the "Go/No-Go" decision to scale into the next region, Karamoja. This must be co-owned. If World Vision leadership just "approves" this based on our own internal timeline, we are guaranteeing failure. We'd be pushing a schedule, not scaling a successful model. That's how we end up with "pilot theatre" and how we break the 'spine' Kujenga is trying to protect. Here is how I would structure it so that Kujenga truly co-owns this decision: The entire decision will be based on the 90-Day Learning Log from our Teso scale-up—the one Kujenga's team owns. The structure for the "Go/No-Go" meeting would be: 1. Kujenga Presents the Data: Kujenga's team leads the first half of the meeting. They present their findings from the Teso Learning Log. They alone answer the question, "Is the model working? Are the new women's groups engaged? Do we feel supported?" 2. Kujenga Makes the First Recommendation: Based on that data, they make the official recommendation. For example: "Go. The model is working, and we are ready." Or, "No-Go. The new partners are still sidelining us, and we need to fix it." 3. We Decide Together: My leadership team and I don't get to "approve" or "deny" their recommendation. Our job is to respond as co-owners. If Kujenga says No-Go, our reaction shouldn’t be to push them. Our reaction is, 'Thank you. You’ve protected us from a major failure. What resources do you need from us to fix the Teso model to get us to a “Go” within 90 days?"’ This is more than a nice gesture. This is a means of “shifting power” and ensuring that those people with the most significant knowledge, those individuals that are “on the ground,” are also in charge of “steering the ship.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: An executable promise here isn't some big, vague, corporate-sounding statement. It has to be real and simple. My promise would be: "Kujenga's voice will be the loudest in the room. My job is not to manage Kujenga; my job is to clear the roadblocks for them so they can lead." This isn't just about empowerment; it's a promise of service. It directly addresses their "role confusion" and makes it clear that our internal teams and formal partners are there to support, not to take over. My Weekly Commitment and How I'll Enforce It The one commitment I would publish weekly is the "Field-First Blocker Report." This would be a one-line email that goes out every Friday to my leadership and all partners. It would state the single biggest obstacle that Kujenga's team reported to us in our bi-weekly "Learning Log" call. For example: • "This week's blocker: The new Teso groups are still waiting for their transport budget to be approved." • "This week's blocker: The formal partner's MEAL form is taking up 4 hours of Kujenga's field staff's time." As for how I'd enforce it? It's pure public accountability. My name is on that email. If the same blocker appears on my Friday email two weeks in a row, I have failed to do my job, and everyone on the team knows it. It's not Kujenga's job to chase us for a fix. It's my job to make sure a blocker never appears on that list twice. This forces me and my internal teams (like Grants or Ops) to be accountable, not just to our bosses, but to our partner.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: My Simple “Spine Health” Dashboard 1. Leading Indicator: Partner Voice • Metric: Kujenga's "Blocker Report". This is a 'Red/Yellow/Green' status that they offer in our bi-weekly call. Red is 'We are stuck', Yellow is 'We have a concern', and Green is 'We are moving'. • Owner: Kujenga's team. This is their metric to own and report. My job is to listen to it, not to set it. 2. Leading Indicator: Learning Rhythm • Metric: "Learning Log" Call Completion. Did our bi-weekly learning call (the one Kujenga leads) happen on schedule? • Owner: Okello (me). I don't own the meeting, but I own protecting it. It's my job to make sure everyone (including my own leadership) treats it as the most important meeting on the calendar. A "Yes" means we are listening. A "No" means we are already failing. 3. Leading Indicator: Service Quality • Metric: "Helpful or Hurdle?" This is a simple, anonymous poll I'd ask Kujenga's lead to fill out weekly about our internal teams (Grants, Ops, MEAL). • Owner: Okello (me). This is a direct report card on my team. It's the only way I'll know if we are living up to our "service provider" principle, or if we're just creating more bureaucracy. My Escalation Rule My rule is simple: One Red, We Act. Two Reds, We Stop. • If any single metric turns Red: I (Okello) must personally intervene within 24 hours. My first call is not to my own team; it's to the Kujenga Director to ask, "What do you need me to do to fix this, and who on my team is in your way?" • If any two metrics turn Red (e.g., Kujenga reports a 'Red' Blocker and the 'Learning Log' call was missed): This signals a systemic failure. I immediately call for a 48-hour full pause on all new expansion activities. We don't take one more step forward until Kujenga, my team, and I have fixed the problem and the dashboard is back in the green.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: The Recovery Conversation I'd call the Kujenga Director, and I'd start the conversation with humility. I'd say something like this: "Hey [Partner Lead], I'm looking at our 90-day plan, and I see we're off-track on [Milestone X] and [Milestone Y]. My first thought isn't 'you're late.' My first thought is that I've messed up. I've either given you a ridiculous timeline, I've failed to get our own team out of your way, or we're just asking for the wrong thing entirely. I'm not calling to get an excuse. I'm calling because I need to know what's actually happening. Is our Grants team making you fill out 10 forms for one payment? Is our MEAL team asking for data that doesn't make sense? Tell me the truth. What is the single biggest thing getting in your way right now? I'm not here to manage you; I'm here to fix the roadblock." The Decision Options This isn't about punishment. It's about fixing the plan. Based on what they tell me, I'd propose we choose one of these three options together. 1. Option 1: We Fix the Plan (The "Co-Creation" Option). This is for when we hear: "The plan itself is the problem. It's unrealistic." o The Decision: We agree our original plan was wrong. We "co-create" a new 90-day plan together, with a timeline that Kujenga confirms is achievable. My job is to then take that new, realistic plan to my leadership and get them to bless it. 2. Option 2: We Fix the Support (The "Strengthen Capacity" Option). This is for when we hear: "We can do it, but we're stretched too thin. We're drowning." o The Decision: We agree the work is right, but the resources are wrong. My job is to find the right support, as defined by Kujenga. This isn't about giving them a "formal NGO" partner they don't want. It's about me finding the budget for the specific help they're asking for—maybe it's a part-time finance person, or a dedicated transport budget, or a technical advisor they choose. 3. Option 3: We Fix Our Bureaucracy (The "Shift Power" Option). This is for when we hear: "We're stuck. Your own internal process is the roadblock." o The Decision: We agree to pause the timeline for this milestone completely. This isn't Kujenga's problem to solve; it's mine. I will personally take their "blocker" to my own Ops or Grants team and get the rule changed or get an exemption. The clock only restarts after I have called Kujenga back and confirmed for them that the roadblock is gone.

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: "Update theatre" is a symptom. It's what happens when partners think their job is to perform for us, not to work with us. It's a sign we're acting like auditors, not partners, and it's the fastest way to break trust and lose the "spine." My rule to prevent this is simple: We share information before the meeting, so we can use the meeting for decisions. Here's how I'd enforce that: 1. That 'Learning Log' is the update. We've already agreed to that bi-weekly "Learning Log" call with Kujenga. That's the only update. We will not have a separate, high-level "update" meeting for my leadership. I will take the log, add one sentence of my own analysis, and that is the report. 2. I will change the first question of every meeting. The first question is never, "What updates do you have?" The first question is always, "What's our single biggest roadblock, and who here can help solve it?" This ritual immediately kills update theatre. It makes the meeting a work session for Kujenga to get our help, not a performance for us to get their update. If a meeting doesn't have a clear roadblock to solve or a decision to be made, it's an email.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: The Questions I Will Ask My questions wouldn't be about "progress against the work plan." They'd be about the health of the partnership and the integrity of the model. I'd ask four simple questions, and my job would be to shut up and listen. 1. "Let's be honest. On a scale of 1 to 10, how much 'spine' does this project still have? And what's the single biggest thing, a person, a process, a partner, that's threatening to break it?" (This gets us past the 'everything is fine' talk and right to the core problem.) 2. "What is the single dumbest, most bureaucratic, or most time-wasting thing we (World Vision) made you do in the last 90 days?" (This is my favorite. It builds trust, gives them a safe way to vent, and instantly shows me where our "support" is actually a "hurdle.") 3. "What's the one thing you did in the field that worked way better than you expected? And what do you need to do more of it?" (This puts them in the expert seat, gets us field-first innovations, and turns the conversation from "blockers" to "accelerators.") 4. "Looking at Kujenga and our other partners here, what's one thing you've learned from each other that you want to 'steal' or adopt?" (This builds the ecosystem. It forces peer-to-peer learning and reinforces Kujenga's role as the mentor.) How I'll Convert Answers into "Signed Changes" We won't leave the room with "meeting notes." We will leave with "Our 90-Day Commitments." This is a simple, two-part process that we'll do in the last hour of the meeting. Part 1: We "Triage and Commit" on a Whiteboard. We'll have three columns. We take the answers from our discussion and put them into the columns: • The Problem: (e.g., "The new grant report form is a 'hurdle'.") • The Fix: (e.g., "We will only use Kujenga's 1-page Learning Log for the next 90 days.") • Who Owns It: (e.g., "Okello.") This is crucial. We don't just identify problems; we assign an owner to the solution. If the "fix" is for me to get a budget line changed or kill a stupid form, my name (Okello) goes on it. This makes it a public, personal commitment from me to them. Part 2: The "Signed Change" is a Public Email. I will type up that whiteboard list into a simple email with the subject line: "Our 90-Day Commitments from the Q3 Reset." Before anyone leaves the room, I will hit "send." That email goes to everyone who was in the room, and it goes to my boss and the finance director. That email is the "signed change." It's not a legal document; it's a public promise. Kujenga sees that I've committed to my leadership. My leadership sees what I've promised to Kujenga. And in 90 days, that email is the first thing we'll look at. It's how we hold each other accountable, and it's how I prove that I'm here to clear roadblocks, not just get updates.

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: This is actually the most important moment. A negative finding isn't a failure. It's a signal. Hiding it or spinning it is the only way you can truly fail. My entire approach here is about proving our partnership is real and not just "theatre." First, I protect trust. My first call is not to my leadership. It's to the Kujenga Director. I have to be the one to show vulnerability and humility. I'd call them and say: "Hey, I'm looking at our latest MEAL data, and it looks like our gender outcomes have stalled. My first assumption is that our plan is wrong, not that your work is wrong. We've clearly missed something big. You're the one on the ground. What are you seeing that these numbers aren't telling me? What's the real story? I need your expertise to help me understand what we need to change." This is critical. It makes them the expert, not the one being blamed. It turns a moment of accusation into a moment of co-creation and genuine "local ownership". Second, I protect momentum by pivoting. Momentum isn't just about moving fast; it's about moving in the right direction. Kujenga and I would then work together on the "fix." Maybe they'll say, "We told you we needed to engage the male leaders, but the plan didn't have time." Okay. We now have our pivot. I'd then go to my leadership and frame it with total honesty: "Our field-first learning loop just did its job. It caught a major problem early. The data shows our gender outcomes are stalling. Kujenga's team and I have already dug into it, and we believe the root cause is X—we're not engaging the men. So, we're not stopping. We're pivoting. For the next 60 days, we are re-allocating the travel budget to fund a series of 'male-engagement' workshops, which Kujenga will lead. We'll measure the impact and report back." This protects trust because I didn't throw my partner under the bus. And it protects momentum because we're not just stopping; we're adapting based on real-time, partner-led evidence. We're showing our model is strong enough to handle the truth.

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: What I Will Stop Doing: First, I am going to stop all new, high-level engagement with the 'formal' NGO partners for the next 90 days. We are burning time, money, and focus on meetings that are creating the "role confusion" and "execution drift" Kujenga flagged. Pausing this frees up my time, our grants team's time, and, most importantly, the budget we were holding for their "management" role. Second, I will stop (and scrap) the current, top-down MEAL redesign. It's actively "diluting the gender lens," and it's a "hurdle," not a "help." We will stop all meetings and consultant work on it, which frees up the MEAL team's time and any associated budget. How I'll Use That Money to Fund the Adaptations: This is the best part. We don't need new money. We just need to move it. 1. I'll take the budget we had set aside for the "formal partner's management fee" and turn it into a "Kujenga Mentorship Fund." This will directly pay for Kujenga's staff time and transport to be the "Center of Excellence" we talked about. It funds them to do the real work of peer-to-peer training in Teso. 2. I'll take the money we would have spent on that failed MEAL redesign (consultant time, our staff time, etc.) and turn it into a "Field-First Learning Fund." This will pay for the "reset" workshop we need. It will pay for the "Learning Log" calls. And it will pay for the small, frugal innovations like the "Market Access WhatsApp Group." It's a straight trade. We are stopping the "pilot theatre" and cashing in those resources to fund the "spine" that Kujenga rightly said we were losing.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: On one hand, we have the "Align with the Ministry's Agro-Parks" route. • The Benefit: The upside is huge, politically. We'd look like great partners, we'd be "aligned" with the national strategy, and we'd have a clear story for our leadership and donors about scaling. It's the path of least resistance. • The Cost: The cost is that we would almost certainly be absorbed and diluted. We'd be forced to fit our model into their top-down, industrial-scale boxes. This is exactly how the "gender lens" and "field-first learning" Kujenga is worried about would be lost forever. • Equity Implications: This is the killer. These big, top-down projects almost never serve the smallholder, women-led groups we're here for. The equity implication is disastrous: we'd be "whitewashing" a big project, using our grassroots "success" as a cover, while the real benefits flow to larger, male-dominated commercial players. • Execution Risk: The risk is that Kujenga and the women's groups would see this as a total betrayal. They'd disengage. We'd have "scaled" a program that has no soul, no "spine," and no real-world impact. On the other hand, we could just "Protect the Grassroots Focus" and ignore the Ministry. • The Benefit: We'd protect the integrity of the model. We'd keep Kujenga's trust, and the "spine" would be strong. We'd be doing real, deep, effective work at the village level. • The Cost: We'd be seen as "difficult" or "not scalable." We'd miss a massive opportunity to influence the national conversation, and we'd be picking a fight with a powerful stakeholder. • Execution Risk: The risk is that the Ministry could just shut us down or make our lives impossible. We'd be "pure" but "powerless." My Call And Why My call is neither. Both of those options are traps. The "Align" option is "pilot theatre" at its worst. The "Ignore" option is a missed opportunity. My call is to do the harder, smarter third option that your documents call "Thought Leadership" and "Policy Advocacy": We will use our proven grassroots model to actively influence the Agro-Parks strategy. This is how we'll do it: We're not going to "align" with their plan; we're going to proactively show them how their plan can actually succeed. I'll take the hard proof and the field-first data from Kujenga's pilot, and I'll go to the Ministry. I'll frame it like this: "The Agro-Parks are a critical national goal, and we want to help you make them a success. Our biggest risk is that these parks will fail to connect with the smallholder farmers who make up 80% of the sector. We have a proven, women-led, field-tested model that already solves this 'last mile' problem. Let's work together to make Kujenga's model the official 'how-to' guide for community engagement for the Agro-Parks. Let our model be your evidence." This way, we don't sacrifice our spine. We're not "aligning" we're leading. We're using our grassroots success as the evidence to make national policy smarter, more equitable, and more effective. That's the real win.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: Here are the two data points I still need by Friday. 1. From Kujenga's Director, I need their 'Go-Live' Non-Negotiables. I've asked her to send me a simple, one-page list of what they must have to lead this. I don't want a long proposal. I want a bulleted list: "This is the minimum budget we need to start. These are the three things our team will lead, and these are the two things we will not do." I need to see her terms, in her words. 2. From my own Head of Grants, I need a 'Yes' or 'No' on a simplified funding model. I've asked him, "Can you agree, in writing, to give Kujenga a single, upfront 'working capital' payment for 90 days, based on their one-page budget? Or are you going to force them into our standard, slow, monthly reimbursement process?" My Fallback Plan if They Don't Arrive My decision on Friday will be made with or without this data, but the data changes what the decision is. • If I don't get the list from Kujenga: If I don't hear from them, that is the data. It tells me they are not ready, not empowered, or don't trust us. My fallback: I will go to leadership on Friday and my call will be "No-Go." I'll state that we cannot move forward until our lead partner is genuinely co-leading the design. We will spend the next 30 days building that trust and getting that one-page plan right. • If I don't get the 'Yes' from my Grants team: If my own team says 'No' or "we'll see," then I know I can't protect Kujenga from our own bureaucracy. My fallback: My call on Friday will be a "Conditional Go," with a high-profile risk. I will tell leadership, "We are moving, but I am formally stating that our own internal grant process is the single greatest threat to this project's success. I am escalating this to you now, because when Kujenga's payments are late, it will be our failure, not theirs."

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: This is probably the most important test of our "partnership." This is where trust is either built or permanently broken. The worst thing I could do is send a formal email or let them hear it through the grapevine. That's the old, top-down behavior. I would go see the Kujenga Director in person, or at least get them on a video call. I'd sit down with them, one-on-one, and I'd be 100% transparent. I'd say: "I'm here because I have to share a hard decision, and I wanted you to be the first to hear it from me. The donor has (or my leadership has) made a call. Because of [reason X], we have to [the trade-off, e.g., 'cut the transport budget in half']. I'm not here to ask you to like it. Honestly, I don't like it either. And I know this is going to make your job twice as hard. What I'm here to do is to figure out our response. The decision is made, but the plan is not. You and I, right now, need to figure out how we're going to deal with this. What's the biggest risk this creates for you? And what's our 'Plan B' to protect the project? How do we co-own this problem?" Then I would just shut up and listen. I'd let them be angry. I'd let them be frustrated. I wouldn't get defensive. This is the only way. You show respect by being fast, transparent, and humble. And you keep them as a partner by making them a co-owner of the solution, even when they weren't the co-owner of the problem.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: This is a critical question. It's the "execution drift" Kujenga was worried about, but seen from another angle. My decision rule for this is simple: "We are 'tight on the why,' but 'loose on the how.'" The "coherence" we need isn't about every region using the exact same form or holding the exact same meeting. That's the old, top-down model. The "coherence" we must protect the 'spine' is our set of non-negotiable principles. So, here's the rule I'd give to all regional teams: "You can adapt the program in any way you think is necessary for your local context. In fact, I expect Teso to look different from Karamoja. That's not 'drift'; that's 'local initiative.' But... your adaptation must strengthen our three non-negotiables. It can never, ever break them." Our Three Non-Negotiables (The "Tight Why"): 1. Is it women-led and gender-transformative? We will not dilute the gender lens. 2. Is it driven by our local partner? We will not take over or sideline Kujenga's team or the new local partners. 3. Is it based on field-first learning? We will not make decisions from an office; we will use what the women's groups tell us. Here's how we'd enforce it: If a regional team wants to change the model, they can't just do it. They have to bring it to our bi-weekly "Learning Log" call. • If the Teso team says, "We want to stop the women-only meetings because it's just easier to talk to the male leaders," my answer is No. That breaks a non-negotiable. • But if the Teso team says, "We want to test a local radio program instead of the WhatsApp group, because Kujenga's team found that women are having their phones taken by their husbands," my answer is Yes, absolutely. That's a brilliant, locally-led adaptation. It doesn't kill the initiative; it is the initiative. And it's still 100% coherent with our 'why' because it's finding a better way to get the gender outcome. This way, local initiative becomes our R&D, not a threat to our 'spine.'
