question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: Delivering a project: Economic empowerment for Women in Busia district-Project Outcomes will include: Increased income, financial stability and Entrepreneurship for women, Then improved health and education for children and family and lastly Confidence and Leadership skills among women. The Milestones include 1. Connecting women to productive resources like Land for agriculture, information, money, technology like internet and natural resources.2. Job creation for women through skills and agency building.3. Planning and budgeting by Learning financial Literacy hence participation in spending decisions at home,4. Security for women and their businesses including reduction of GBV which is common where there is money especially over decisions, 5.Rights for women including positive gender and social norms change. The owners of all these are women who are at the centre of transformation and the decision gates include women themselves, their spouses, the children at household level, the Local community leaders, the private sector, government ministries for policies and guidelines and the Civil Society organizations as facilitators for change. The activities will start with conducting a rapid assessment in the district reaching out to Leaders, women, men, private sector, market actors to identify key sectors, level of knowledge among women, key constraints, opportunities and actors for 10 days, next 10 days mapping of private sector and public sector actors in line with identified sectors categorized as agriculture- On farm, off farm, trade and skills, Analysis of data and definition of roles for each player-women, local leaders, extension staff, banks,, private sector actors for 10 days. Engage key partners and formalize the relationship in writing including clarity of roles for each for 20 day. After this I will start Mapping women groups of collectives in form of VSLA, FFBS, ROSCAs working with community leaders for 5 days and next 5 days sensitize these group on the project objectives, implementation process, their roles and benefits. Then in month 3 I start capacity building TOTs, group training, reflection meetings, project roll out.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: # of women participating in VSLA # of women owning business/es %of women participating in community leadership and decisions over money at household level. The owners of these results are the women or impact group members. Weekly story of change documented and shared, using a tool that frontline soldiers- community facilitators, partner staff are guided on how to use. This can also be aploaded on digital gadget for ease of tracking.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: Engage on the causes of this shortfall, chart on how best to recover together, what is needed to come to speed, together draw an acceleration plan, include clear timelines, set up specific roles and have on time check ins to track progress.

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: As a manager I need to have a clear purpose of the meeting and so have participants well prepared for what they are to achieve from the meeting. The meeting should be able to generate actionable take aways for each participant. Active collaboration where each participant contributes freely across the agenda. Meeting should have a clear agenda in relation to the project and I will ensure all participants are phsycologically ready to participate.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: What went well? what did not go well? what can we do differently? A report will be made with clear evidence of stakeholder participation, indicating what the project have achieved, the key gaps that people think should addressed and recommended changes. Upscale stakeholders will be engaged on the proposed changes for appreciation and sign in.

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: I will investigate the missing link in the delivery approaches, allow sharings of success where it has happenned and together wth stakeholders come up with most appropriate approach that can deliver this result and this should be community owned, built from within. Forexample encouraging family planning among women without engaging the spouses can cause greater GBV, so there is a need to engage men, then women and all should be part of the decisions and action.

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: The adaptations should be aligned to the existing related budget to ensure the project does not loose out on the set targets.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Grasss root population understands their situation better. As much as Agro-parks as proposed by ministry are key at improving market access, boosting job creation, enhancing food security and facilitating technology transfer, There is need to appreciate the Existing constraints that have ecluded the Local women from the market. Until these are identified and addressed systematically, the Agro-parks will not work because there will always be shortages in agro production. Things like fragmented land holdings, poor production technology, lack of improved inputs, skills in production, market information and financial exclusion need to be addressed to facilitate the growth of Agro-parks with associated benefits.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: Time tracking and cost management metrics. Then quality metrics. These sets are needed from the project implementing team -Thus partners, private sector. Conduct stakeholder reflection meetings for feed back, conduct field follow up and support visits for mentorship and coaching, build further the capacity of partner teams through the named actions.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: Hold reflection meeting with partners with focus on the project objectives and the intended outcomes. Partners can do a reality check of their contribution to achieving genuine results and hold bold feed back sessions. Together chat actionable points to achieve project goals.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: As long as the decision is Consistent with the project plan and objectives.

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: 1. The vision is to grow without losing our roots-every decision and activity we embark on must deepen our models and impact, not scale them off. While regional scaling offers us a great opportunity to deepen and widen our impact, we must be careful to keep our gender lens on and hold onto the field first learning that got us here. it is also critical that at this point we clearly define the non-negotiables which for me would be: 1. The delivery model-grass roots interventions that are women-centered, field level learning, 2. Gender lens which we must embed throughout our design process, interventions and across our MEAL systems indicators. Lastly, I would be flexible on the strategic partnerships for example how we can re-position Kujenge as a bridge for the women between the regional and local markets in order to align with the government initiative of the Agro-industrial park. This would seamlessly incorporate into their core business without derailing the project from its core goals and objectives.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: 2. We must be intentional about involving local leadership as we scale our interventions, right from planning, execution and to monitoring. This is critical for ownership and sustainability.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: 3. Risks can include partners dominating decision making rather than co-creation with community, mis-use of resources, prioritizing numbers (scale) over actual empowerment/skilling of women. Safeguards would include: ensuring partner budgets factor in provisions for joint monitoring and review meetings for project initiatives with the local community, co-creation with the local communities, representation of the community on the project's governance or committee

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: 4. I would trade numbers for depth of interventions. Much as the project aims to scale its initiatives, it is important to maintain the authenticity of our interventions such that we keep the community's trust and ensure sustainability long after the partners exit the implementation areas

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: We shall have regular (weekly-every Friday) catch-up meetings with the partner and women group representatives for the next 60 days to document our processes but also ensure the findings are adaptively incorporated into our programming. This will include engagement with local leadership through field visits and monthly coordination meetings. Emerging trend, successes and learning opportunities should be documented as reports, case stories among others. The signals that would trigger a sprint for me include: A significant drop in women's participation in the project activities and role confusions on partner end in the field. I would quickly jump in to clarify partner roles and how each partner's work contributes to the overall project goal, ensure that project delivery is adapted to local context especially considering the regional scale spreads into different districts which may have unique needs.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: I expect that while we believe women will be willing to adopt our climate smart initiatives, they still experience social norms and gender related barriers that bar them from owning or having control over productive assets, thus may not be able to fully decide how these are utilized. Also, the burden of unpaid care work may leave very little time on their hands to deeply engage in these initiatives. I'd surface this by sharing/presenting these in our weekly and monthly catch-up meetings with the partners and act to ensure incorporation of gender transformative models in partner implementation and adjust the partner budgets and terms of engagement to ensure these approaches are embedded in their delivery.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: Policy basically gives direction to our work but the village experimentation gives life to the strategies within the policy. Ensuring that each village intervention answers a policy question is critical. Each experiement will be done with a clear learning objective, results shall be well captured and documented together with the local government to ensure alignment and prevent a pilot theatre.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: I would test the produce aggregation and shared transport costs on moving produce to the markets where women groups aggregate their harvest and pool transport to move the goods to big markets to reduce the costs on individuals. I'd judge it by how many groups are adopting it, the cost effectiveness as compared to individuals moving their products separately.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Supply chain engagement will be managed by Kujenga (Agribusiness lead) who will directly coordinate input and output markets including input demand and output aggregation, transport linkages and strategic partnerships for markets for women's products. This milestone will include having Memorandums of associations with reputable input suppliers and output market actors, and being able to monitor weekly activities. MEAL learning with be handled directly by Kujenga's MEAL staff and greatly supported by the MEAL advisor at World Vision. The role should be able to lead on adaptive learning and ensure that gender is incorporated in all the indicators against which project progress will be measured. The role will also be responsible for ensuring there is a working and easy to use community feedback and response mechanism in place and that feedback from this is continuously shared on the weekly and monthly catch up meetings. Community liason will be directly managed by the community field facilitators who will anchor village level coordination with the women groups, farmer networks and local leadership to ensure ownership of project initiatives by the community. Overall, the project manager should be responsible for ensuring the activities of Kujenga and the project in general are implemented timely, in a quality manner and be able to escalate any threats to the senior leadership at World Vision.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: 2 weeks-Regional inception with the women groups for field validation led by the Community field facilitations/ community liaison lead, 2 weeks-Inception meetings at the district, signing of MoUs with DLGs and supply chain actors- input output markets to ensure strategic alignment of interventions with the government policies. 2 weeks- MEAL advisor and coordinator launch and test the dashboard and community feedback mechanisms and disseminate to the partners, MEAL plan and KPIs aligned with the implementing partners. 2 weeks-Agribusiness lead at Kujenga leads the supply chain and logistics for the input and output markets testing to ensure suitability for scale determined. Last 2 weeks- Review of the approaches to ensure project is on course and adapt any learnings.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Between the Kujenga's field level staff and World vision. Because whereas World vision may be operating at a distant oversight and on strict timelines, the partner staff may be encountering real field constraints that World vision may not understand. Encourage documentation of arising operational contraints and share these in the weekly and month catch up meetings and ensure strict follow up to close them off.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: none

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal- To align all functional teams and partners to layer interventions for the climate smart interventions. Agenda blocks-Welcome remarks and climate setting, project overview, presentation of roles and responsibilities, deep dive on gender and community dynamics, deep dive on MEAL and learning, presentation on risk and mitigation, action planning and closure. Expected outputs- Clear execution spine, project learning agenda, MEAL plan with clear indicators per output, gender integration strategy across board, feedback and response mechanism in place, risk matrix and action plan

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Co-creation of project interventions and monitoring systems to ensure gender integration in the project activities can be measurable and that the project indicators speak to that. Clearly define what gender integration means and how success would look like.

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text: Excellence, Accountability, Agility- field verification, feedback loops, adaptive management.

question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: training schedules for the women groups. Field facilitators engage the groups and their leadership to agree on the training schedules and mode of delivery.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: an executable promise is SMART-Specific, has measurable metrics, assigns ownership and follow through, timebound and can be implemented by the team. One i would surely commit to is sharing of learning briefs which consolidates the weekly feedback from the implementing partner. I will enforce this by assigning clear responsibilities to the team, set timelines for sharing drafts, follow through and publish.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: 1. Number of women attending weekly trainings, Field facilitators/trainers, less than 70% attendance triggers discussions for alternative approach, Input-output markets activity, Agribusiness lead, more than 2 consecutive fails in delivery or pick up trigers escalation.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: Recovery conversation: Mention of shared commitment to project goals and objectives, Request partner to talk through the milestones that have not been achieved while highlighting the barriers the team faces and what support could have been given to ensure achievement, Agree on the corrective actions that can be taken moving forward, together design a corrective action plan with clear expected outcomes, responsible persons and how progress will be tracked, also schedule a follow up call or meeting for progress checks.

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: Indepth review of previous meeting actions ensuring detailed updates from the responsible persons, clear timelines on agreed actions and focus on matters in agenda to prevent drifting conversations. adherence to meeting timelines.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: Once every quarter, the team meets to reflect on the project in terms of what is working and what is not, share insights from field, convert learnings into actions to improve. Questions to ask include: Are women benefiting as planned?, are there any barriers to adopton of the climate smart initiatives? are supply chain actors responsive to the women's needs?, ARe women utilizing the linkages?, what innovations are working?, What interventions are not being adopted and why?, what additional strategies should be come up with? Are the men buying in to support women initiatives? Is the dashboard reflecting the truth of our efforts in the field?. Converting the answers into signed changes through proper documentation, co-creation of way forwards/changes, assigning responsible persons with clear timelines and scheduling follow ups.

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: I would approach it the same way i did with the partner who has missed out on their milestones with specificity to the gender context.

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: the quarterly pause and reflection meetings especially if the weekly and month catch ups are doing great. Also, only do targeted branding and visibility materials to reduce costs- t-shirts, caps, among others.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Cost- alignment would require additional costs for reporting, compliance and aligning models with government, if the grassroots focus is protected the project could miss out on initiatives that government could give to entities that have implemented with them. Equity implications-Aligning with the ministry's agro parks would mean focusing on central government initiatives while leaving out women's voices, while focus on the grassroots will mean equitable access to inputs, skilling as well as output markets and overall building of the women's agency. Execution ricks- With the ministry's initiative of the agro-parks will come bureaucracies in implementation due to need for several approvals while focus on the grass roots can face the risks of slow rate of scaling of the interventions.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: Number of women reached with climate smart initiatives to-date and record of supply chain activity including total input demand aggregation and buy back to-date by the groups. the data submissions will be done by the MEAL advisor at World Vision. The fall back would be the MEAL coordinators/officers at Kujenga and the group records.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: I would start off with a explaining our partnership commitments, speak to the trade off in simple terms and transparently, give my reasons why it is important we do the trade off, hear the partner's thoughts, together design next steps and define course of action. Lastly close the meeting with clear action and accountability points.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: The team is open to thinking creatively and innovatively within the project frame- while being mindful of the negotiables and non-negotiables.

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: The interventions in the new districts should remain grassroot driven with Kujenga fully engaged across. There is need to identify grassroot organizations in the three districts that will lead the implementation. There is need to clarify roles right from the onset with World Vision playing the lead role of coordination while the grassroot organizations do the actual implementation. Kujenga will support learning through regional learning and exchange visits with support from World Vision. Engagement with the Government should be based on strategic alignment while all MEAL activities should incorporate gender lens. The non negotiables include; The model should continue to be grassroot driven, integrating gender in MEAL systems and integration of learning. Flexibility can be in terms of the role of formal NGOs, Government engagement and implementation schedules.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: The grassroot driven model that engages local leadership into partner TORs and budgets increases ownership, accountability and efficiency in project implementation and should therefore be at the core of scaling interventions. Involvement of local leadership into partner TORs and budgets not only boosts donor confidence but also promotes sustainability.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: The risks include; some formal partners are not present on the ground, lack of accountability to the farmers or local community and higher over-head costs which would otherwise have been used to benefit the local population. Safeguarding community voices can be done through establishing feedback and accountability mechanisms where feedback is collected regularly. For instance through suggestion boxes, community dialogues, toll free lines. Furthermore, the community should be involved in actual implementation or governance, conducting joint learning sessions with the community also ensures that their voice is heard and respected.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: There is need to scale in the three districts in a phased manner so that we protect the grassroot implementation model since it was effective in the pilot phase. Rushing to scale in the three districts would end up affecting the grassroot model.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: What would trigger a design sprint is if learning is not taking place, gender is not fully integrated and the community is not fully engaged. This would require a deeper investigation to understand where the failure came from and hold a consultative workshop with all the concerned parties (farmers and Kujenga).

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: Learning does not take place because women attend the project activities when they are exhausted having done other household chores like cleaning and taking care of the children. HQ might assume that so long as women attend the trainings, learning has taken place yet this might not be true. The timing of trainings should take into consideration the fact that women have other domestic roles and responsibilities. Collecting regular feedback and having debriefs is important to structure the trainings according to the realities of the women groups. Therefore women groups need to be involved in designing the programs because they affect them.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: As long as there is evidence to suggest that interventions are effective, the village works should be able to reshape the policy around agro-parks and not necessarily conform to what exists. Having strategic policy engagements with government stakeholders to present briefs on what is working at grassroot level is key.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Issue cards to women farmers that contain their photos, mobile money number and QR code for verifying identity. These cards can be used to pay or receive payment. These help women not to carry cash at the market ensuring their safety. They also retain their incomes which can not be easily accessible by their husbands. Its effectiveness can be judged by number of women reporting that they control their income after selling their produce.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Supply chain and market linkages: managed by formal NGO leads supported by Kujenga. MEAL Learning: Managed by Kujenga with support from the field coordinators in the respective districts. Community liaison will be managed by appointed leads in the three districts but overseen by Kujenga. Escalation path: Managed by field staff. However, if the issue persists, it is escalated to the head of programs in the respective district. This can then be escalated to the regional lead at Kujenga or World Vision. Key milestones include; 60% of women farmers engaged in learning journeys within the first 3-month, Evidence briefs published and shared, climate smart practices adopted.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: Outcomes: Effective Governance framework developed. Field learning mechanisms established. Women grassroot farmers have access to markets. Major milestones include: Partner agreements signed, field operations launched, 70% of farmers recruited, 5 learning briefs developed, 2 innovations tested. Decision gates: Is the governance structure working? Are women taking part in the trainings? Is learning taking place? If not why? Are decisions based on data/evidence?

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: The highest failure is when farmer voice is not heard due to lack of feedback and accountability mechanisms. This can be closed by instituting feedback and accountability mechanisms in place to ensure that feedback is obtained and acted upon.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: I would ensure that the launch in the 3 districts is not done all at once to create time for learning. I would also drop the agro-parks industrial alignment. The grassroot model stays, gender integration, market linkages, MEAL and strategically engaging the government.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: 1 day alignment workshop for stakeholders between 20 – 40. Key participants include World Vision representatives, regional leads and decision makers in the 3 locations, Kujenga representatives, farmer representatives, local leaders and NGO representatives. Location is field based- Busoga. Workshop has to have ground rules, setting of expectations. Workshop will be participatory and will have panel discussions. Workshop will have breaks for participants to refresh. It will be chaired by an independent facilitator. Major agenda blocks include; How women were engaged; What lessons were learned; What were the major challenges; What innovations were applied; What are the recommendations to inform future programming; Were grant approvals efficient?, Were the grants and compliance systems efficient? Key outputs: Number of farmers who attended the workshop, Number of resolutions adopted.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: By integrating gender into MEAL systems especially having tools that have gender lens.

text: Shared learning, farmer voice is heard, accountability and transparency. These will be tested through audits and continuous monitoring and evaluation.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Large agro-parks typically favor the rich while excluding small scale farmers. Men dominate the agro-parks while the voice of women is marginalized. Women are more likely to receive lower pay in agro-parks because of low bargaining power. On the other hand agro-parks have larger access to markets, cold rooms and storage facilities which are beneficial to women farmers.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: - Local partners are on ground and they understand the issues more than regional actors

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: My intention would be to ensure growth without losing the local spirit that made Kujenga work. Kujenga’s pilot work succeeded because it stayed close to the local women farmers and managed to solve the problems they faced daily. Personally, this will remain the heart of the scale vision. Expansion will build on what works well, e.g. community ownership and quick feedback from the field while adding structures that support reach across the proposed new regions. My non negotiables would include these. Voices from the local women farmers must continue to come through and shape decisions, field first learning and local ownership where Kujenga’s community structures must remain central and not side lined by the larger NGOs. Where I can flex would include these. Embracing working with larger NGOs because of the additional expertise they would bring onboard, adjusting the MEAL tools to facilitate regional reporting but ensuring that core metrics on women’s participation are kept. Additionally, aligning with Government’s development strategy without changing Kujenga’s model.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: 1. I propose that every partner ToR and budget includes a funded local leadership role preferably a woman from the community. 2. Each work plan should reserve a small percentage of resources for locally led training and feedback sessions.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: Over-indexing on formal partners can disconnect the program from the people it serves. Field learning slows and the local project participants lose confidence in themselves thus leading to “cooked” reports which are disconnected from reality on ground. To prevent this, among others, I would recommend that at least some project review meetings happen in the field with local community representation and not just in offices.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: I would trade fast growth for depth. Quick expansion through the larger NGOs looks impressive but it risks leaving out the gist that made the model work. Slower growth allows the opportunity to build local capacity and keep the local women farmers’ trust. Protecting community leadership/ownership is very key because it anchors the program in real local ownership which is what sustains scale.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: The next 60 days will be a live learning cycle where the field teams, women farmer leaders and partner staff will feed data weekly from sources like adhoc farmer catch up meetings, feedback from trainers etc. A locally led team will meet periodically to review patterns and agree on the next steps. Key artifacts will include simple dash boards that track harvests and the participation of local women. Summarized brief reports about lessons learned for the partners coupled with feedback from community groups on what worked well. A design sprint would trigger when 2 or 3 consecutive catch up meetings show a high drop in local women’s participation as this would mean that the model is losing track. The changes I would make are to allow field leaders to make relevant adjustments in the field without waiting for head office approval.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: The local women might prefer smaller and more frequent delivery of their produce to bulk sales encouraged by the regional hubs. HQ might assume that bulking facilitates efficiency, yet the local women want to balance their participation with mother caregiving duties among others. For me to surface this early, field teams will share catch up meeting summaries that mention the local women’s constraints. Those summaries will feed into periodic “pattern boards” reviewed by local leads and one HQ representative. In case the vice remains the same consecutively, I plan to experiment with a smaller bulking model for HQ to witness trends.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: Policy alignment is supposed to give us directions and not to dictate what we are supposed to do. These Agro parks by the Government can provide the market linkages we need but our model remains intact i.e. interventions stay at the grass roots where the local women farmers test what works well. To avoid pilot theatre, each experiment will solve a real problem say in line with marketing or production. The grass root teams will document a change per cycle to ascertain what can be put into routine practice. We will ensure that we do not abandon our principles but instead make necessary changes to align with the national frameworks.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: I would consider shared transport for the local women farmers e.g using a hired truck per market day. Each women’s group books time slots and fuel costs are shared amongst members based on individual’s load. I would judge this based on signals like, how often women reach markets and whether transport costs per member are dropping.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Supply Chain Engagement; Madam X, Area Agribusiness Advisor Owns links with buyers, transporters, and input suppliers. She will secure at least 3 framework agreements for aggregation of yields and input delivery in Teso and Karamoja and align local cooperatives accordingly. MEAL Learning: Mr YZ, MEAL Advisor – Livelihoods Program Spearheads data capturing and analysis. He will be able to develop one pager field logs and or WhatsApp reporting for trainers. He will host the first field learning review with local farmer leaders and update the dashboard on yields and participation. Community Liaison: Madam ABC, Community Liasion Officer - Kujenga Network In charge of keeping women farmer voice at the center of the program. She will convene women group representatives from different districts for shared issue tracking and will be able to share a short brief highlighting field insights and challenges to leadership. Escalation Path: Okello, who is the Strategic Initiatives Lead Receives weekly summaries from the above personnels and if a high risk is consistently reported, e.g. drop in women’s participation, Okello should convene a review call with World Vision and Kujenga to decide immediate action.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: Target outcomes include women-led producer groups in the regions can sell directly to verified buyers, a functional feedback mechanism that links field data, MEAL reports, and leadership reviews within 2 -3 weeks of collection plus integration of community leadership roles and budgets in all new partner agreements. Milestones include; completion of field baseline survey by day 20 owned by the MEAL personnel, signing of local leadership ToRs by day 35 owned by the community liaison officer, drafting buyer contracts by day 45 owned by the area Agribusiness Advisor, mid-term review by day 60 owned by Okello the Strategic Initiatives Lead and lastly regional handover by day 90 which is a responsibility of the entire team. Some of the slippage signals include fewer women participation in coordination meetings.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: The highest risk of failure is majorly between the local community trainers and regional NGOs. While the local community trainers share real time lessons, the NGOs focus on compliance and reporting cycles which might lead to a mismatch. To close this gap, I would introduce weekly physical check-in calls that convene a field trainer, NGO officer, and MEAL personnel to share experiences and address all matters arising.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: I would drop the long partner workshops because they are expensive and usually time-consuming, yet they don’t really touch the field outcomes. I will keep the weekly check-ins intact as they help us to keep in touch with the real farmer experience.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Workshop goal: To bring everyone onto the same page about how we will use real field data to guide the next 90 days such that by the end of the day, each team knows what they own, how they connect, and how learning moves from field to decision. Agenda of the workshop 9:00 to 9:30 am: Opening remarks from the strategic initiatives lead with a brief on the importance of the alignment. 9:30 to 10:00 am: Feedback from the field i.e. the women’s groups. 10:00 am to 12:00: Moving from data to action i.e. sharing a real case scenario. 12:00 pm to 3:00 pm: Keeping the local women farmers at the center. Led by the Gender Advisors. 3:00 pm to 5:00 pm: Wrap up and the next steps. Each team commits to one action they will deliver immediately. The day feels practical and everyone walks out knowing who does what.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: I would make gender data part of MEAL’s core and not isolating it. I would emphasize tracking how women shape and benefit from results using the same indicators, tools, and review what MEAL already runs. I would also encourage the Gender Advisor to always sit on MEAL review calls

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text: My 3 principles will include listening to each other, testing solution before scale up and constantly staying in touch with partners to keep updated

question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: The decision on where and how to scale next must be co-owned, not just approved because if top leadership decides alone, scale risks failing. I would structure it as a co-decision platform composed of key personnels. The entire membership must always reach a consensus before something is done.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: An executable promise here should is something people can touch, feel, see, and trust. My weekly promise would be sharing one short note from the field to show case what changed for women farmers in the week.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: My 3 leading indicators include, Number of women participating in activities, quantity of produce reaching the buyers and number of weekly reports shared. Once a metric turns red, I will organize a mini review meeting to fix the issues as soon as possible.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: My recovery conversation will focus on the facts and not a blame game. I will ensure that we review the 2 missed milestones together and ask the partner what might have hindered the progress. After our review, we will jointly build a recovery plan to clarify roles and time frame. My decision options will include offering support through extra check-in meetings and focusing on what can realistically be done.

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: I will ensure that every meeting has a real decision to make and not just updates. Action points must always be noted and tagged to a responsible person who must be accountable in the next meeting.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: Some of the questions I would ask include. What are the best practices that have helped the local women farmers to succeed? are the partners’ roles clear to everyone? what are the key learnings we take from the field? After the reflection, key deliberations are noted and shared with everyone such that required actions can be done accordingly.

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: It will be a lesson learned for us, and I would share the finding with field teams and partners then I would invite explanations on what might have caused that. We will jointly co-create a solution to address this.

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: In the next quarter, I will stop hosting those long partner workshops because they take a lot of money and time but rarely change what happens on ground. I would invest the saved resources in the field level adaptations.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Aligning with the Agro-Parks helps us to gain visibility and access to better storage, buyers, and government support but exposes us to a risk of bureaucratic tendencies. Staying fully grassroots allows us to stay real. My call is 50 50. We stay anchored in Kujenga’s field work and plug into Agro parks where it adds support.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: I will need an updated produce and sales report from Kujenga’s Serere pilot and a district level partner readiness note from the operations team who’s set up to move in Teso and Busoga, and who’s still short on staff or tools. If either one doesn’t come in, I’ll call the field leads directly, get rough numbers and make the decision with what we have.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: Honesty and context are key here. I would call an adhoc check-in meeting just enough to explain the choice of a decision and what drove it. I acknowledge the consequences and then invite partners to suggest how to soften the impact. Even if we still move forward, they will know that their voice counted and that we made the call with care, not convenience.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: Everyone has to stay true to the core commitment which is women lead and learning stays close to the ground, and data drives choices. When a change feels big enough to affect others, teams share it in a short brief about lesson learned.

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: Key to note and take on in any scale out is what has worked out well, and a remodel in what did not work well while using learning of why it did not work well. There will be need to stick to the models that were agreed on with the donors, unless remodeling was approved or is able to be approved. example would be sticking to the gender lens. Next to note is to carry out cpacity assesment of the actors to be involved in the implementation, and plan tailored capacity building.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: To achieve results, we will need to build local leadership at the partners leadership, therefore, we will need to have capacity building sessions in the TOR. 2, when we build the capacity of the local leaders, there will be sustainability, because they will remain in the communities with the skills and will likely continue to implement and advocate for the required changes.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: One possible risk is leaving out potential partners with the right will, skill and local knowledge of the contexts. Many formal partners of mastered the art of making money, they may not deliver adequately yet report on impacts that are not real, the risk is in having low impact at the end of the project, or much moeny will be spent in close follow up of the partner. Risks of not building and leaving behind sufficient local capacities. To avoid community voices from being side lined, involve community right from design, to ensure ownership, encourage clear, transparent and safe community feed back mechanisms

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: I would select may be two of the scale out locations(maintain a focus to small reach) but ensure the gender lens and forcasted impact to inclusive group is maintained.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: The 60 day learning loop would include the community members, project staff, project participants, opinion leaders or key informants, and field observations and produce case stories, briefs and facts to help in the scale out. and what I would recommend chaning first is dropping what did not work, taking up opportutnities that were not foreseen.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: An example would be the availability of the staff on ground to support the implementation of the project, picking example from where I mentioned before that formal bigger partners may be so much profit oriented contrary to implementing quality work, yet HQ may assume them to already be experts, with right staff, and focused on quality delivery. I would bring it out on field reports, and meetings and together with the partners, device means for improvements.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: Make sure that the experimentation at village level involving kujengo and the women's group fits into what is in the policy, probably having actors responsible for policy environment such as sub county agricultural Officers involved.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: One that comes to my mind is collective bulking and marketing, I would judge by it's ability to enable the women sell their products at beyond break-even point, and also within acceptable timing.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Supply chain led by Aplot who is operations manager , she will ensure that all the required items for work are procured, she escalates to Okello, the strategic inititative Lead. MEAL learning will be handled by Otim, he will spear head the learning loop and reporting to Okello, community Liason will be by Asango, who will be in direct touch with and reports to Otim.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: Outcomes; 1.Field-first learning loop implemented in the targeted community.2. Community made aware of the plan to expand. 3. Successful models scaled. Milestones; 1. Required partners on-boarded, lead by Okello and the Kujengo lead, to be complete in15 days. 2. Community buy-in secured in the new locations with willing participants signed up/profiled, led by Apolot, in 15 days. 3. Learning complete and report shared for use by team to design scale out, led by Otim the MEAL in 10 days. 4. Village level experiement established, and monitoring started for the first 50 days and to offer continous learning, led by community Liason. 5.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: The highest likelihood of failure may be in process of transitioning from grassroots actor like Kujengo to a formal NGO, local experience may be lost, and large NGO may be over ambitous, affecting quality of implementation, to close the gap I would match the grass root with formal NGO in implementation, and ensure capacity of grassroot is built in the process. Ensure each partner is sure of their roles.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: In my opinion all the activities would stay.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: The one-day alignment workshop involving would look like this; Arrival of participants, registration of participants, opening remarks by Okello the Strategic Initiative lead, H e higlights the reason for the workshop as being to enable each team understand the locally led model, and plan for scaling the successful model. He takes the participants through the roles of each partner and each team member. Next Agenda would be mapping the role of each actor, and laying down the excution plan, so that everyone goes back sure of their roles and timelines. After every actor is clear of their roles, and timelines for the activities, the grants team leads the rest in budget review for each activity, and action point drafted and the workshop ends.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Ensure that all the team members understand the need to win together and bring MEAL and Gender Advisor together to jointly work on success indicators, in design of the interventions, the field-first learning, ensure both MEAL and the Gender Advisor are available agree on acheiveable targets.

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text: Locally Led model, Gender lens. and climate smart approaches. to check adherance, check the execution plan drawn, and review/ check for adherance in in periodic reports and meetings.

question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: A decision on how to realign interventions and approaches.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: An executable promise would have the timeline, and responsible person to execute. One commitment to publish weekly would be weekly progress towards the activities as indicated in the execution plan.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: #women practicing climate smart agriculture, set at 80%, for achievement in month 80, and light turning yellow if still at 60% by month 70, and red at 60% in month 75. %women who have accessed market set at 80%, for achievement in month 80, and light turning yellow if still at 60% by month 70 and red at 60% in month 75. %increase in household income for women participants set at 80%, for achievement in month 100, and light turning yellow if still at 60% by month 80 and light turning red at month 90. All these will be reported by the MEAL Advisor. The light will remain green before turning yellow, meaning the team is on track, yellow light means the team should change the speed and strategize to meet timeline. while at red the team MUST put in writing reason for delay, and set a timeline for achieving the required.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: Bring to the attention the need to deliver within the required timeline and target. Non-negotiables: gender transformation, MEAL, integration of field learnings

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?

At the end of these presentations, the partners are given time to ask questions of clarity and also make suggestions to improve what the consortium manager and advisors have communicated. The outputs from this workshop would include a clear understanding by all team members of the project goal, objectives, indicators, targets, budgets, workplans

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: What is going on well? What isn't going on well? why is it or isn't it going well? How can it be fixed? Who should fix it? What is needed to fix the problem? Once these questions are answered together with the team, come up with a matrix detailing way forward and responsible persons. In the next quarterly meeting, review the matrix and see whether what was planned has been addressed by those responsible. If not, include this in the next matrix until it is addressed.

text: The scale vision is to build a rooted network that scales widely.The non negotiable are;Community led delivery where implementation is in the hands of the farmers.Empowering the female farmers to strengthen the gender lense,.adaptive learning through simple feedback mechanisms.We can flex in the partnership models by tapping on the technical skills of the bigger NGOs to build capacity of the farmers, flexing can also be done by engaging the government led agro industrial parks to build the skills of Kujenga and strengthening of the MEAL reporting system to capture to capture not only donor requirements but also support farmer improvements.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: Loss of field-first learning." Formal partners often come with rigid, pre-designed methodologies and bureaucratic processes which can affect Kujenga's model that learns directly from the community making it slower for the organization to adapt, new strategies .When a formal partner is the primary funder, Kujenga risks becoming a mere implementer which erodes its autonomy and accountability to the community it serves and theforfore decisions will no longer be in the best interest of the farmers but to satisfy the partner's reporting requirements.To mitigate this ,several safeguards can be put in place such as ;Redesign the MEAL system with the community, train the community members (especially women) as data collectors and analysts,utilizing participatory tools like Community Scorecards, where community members rate the program's performance against their own defined indicators, this counters the risk of the gender lens being diluted, as the community sets and monitors the actions.Seeting up feedback and accountability mechanisms is also very important to facilitate improvements and tracking and Strengthening of Reflection meetings;Establish regular, open community meetings (e.g., quarterly ) where all partners (Kujenga, formal NGO, government) present progress, challenges, and financial updates in an accessible, transparent manner. This prevents information from being filtered through bureaucratic layers and builds shared ownership.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: 1. Opening: Acknowledge Partnership & State the Facts (Grounded & Direct) "Thank you for meeting. I want to start by reaffirming how much we value your partnership and the critical work you do on the ground in Serere. Your local knowledge is the backbone of this network." "With that said, we need to be direct. Our records show that Milestone (B )and Milestone (C) were missed by [number] of days. This has a direct impact on our ability to scale to Teso and Karamoja as planned. The purpose of this meeting is to understand what happened and together, decide how we get back on track, immediately." 2. Diagnosis: Understanding the 'Why' (Grounded & Inquisitive) This phase is about listening. I will use open-ended questions linked to the context Kujenga has flagged. On Execution: "Walk me through the internal challenges. Were there issues with your team's capacity, resources, or processes? From our side, we've been concerned about 'execution drift' and 'role confusion' as we scale. Are you feeling that? Is the 'spine' of the project—our core principles—getting lost in day-to-day chaos?" On Scaling: "How is the expansion from Serere to the new regions affecting your team? Are the challenges in Teso or Karamoja different from what we anticipated, and are we adapting our support accordingly?" On External Pressures: "There's a lot of noise right now, the government's 'Agro-Industrial Parks' strategy, pressure to work with larger formal NGOs. How is this external environment impacting your focus and ability to deliver on our grassroots commitments?" On Kujenga's Role: "Be honest with us. Has our support been adequate? Did the recent MEAL redesign discussions create confusion or dilute the gender lens you were supposed to focus on? Are we, the leadership, part of the problem?" 3. Co-Creating the Recovery Plan (Bold & Executable) "Based on what you've shared, we need a recovery plan that is realistic and has immediate milestones. Let's build it together, right now." Immediate Actions: "What are the 1-2 things you can do this month to get back on track with the missed milestones?" Revised Work Plan: "Let's look at the next 30 days. We need to break down the next major milestone into smaller, weekly check-ins. What support do you need from us to make this happen? A dedicated technical advisor for MEAL tools? Clarification in writing from leadership on our priorities?" Feedback and accountability Mechanism: "We will schedule a 15-minute check-in every Friday for the next month to review progress against these weekly goals. This is non-negotiable." 4. Closing: Defining the Decision Point (Grounded & Clear) "We are leaving this meeting with a revised plan. I want to be clear: this is a critical moment for our partnership. We will review progress together in two weeks. At that point, based on whether you have met the revised weekly targets, we will make a final decision about how to proceed.

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: Since they had a successful pilot of the Climate-smart, women-inclusive Agribusiness implemented Kujenga farmers network therefore my vision to scale up to enable reach to Teso, Karamoja and Busoga will not change the grassroot of the proven model at pilot while promoting locally led innovation, advancing women and girls voices and continuous learning. Based on my experience working with Bioenergy Association of Kyangwali (BUAK), I have learnt that it about relationships between the refugee cluster leaders and how they know their household association members in order to scale. Therefore, I would envision using the same structure for the new district where to Kujega is to be put so that the local people own the decisions instead of making them as implementers. My non- negotiable include the following; Kujenga Farmers network in serere co-design, co- lead the implementation of the program together with other NGO partners , women and girls put at the center of the implementation to enable addressing of the barrier and decision making, use evidence based approaches through carrying out local studies plus research , capacity building of the Kujenja farmers network . Interms of where I would Flex include the following; adoption of the Kujenja farmers network to the new MEAL tools employed during the process of scale up, I would be flex on the system change surrounding Kujenga farmers network, I flex on strengthening local governance of Kujenja farmers network for long sustainable impact.

All of the work to be external work and implementation at Kujega should be outsourced local-led in the community instead of bring external people who are not from the community of implementations.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: Over index on formal partners leads low visibility and influence of local partners. Over index on formal partners reduces ownership of the community solutions as they would perceive it as external. Over index on formal partners brings about power imbalances with the local partners . I would design the following safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined; formation of regional steering committees with 60% representation from behalf of Kujenja farmers network to increase their visibility and influence, co-designing of the community solutions together with Kujenja farmer network because they understand their own problem and using the community score card which encourages participatory assessments.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: I would use my experience from BUAK from last year when we were spending most money in transporting the bioslurry from women in different zones to aggregation center. The frugal innovation for me would be putting a whatsapp group for women farmers and vegetables vendors in one group to connect them and remove middlemen. I would judge that it is working by asking them if they sold to each other.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Assume Zahara is the head of supply chain from Kujenja farmer network,assume Charles is the head of MEAL at world vision, assume Sandra is the community lead in teso at Kujenja, Otim is the community lead in Karamoja at Kujenja and Grace is the community lead in Busoga at Kujeja supervised by Sanyu the community liaison at Kujenja. In terms of supply chain engagement , the key owner shall be Zahara ( Kujenja farmer network head of supply chain) working hand in hand the world vision manager, private sector, vendors contracted by the Kujenja and procurement officers at kujenja. Their milestone is on boarding and contracting of vendors, provide logistics, procurement. Escalation path shall through Okello at the world vision. In terms of MEAL learning, the key owner Charles the head of MEAL at world vision working hand in hand with Kujenja’s MEAL officer and the data clerks based at Kujenja. Their key milestone is to ensure that they track the progress of the project interms of gender and other MEAL related function. The escalation path is through the Okello and world vision director of MEAL. In terms of community liaison, key owner is Sanyu working hand in hand with Sandra, otim and Grace. Their key milestone is engage with women group and provide feedback report. Escalation path shall be through Sanyu to Okello.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: The 3 core outcomes include, increase women sales by 40% of the women actors, validation of the scale up integration gender and policy integration achieved without distorting the grass roots. 5 milestone, owners and decision gates include the following; my first milestone is Draft the list of roles and responsibilities by week one. This activity will be owned by Okello and the Managing director Kujenja. out put shall be a signed partnership agreement between Kujenja and world vision. Decision gate shall be if Kujenja is the right partner to deliver this scale up. Slippage early will be no signed partner agreement by week one. Second milestone is Carry out community feedback meeting defining women pathway across the areas of Teso, Busoga and Karamoja interms of pricing, aggregation among others by week 2. Key owner is Sanyu and Okello. Out put shall be community feed back report plus audios captured. Decision shall be around the different pathways voiced by the women and which among them is relevant to the project. Slippage early is less than 60 percent of women are not included in the decision made. The Third milestone is introduction of MEAL system and gender related activities in week 5. The Key owners is Charles the MEAL lead world vision, Kujenga gender advisor and Kujenja MEAL officer. Out puts shall be dashboards and finalization of gender related activities. Decision shall be around Kujenja being able to adopt the MEAL and gender related tools. Slippage early is understanding of the indicators by both world vision and Kujenja. Fourth milestone is review of the 90 day scale up plan drafted between Kujenja and world vision. The key owner is Okello and selected leadership team. Out put is scale up report for the 90 days. Decision will be archive 2 outcomes inorder to scale up. Slippage early shall be archiving less than 2 outcomes no scale up.

text: The likelihood of hand off failure shall be between World vision technical team and Kujenja field-based team because different understanding of milestones deliverables, failure to deliver on the targets set on the activities and different cultures and languages. I propose weekly check-in with Kujenja to understand their key deliverables and challenges plus areas where they need support. I also propose learning workshops between world vision technical teams anhd Kujenja.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: I would not onboard any other partner to implement the scale up because it would give us time to strengthen Kujenja capacity to deliver this scale up since they manage to deliver the pilot. Bringing on board any other partner would increase coordination work loads and delay the implementation of the scale up. I would not bring on board to many MEAL and gender tools because Kujenja also has MEAL tools that we could review and adopt during the implementation of the scale up.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: The goal of the meeting is to leave everybody knowing what we want to achieve, who will be doing what and when. The meeting will start at eight in the morning and end at five in the evening. The meeting will start with introductions for the members; sharing what they do and where they are struggling to do their work well. After that, the chairperson shares why they meeting was called and the expected outcomes and dive straight into the activities of the days while responding with answers to the questions where the members are struggling and also set up away for them reach out for support and then go for lunch. After lunch I give the members a real scenario when participation drops to 20% in 6 weeks and they discuss what happens and from that, everyone get to share what they would do differently when they get to their work stations. The signed commitments on what they are going to do on Monday would be one of the output.
