This will be enforced by ensuring there are reporting deadlines for activity implementation, having weekly catchup meetings.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: The dashboard will start with developing indicators e.g The three leading indicators will be 1. Number of women practicing climate smart agriculture. 2. Number of women involved in climate smart agriculture accessing markets. 3 percentage of actions implemented to create an enabling environment for women to freely access markets for their agriculture produce. Then determine the target for each indicator. After track performance using colour codes like red for poor performance, yellow for moderate performance and green for good performance. Then this metric is linked to data base where accurate data is filled. This will be owned by the MEAL and project staff. The escalation rule if a matric turns red is to pose and review all process and develop a new way of achieving target i.e identifying any other knowledge or skill needed, any norms inhibiting achieving results, etc.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: If a partner misses 2 milestones, the first thing will be to support them to acknowledge that there are missing milestones and then support then identify causes of missing those milestones then support them to develop an acceleration plan and bridge any gaps that caused the missing of milestones.

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: Update theatre will be prevented through ensuring updates are do just focusing on activities implemented but they are focusing on whether the expected output and outcomes were achieved by the activity as well as discussing lessons learnt.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: The questions would include What has the project achieved VS what was projected by end of quarter. Reasons associated to that performance. Challenges faced. Lessons learnt and key recommendation or what can be done different as well as answering the “so what?” a report will be written and shared with the donor for approval of changes suggested.

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: I would conduct consultation and feedback meeting to identify cause of the negative findings the develop a new plan to address gaps or anything that was overlooked at design or implementation.

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: Pause activities until realignment is done that include new adaptations.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Alignment would involve advocacy meeting with policy makers to also involve grassroot farmers, for example creating points for small scale farmers to store their produce where they can be picked or create cooperatives. My call would be to farmers to join cooperatives who would bring the industrial park services closer to farmers as well as negotiate better prices for the agri products.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: The 2 data points would be number of women involved in climate smart agriculture and number of women linked to markets. This data would be got from the women groups and this is data that can be routinely collected and updated so continuous monitoring would be my fallback.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: I would socialize hard trade-off buy involving partners at project start so that the objectives and deliverables for the project are well understood. Conduct frequent project reflections to iron out bottlenecks while allowing innovation and adaptation.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: Allowing flexibility, conducting regular reflection to contextualize implementation without diverging from the outcome. Community involvement in design and decision making.

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: The vision should is empower women and women led enterprises across Teso, Karamoja, and Busoga, leveraging on Kujenga's grassroots expertise to drive climate-smart programing and inclusive growth. The non negotiables include the gender consideration / the work with women and girls, the use of local/garssroot community based organizations who understand the local contexts ,and the focus on climate smart agricultural production for improved resilience. The areas of flexibility will include adjusting the operation structure of the project totake into conideration the geographical needs and government priorities, redesigning the MEAL frameworks to ensure genders sensitive climate smart outcomes are adequately measured and reported on across the new project location.Also adapting the partnerships -Grassroot organization, Goverment and community members to utilize existing local expertise and resources while maintaining the core partnership principles of ensuring Kujenga has the voice, power, resources and capacity to take lead in the delivery of the project..

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: 1.Increase(flexible) funding allocation to partner with at least 10% of the budget for local partner capacity building. 2. TORs/MoUs to reflect more long term enggagemnts rather than transaction

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: 1. Power imbalances may favor influential stakeholders, marginalizing vulnerable groups such as women and girls. 2.Formal partners may not capture community dynamics, causing missed opportunities for improved delivery. 3.Local voices and needs may be overlooked, leading to less effective interventions. Safeguards include: Feedback sessions such as joint monitoring and evaluation with all stakehoders -women/girls inclusive to ensure participation of all, partipatory decison making through consultation with all catergories of stakeholders to ensure their voices , needs and isuses are fully represented, Kujenga should ensure field presence to bridge any communication gap and s

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: Expansion to Karamoja, Teso, Busoga can be traded off but the localy led approach of working with Kujenga to preserve its community led approach is non negotiable. Expansion may ensure the numbers of participants /reach are met but quality, impact and sustainability can easily be compromised as Kujenga seeks to expand.By prioritizing community led approach, we are prioritizing community engagement and participation, subsequently building trust, fostering ownership, and creating more effective, locally relevant solutions to community problems..

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: Sources to include the partner team members-project staff, workplans and budgets , activity and partner reports, community/stakeholder feedback meetings. The learning would happen on a weekly and monthly basis; partner meetings are done on a weekly to review the workplans and budgets, the stakeholder/community meetings can be done on monthly basis as well as review of progress/activity/monthly reports to track implementation and identify emerging issues. If the issues being addressed by the project do not align with what the community /stakeholders are sharing as the pressing needs then it will require design print. Also if the project priorities are not aligned to the local government priorities them a design sprint is required. I would change the terms of the partnerships to ensure community voices are heard, interests are considered through a participatory process.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: Climate smart interventions are may not be a priority because of norms around land access and decicion on finances and enterprise selection. I will plan for a community meeting with women groups, local laders, local goverment reprsentatives and Kujenga staff to understnad more into this insight. Then discuss with partner an opportunity for revising the work plan and reallocating the budget to take into consideration the new initiatives or priorities by the women's groups.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: Identify opportunities for collaboration between the project and local government priorities-Agro Parks to ensure the two are aligned. Through feedback sharing, stakeholders and community members will be able to identify what works and is scalable and what requires re design.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Digital Agro input system is a web based platform that brings women groups and agro input dealers to ensure improved access to inputs, extenison services buyers together . Through this innovation, women's groups receive digital vouchers via SMS or WhatsApp. The Vouchers can be redeemed at local input suppliers or service providers. Once vouchers are redeemed , the supliers and service providers are reimbursed via mobile money - the partner will sign an MoU with Mobile money to provide payment to suppliers.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Supply chain Engagament: Bob, the procurement Advisor; Map service providers -agro input dealers, onboard vendors-service providers and train them on the voucher system. Esther , the partner MEAL Advisor ; develop the MEAL plan and indicators, recruit and train Research Assistants to collect baseline data, data is collected and analyzed and report drafted. Judith the Community Liaison Officer for Kujenga; develops an action plan for community engagement, mobilizes communities and conducts sensitization about the voucher system and conducts feedback sessions with community. Escalation paths are Molly-the ED at Kujenga and Okello- the Initaitive lead Worldviison will develop a SOP for escalation, stakeholders will be mobilized and oriented on the SOP , and the SOP will be tested, feedback documented and used before the SOP is scaled up for adoption

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: The 3 Outcomes are : a) Increased market access- Women Groups have improved access to and buyers b) Improved Livelihoods-Women's groups increase income and decision-making power c) Strengthened Partnerships- Effective partnerships with government, private sector, and communities. The Millestones are a)Women groups mobiized to participate in the project activities by Judith the community Liason Officer within weeks 1 and 2. Another mileston is that MoUs/agreements signed by servoce providers and other vendors , being managed by Bob the Procurement Manager within week 3 and 4. The third milestone is testing of the voucher system by the MEAL offiver-Esther within week 4 and 6. While training of women groups/capacity building of women groups by Judith the Community iiason officer within the week of 7 and 8. Lastly, review of progress, identification of gaps by Okello, the Strategic Imitative Lead in the last weeks-9 and 10. For each milestone, the processes will be reviewed to identify any challenges and support decison making processes through designing corrective actions from week 1 to week 10.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Delay to account for funds . Implement a milestone based kind of funding-partnership

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Workshop based reviews and trainings . Community feedback and reviews and more field based trainings

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Objective of the Workshop: To unpack the project, to assign roles and responsibilities and identify critical points in the project delivery. Key outputs to include: critical /strategic activities identified, workplans/procurement plans with key activities /actions developed and assigned timelines. A revised budget with realistic forecast developed. Schedules for weekly, biweekly and monthly meetings to discuss progress and support needs. Agenda would include: Review of the prioject proposal, review of the workplan, DIP , Log frame, procurement plan, budget by the sector heads (Project Manager, MEAL, OPs, Grants)

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: By having joint planning with MEAL and Gender technical persons .

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text: Collaboration, clear communication and accountability. Include parameters that measure these principles into the routine appraisal process.

question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: All functions to support procurement processes through automating the system from the point when request are raised to the reviewer till through approval while ensuring visibility to the supervisors of the different persons responsible.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Weekly check in with the teams on agreed actions/plans to track progress. Provide a dashboard of level of completion of tasks per individual /sector and follow with respective sector/individual to understand more and provide support accordingly.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: 1. At least 8.3% monthly budget performance of the total budget- Project Manager 2. At least 50% of target achieved by the first 6 months - MEAL Advisor and 3. Milestone completion rate/reporting timelines. If the budget performance is below 8.3% per month, arrange for a meeting with the team and develop an accelerated plan for 6 months and follow through on a weekly basis to track implementation .

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: Meet the partner staff-ED inclusive to understand what the issues/challenges. Develop doable solutions within a timeline and implement. If there is no improvement, put the partner on PIP and monitored for a month through weekly check ins until

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: Utiise other channels of communication open other than meeting-whatsapp and phone calls and emails within agreed timelines-weekly , monthly .

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: 1. Reflect on what's going on well and whats not going on well. what strategies will you implement/do differently and the indicators . How shall these changes be tracked-weekly, monthly etc through what approaches-meetings, field visits , joint implementation .

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: Conduct an additional investigation to complement the other finding. For instance if a gender analyis isnt comprehensive, i would pan for an SNET To enrich the findings of the gender analysis

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: To conduct hub level reflections /review instaed of national level with partners across the country. In doing so , we save other costs-transport accommodation and other conference services

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Agro Parks are require more investments, less focuses on the local needs of the communities. They provide more employment opportunities, additional revenue contribution to the districts/government. Protecting grassroot focus enforces local initiatives that adresses local needs, incorporate community voices and interest. There is value for money since the costs of operations are low, sustaining the benefits are realistic since the local staff are from the same communities. They unerstand the different practices and beilefs, norms and therefore design innovations that can result into impact but also a good understanding of the gatekeeper of these norms who can be engaged to transform communities. My call is to support ocal grassroot initiatives instead of prioritizing national investments that are not aligned to the interest, of the local communities .

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: The two data points are: risk management related data from the Risk department/ OPs and Business development data from the business development Manager/Advisor. If they dont arrive, we can get the data from MEAL and OPs for risks; we get data from OPs on currenting /existing funding and their end dates to ascertain the continuity of the organization/sector. and

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: Allow open discussions and reflections through meetings . Jointly implement to jointly identify the challenges and solutions.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: Identifying and working with grassroot initiatives who share similar vision and mission within those regions instead of bringing external initiatives/CBOs

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: A vision to scale: Locally Led vision with focus supporting this grass roots and women's model. This means Kujenga Farmers Network pilot continues to scale without changing it but gets support from World Vision, Formal Partners and aligns with the agro industrial parks strategy for the benefit of linkages in market access and technical support or backstopping and alignment with government policies. The non negotiables include: Field First Learning flagged by Kujenga hence have feedback mechanism from the groups periodically so that lessons and concerns are captured and addressed, local/community ownership especially women in decision making and direct funding should not be compromised (aspect of the gender lens) and then the implementation/execution should be done by Kujenga to avoid role confusion. Where to Flex: Alignment with the agro industries park strategy/partnership as this may be helpful in capacity strengthening and access to market linkages and the formal NGO partners as long as we are clear on that we are maintaining Kujenga as the a grassroots women inclusive model with a stipulated amount of direct funding.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: 1. Allocate 50% of funding directly to Kujenga Network to strengthen their local leadership/agency which can then contribute to regional expansion 2. Kujenga Farmers Network's roles should be clearly stated in the partner MOUs and their participation in any redesign process (TORS, Planning, Budgets) is mandatory.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: Risks arising from over indexing include; lost of Local innovations and agency -The formal partners may bring the 'big brother syndrome" of knowing it all and rejecting some of the local ideas, voice and innovations which will eventually kill the first field learnings and their agency and voice, secondly, NGO Bureaucracy is real around decision making and may slow the speed of Kujenga Farmers Network , Delayed or late disbursement of funds could be another risk that may lead to delays in implementation and destroying the element of local ownership and grassroots adaptability as formal partners subject them to their tools for implementation, monitoring and reporting. Safeguards would include setting up a feedback mechanism for instant feedback from Kujenga Farmers network, periodic community feedback score cards to review performance of the formal partners and also ensure all governance committees have local representation for inclusive participation and decision making.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: I would trade the quick scale (to protect this pilot women inclusive model) for purposes of strengthening capacity and agency of this local and community network. We should be able to scale tested grassroot innovations rather than scaling for the sake of expansion and replicating many which may be a failure. Additionally, letting the pilot grounded would help pick lessons and best practices for scale

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: Sources: Leaders feedback from Kujenga farmers network, partner reports, Field and back to office reports, Feedback and accountability channels, women groups meetings. Cadence: Biweekly meetings with the women leaders and formal partners, monthly community score card meetings Artifacts: Monthly learning briefs consolidated from the meetings, Weekly Field updates to SMT with key highlights. A signal that would trigger a design sprint would be leaders from Kujenga reporting that they are spending most of their time working working with new tools given by each formal partner as they were told to abandon all their tools. This would call for a redesign sprint to harmonize and standardize tools prioritizing Kujenga's tools they have been using in the past and tell formal partners to align with those of the local partners to avoid losing the local ideas/context and to redeem time for them to engage in their primary agribusiness work.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: The women may challenge that the alignment with the agro industrial parks strategy may not benefit them equally with other players in the market who are slightly advanced in the game because of quality standards. They want access to big markets for their products however, they are not yet there due to issues around post harvesting handling, storage etc that could hinder access to markets and other opportunities.. Yet HQ assumes that once they align with the agro industry parks strategy they should be able to compete favorably which is not the case especially in the early stages.. I will surface this by sharing this response in the weekly updates as one of the key highlights/fears for Kujenga and provide recommended actions if HQ is to support Kujenga and what it would take to be supported fully eg leverage synergies with different players to enhance their quality and gain benefits that come with the agro parks strategy.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: Experimentation at village level can be used as a valuable tool to create innovative ideas and products that would then feed the into the Agro parks hence connecting the two to align rather than working in isolation. kujenga is looking at strengthening their capacity by organizing, training and equipping women farmers with knowledge and skills to produce high quality produce that is competitive with the market standards and become a leading supplier for produce for the agro parks thus aim is to grow in capacity through experimentation, research and development and skills enhancement and not becoming a pilot theatre all through.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: A frugal visibility innovation would be introduction of a Daily Market Notice Board to strengthen market access by providing consolidated pricing and buyer demand information in real time to producers and market groups. This would be a physical board placed in a centralized place around the market, or identified strategic location in the communities that displays information that farmers can use to make decisions on demand and supply. This can then be shared on social media groups like whatsapps and text sms. This Daily Noticeboard tracks the daily high/low prices and and trending products, Buyer Alerts eg 10,000kgs of beans needed by so and so, include contact, and then the Price Lists that shows trending prices for few days so that a farmer knows and uses this to make decisions. This has a minimal cost of a board and markets and then a volunteer has to update daily for consistent and people to gain trust. To judge : Interview around how many people have relied on it for timely information and found it helpful (over 30% engagement?) any success story where people report using it to negotiate better prices and increase sale unlike before

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Supply chain is done by partners and WV to connect the Kujenga with Agro parks through an MOU (Milestone) by the first day partnership starts, MEAL learning is joint to get the first field learnings, they should come up with M&E tools and orient kujenga on how these will be used to not only monitor and report but also collect lessons, learnings and field insights. Milestones Co designed MEAL framework and reporting tools by 15th Day of first month and first brief on field learning published monthly. Community liasion is done by Kujenga farmers group leaders to mobilize farmer groups and inform them of the updates and readiness to be trained by the partner NGO, Milestone all groups informed by 15th day of month one and Partner NGO conducts orientation meeting and 1st training by end of Month one. Escalation paths: feedback and accountability channels for feedback accessible to all farmer leaders and their group members and communicated in the first meeting in place.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: 3 Outcomes: 1. Improved market access by Kujenga network (local partners aligned and providing technical support to Kujenga for increased market access for farmers and agribusinesses. milestones and slippage: Partnership mapping report completed before start of activities, if not done, then red flag and pause all new partner engagements - MOUs/Agreements signed with partners to support Kujenga with clear decision making structures owner is Okello (Month 1-2),if not done by end of month one escalate to management at partner level and WV), inception meetings conducted with all partners at the start of the implementation by week 2 of first month (by Okello) to help joint alignments, roles and expectations and learning agenda, if this doesn't happen then halt all field roll out until alignment is done: Joint workplans and budgets submitted before first disbursement of funds by grants and Ops leads Slipagge is if workplans and budgets are not submitted on time then delays in disbursement red flag and halt all activities until these are submitted 2. Local leadership and Agency strengthened through local decision making (voice, ownership and participation) onwer is okello - Local mgt committees established and functional by month (month 1-2) slipagged if committees are not functional by end of month 2, conduct assessement or seek feedback from Kujenga on possible solutions and adjust accordingly: community feedback and accountability mechanism functional by month 1 (formal partners and WVI slippage is inactive by week 4 seek alternative ways in consultation with kunjega on possible alternatives that easy and locally based.3. The field first learning Practice owner is Okello- Learning agenda for the project developed and shared with every stakeholder by 15th day of first month, if not done then escalate to management and request for delay of learning activities until this is established, monthly learning reviews/reflections conducted starting month 1 with weekly dashboards capturing these during the weekly feid visits, if dashboard not functional by week 2 escalate to MEAL teams for rapid catchup session before activities for the next week, milestone First learning brief published by end of month 1 summarizing the insights, slipagge is if not learning brief is published by end of first week in month 2 escalate to Program Director to review the learning loop and identify blockages, learning integrated in to decision making and that adaptations align with the field insights and feedback mechanisms and dash boards active in first month. this dash board should track all incoming feedback and responses and issues resolved targeting atleast 80% of issues closed in one month after reporting silpagge is if the feedback system is not actove or tracking issues that is one problem, and if issues are not resolved by atleast 70% then fag to the MEAl perosn to identify barriers

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Shared Decision making would be the likely handoff failure . The artifact or ritual to close this gap is emphasis on shared design making eg co signing on documents, reports and workplans among others which can resolved through joint review meetings

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: I would drop redundant hotel room workshops and meetings which are time consuming yet come at high cost with little impact . I would keep the joint first field learnings as they will help to capture experiences, encourage active participation of the farmers

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: One Day Alignment Workshop Agenda (Addressing Roles confusion, Loss of Agency for Kujenga and keeping everyone happy in the partnership) outputs would be shared decision making, roles alignment with joint planning, 8:00-8:30am- Arrival and Registration by WVI , 8:30 - 9:00- Welcome remarks and Introductions - WV , 9:00- 9:10 - Objective /Goal of the meeting - WV, 9:10 - 10:30am breakout session by function (What is going on well, what are the blokages, solutions to address this and what can we stop doing) by All, 10:30am - 11:00am - Tea Break by All, 11:00am -1:00pm Group presentations from their discussions to know what each group thought, by All, 1:00pm - 2:00pm - Lunch break by All, 2:00pm -3:00pm - Panel Discussion on Roles (as stated in MOUs) and issues affecting the partnership and what actions should be taken by All. 3:00 -4:00pm Agree on Action plan and commitment by everyone.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Have one MEAL system in place that has an integrated gender lens to capture all indicators around women empowerment, access and control of resources, and avoid creating two parallel systems as this stops silos across the program.

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text: 1. Shared decision making to ensure Kujenga doesnt loose agency/leadership and voice and that the partners are providing the technical support needed. This will be tested through planning meetings , TORs and reports where they have to co sign as well as seeing evidence of their input or contribution. 2. Co creation which can be tested through perodic meetings and reflections to explore of the success was a collaborative effort or one sided and also through the feedback loops. And lastly the principle of Trust and mutual respect. This is a default in any partnerships and its the foundation of success. if partners cannot respect and trust each other then they cannot move forward and this can be tested on how transparent the different functions operate, not hiding documents, not making decisions behind the scenes and backstabbing each other but acting in a consultative manner.

question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: The decision to have one integrated MEAL system with a gender lens and also aligned with all reporting systems with the project must be co owned and not approved because it reduces silos in the project and esnure the gender focus is hard wired to protect women's agency.. To structure it, Have joint MEAL and Gender Teams co design the MEAL framework to ensure each the right indicators are used for both functions, The other is co approvals where both Team Leaders for MEAL and Gender co sign on the reports before or review before final sign off and onward submission, and then the learning should be cross cutting to ensure they feed into each other and not necessarily picking numbers

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: The executable promise is to ensure that field first learnings are happening with active feedback on learning loop. One commitment would be a weekly field learning update that highlights one major learning insight from the field by each of the officers. Each week every officer posts a learning insight on the dashboard by every friday by 1:00pm. Enforcement would be automated through the dashboard, introduce red flags for thos who missed after two weeks and also have a closure loop to show impact by what decisions were made or adaptations that happened as a result of these learnings.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: 1. Focus Area 1- Gender and MEAL integration - Control and Ownership gap owner MEAL And Gender Advisor , Escalation rule if the data reported is not disaggregated according to integrated Gender and MEAL frameworks, or if disaggregated data is showing that less than 60 percent of women have control and ownership then this is a red flag that needs attention by convening a meeting with partners to dig deeper and adjust some approaches in implementation. Focus Area 2. Field First Learning - Roles alignment owner is grants and Ops lead Escalation rule is if Kujenga reports that most of the administrative roles are done by them and using partner templates which are cumbersome reducing their time on the real work in the community. is a red flag that calls for a meeting to realign partners and divert these roles. 3. Shared decision making - Leadership and Agency score for Kujenga By Okello WV Escalation rule if the monthly workplans, reports and TORS for the project are not being co signed by all partners loosing voice and agency of the local partners, There is need to convene and interrogate this issue and go back to the planned ways of having shared decision making

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: I would initiate a meeting with the lead partner to have a one-on-one. Start by - Thank you for making time for this meeting. We need to review two critical milestones that are over due: 1. Delayed Disbursement of funds to Kujenga farmers and 2. Not starting the Field First learning up to now. These are foundational commitments we made to Kujenga as a grass roots model but dashboards on these milestones are in red. The delayed disbursements may be affecting the field first learning which is an interconnected failure on our part. If the grants/Ops processes are too slow to release funds, this affects field footprint including field engagements ultimately this will soon lead to our worse fears earlier flagged by Kujenga of 'execution drift'. Where is the problem and what do we need to do to eliminate it immediately and is that something my organization can support, otherwise more delay will pause a risk to the entire program. Let's set a week to get these milestones back on track, after that, we will discuss the next action. Decision Options: Mandated process fix and transfer funds- trigger identified by laziness or overloading of Grants and Ops staff - Action is shift this task to someone else within 42 hours and transfer resources then they can deal with their staff incompetencies. if they are unable to fix this internally then another optuon could be to transfer the partner funds back to WV within a week for these activities affected and leave the rest for the partner to continue. Third option is phased termination if this continues over the next months with no change on the partner side.

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: Move away from information exchange and updates during the meetings to collective problem solving. Kind of 'Case study theatre' why complex issues are discussed and resolved using the different teams and functions just like heath settings where Inter-disciplinary meetings discuss complicated patient cases as part of the learning agenda. And updates are posted on a dashboard periodically before these joint reviewed meetings ate convened where each team comes with one case to present and get solutions. Strategies- Move meeting updates to problem solving meetings, Have a dashboard for updates separately, Have a decision agenda, invite decision makers into their space and not everyone to have a focused meeting that signs off a decision and this should be the culture and encourage evidence/data insights that will make decision making faster based on data at hand.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: This could be considered as a diagnostic and systems unblocker meeting focused on checking the red flags, governance, learning insights rather than an update meeting. So the meeting would be Titled'; The Quarterly Pause and Reflect. Goal: To reflect on field experiences, what is working, identify lessons and co create strategies improved market linkages and scaling impact. Ensure attendance and participation is balanced and Kujenga has voice and participation. Questions: What is working well?, Does Kujnega feel in charge with Spine or feel exceution drift? Is the Agro parks alignment working out, What is failing and why?,What was the outstanding success we achieved during the quarter, what do we need to stop doing or change immediately, what was the biggest challenge encountered? Phase 1: Diagnosing and prioritizing what to change Does kujnega feel in change or feel execution drift? Answer : we feel in drift when the formal partners take two weeks to approve and co sign on workplans and TORs. Conversion: Agree on approval time for any co signed document to be two days. Violating it results in an immediate transfer of approval authority to WV technical lead where item falls. 2. What is failing and why (biggest challenge Answer: the forms by partners are duplicated and long yet require Kujenga to use each of them to capture the same data and what will not even be used wasting time Conversion: Harmonize data and information requirements to have ine tool that is simple, less time consuming but works for everyone partner and answers their data needs and let Kujenga testify about the time saving. 3. What do we need to stop doing or change immediately? Answer: Partners should reduce time for workshops and meetings that take most of kujenga network time yet they feel these are not adding value technical or improving their market access. Conversion: Reduce all general meetings and non essential trainings with immediate effect and redirect these funds to hire a local business expert to train all farmers.4. Is the Agro parks align,ent working out? Answer: Yes, its working but kujenga getting low process because of low negotiation power. Conversion: Have a Kujenga representative on each of the committees especially one that negotiates pricing. These actions will be documented into an quarterly addendum annex on systems adjustments and co signed by each of the partners to be

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: Red flag alert during the monthly reports and request for joint review to test the earlier hypothesis right or wrong and describe this as learning to protect trust. To protect momentum, validate the community's action in line with their context eg deep rooted social norms in that community and then sign an adaptation note that provides solutions to deep rooted norms in that area eg male engagement activities that will support in shifting these norms.

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: General meetings and workshops and think of every impact per dollar. Look at activities that bring high impact with low cost rather than update theatres that involve high cost and no impact thus redirect money to the adaptation fund with immediate effect.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Costs/ benefits: Alignment with Ministry Agro parks - Initial cost higher in short run but longrun has access to high value national/export markets and linkages, government subsidy and technical support. Protecting grass roots-( Kujenga) Initial cost lower, low quality products forlocal markets for strengthening community capacity. Equity Implication: Aligning with Ministry - kujenga has to compete with established/experienced famers who might be producing more, and have higher power in bargaining and negotiations leaving the as margin suppliers with no spine/control becomes- Vs Protecting low risk- power and profits remain with Kujenga and in charge of supply chain Execution risk- High- Government decision making is slow due to bureaucracy leading to delays in execution and timelines, requires a formal partners to support with accompaniment around compliance Vs Moderate risk with market saturation or lack of scale, dependent on their networks and expertise in the community.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: Failure with co signing mandate - From Formal Partner Grants and Ops Lead Fall back: assumption is the bureaucracy that makes this take days/weeks. Implement a directive of 2 days rule and reduce to two pages maximum until issue is resolved. 2. Analytics Dashboard for funds disbursement: Grants and Ops Lead: Funds should be disbursed after submission of workplans. All disbursements should be done within a week once submission of approved workplans is done and failure to should lead to escalation

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: Convene only the leaders first to communicate the issue in a transparent manner, walk through it and mention the shared risks, get their ideas on mitigation strategies for their voice and participation. share some of the options you feel and gauge. Arrange for a wider meeting with stakeholders and highlight the decision for the trade off the ambition of scale to protect the interest of the women who are a marginalised group hence co owning the risks of gradual scale.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: the 80% Non negotiable (coherence) about Kujenga's autonomy as a local network with direct funding of 60%, Gender and MEAL integration and field first earning loops, and 20% flexible rule where adaptations are contextualized according to region

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: • Engage with Kujenga Farmers Network to document the process of the pilot(initiation, planning, implementation, monitoring and sustainability) and learnings undertaken ( what made it succeed, what were the challenges and key takeaways) to provide a framework for each partner to innovate around without diluting the model. This includes a step-by-step and documenting the experiences of the women farmers. • Identify at least 3 implementing local partners, one from each regions of Teso, Karamoja and Busoga that is aligned to the vision of World Vision, Uganda, and assess technical expertise and experience in the area of climate-smart agribusiness, their readiness and adaptability to driving the pilot while ensuring the inclusion of women. • Identify 1 learning partner to facilitate learning and adaptation of the pilot. This could an institute or university level that will also have to pick up the learning and incorporate in their work for scale up. • Facilitate a meeting with each of the partner management and leadership to unpack the pilot and approach of delivery based on the learnings from Kujenga. I will be clear with the expectations especially on delivering through this approach and learning from the communities of Serere to scale up in the other districts of their regions. • Sign MOUs or agreements and define key things that are required in the adaptation. The approach that will be adapted based on the community, while ensuring gender integration.. • Work with the partners to second or hire staff or consultants with the right skills and experience to scale the model in their regions. The staff should have the right attitude and commitment to learn and appreciate women’s participation in the pilot. They should be passionate about driving change while working with women farmers and entrepreneurs. • Facilitate master training for the partner technical staff to appreciate the model and how it fits within their roles- implementation, monitoring and learning. In these institutions, ask them to second gender focal persons who will trained and mentored by World Vision to be able to support gender integration. • Work with the partners to map and identify key women farmers and some youth in each of the regions of Teso, Busoga, and Karamoja and train them in climate-smart agribusiness as focal persons, facilitators and mentors for other women to enable easy adaptation. • Facilitate the trained women and youth to work with community leaders to mobilize other farmers, raise awareness on the model. Negotiable  Innovations around the model without losing the key components Non-negotiables  Each partner delivers in their region and will always share the scale-up plan to any other locations without interfering with another partner’s work.  Gender integration- Addressing barriers that women are facing. Women must be at the centre of the pilot- innovate with them, women’s voices should be included during planning and innovation.  Document learnings while working with the learning partners.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text:  Partnership with private sector actors will strengthen Market systems as well as technology adoption to unlock the market dynamics for women and youth through Job creation, market linkage and access to credit and digital services.  The field-first learning approach, learning from the women farmers while working with learning institutions (Agricultural and business institutes/ universities), will facilitate hands- on learning and mindset change among the young labor force in agricultural in agribusiness to drive the change in the agribusiness sector especially women farmers.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: • Navigating organisational cultures, systems, policies and internal politics since each institution is independent and would like to see to that there is no interference from other partners. This can lead to delayed implementation or poor quality delivery. • Bureaucratic processes within each organisation/institution especially to adapt new models visavi their models, which they know and do very well and has been working. • High expectation despite limited funds- the organisations expect to be fully funded and yet in reality the funds may not be as much as expected especially in the current funding landscape which has changes. • Most partners have their approach of delivery and this could affect adoption/ adaption of the pilot considering Kujenge is community-based. They could overlook the pilot based on learnings from Kujenge by undermining their level of knowledge, authority, experience and exposure. Safeguards to prevent the community voice from being sidelined • Have a working committee, the Project Management Committee that meets regularly to update progress and discuss what is working and adaptations being made with the community and how it is being made. • Facilitate a gender sensitive community feedback mechanism to receive feedback from the community and even partners. This feedback would be integrated in the reflection and review meetings to challenge each other to ensure quality service delivery. • In addition, support the adoption of the Community Score card, a Gender transformative MEAL tool that enables community to provide feedback to public services especially government. This will help them ensure the services Agro-parks being introduced meet the needs of the women in agribusiness.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: Instead of working with Women Led, I would explore working with training Agriculture and business institutions to scale this at the community. If the pilot is integrated within government learning institutions, they will expose the students to learning by doing through deploying student interns to implement the model. Students could use their theoretical knowledge to support communities while on the other hand gain hands-on-skills. These students may in the long run become the available resources if they come or stay in the communities or even when they move, they will scale up what they learnt. We can also design a module specifically for communities working with women’s groups and community facilitators. They will document the learning and integrate it to improve and scale out to other institutions in other regions while working with government especially with the alignment of the Agro parks strategy.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text:  Documentation of a step-by-step field learning that will involve the field staff, farmers and other community members where the farmers are. This will include experiences from women in agribusiness.  1-10days: Meet with the farmers who have been piloting the climate-smart, women-inclusive agribusiness. This will be done through their groups first, meet men and women together and then separately for triangulation and understand the experiences of women and men. This will involve documenting the learning from the farmers, understanding the opportunities and challenges for men and women farmers to inform adaptations.  11-15 days: Meet with selected households to listen to triangulate information from the FGDs and also have an indepth understanding  16-20 days: Work with the field staff who have been working with the farmers and also documenting their farmers. In all these, ensuring the experiences of women, men (while considering the intersectionality lens of age, disability and marital status). If the intersectionality lens was not factored in during implementation, this would inform the adaptations to be made in the scale up. This will also inform the review and development of key project indicators to trigger results in the scale-up.  21-25 days: Work with the technical team that supported the pilot to put together the learnings in a workable document. The key gaps from the pilot will be noted for further exploration in the scale-up. In the first 25 days, we would have a well-documented step-by-step learning process by farmers(men and women) which will be a reference guide for partners for any adaptation during scale-up. It is critical to have a standard document for reference so that any divergence is easily detected as an innovation for scale or major drift for improvement. Development of the pilot guide for each partner and location: In the next 55 days, the project team (Technical, MEAL and Gender) will have to develop a detailed implementation plan with strategies of delivering the scale up in their locations. In this discussion, target districts, sub-counties, parishes and villages will be identified with justification. We could have plan A(target districts) and plan (another district just in case the targeted district becomes complex due to any risk factor that may arise). Agree on the tools and models to be used to implement. MEAL design workshop(5 days): This will bring onboard all project partners and World Vision staff(MEAL, technical, Gender and Grants) to design what MEAL will look like for the project. During this processes, impact and reach target will be agreed on considering both direct and indirect. The indicators will be developed and monitoring tools. We shall also agree on the monitoring methods and period for instance monthly progress reports, quarterly joint monitoring, reflection and feedback meetings to be held among all the partners, quarterly reports and annual reports. Develop a needs assessment tools and deploy to inform the development and tool alignment. Technical and Gender planning: Based on the learnings, agree on the tools for implementation and key to note are tools that are transformative and engage both men and women in their diversities (youth, persons with disability). This can be guided tools that each partner has based on their technical expertise that they contribute in the partnership(Gender, markets, Financial Inclusion, Business management, digital, etc.) for adaptation. Technical (20 days): Develop training modules based on the learnings from Kujenga, if they have any manuals, we could adapt them and review to meet the current needs of farmers especially women in other regions. In this, gender will integrated as a key module or across all modules. The team will agree how they want the integration done based on guidance from a technical gender lens.Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?" During MEAL design workshop, partners may fail to agree on the key indicators or entry points. With all the suggestions, the team can agree to test the options in their regions and come back to agree on what can be adopted based on the feedback from the community.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: During the field visit, women could highlight their to work with private sectors especially off takers that offer better market opportunities and prices to share with them the different opportunities that could propel their agribusinesses to the global markets. During this conversation, have some successful women in agribusiness are likely to share their insights on how they were able to increase production working with other household members and/or by self and have grown and now earn more income. This could a few and they could be identified as mentors while encouraging other women who would like to learn from them to explore the business opportunities beyond their community by working together. Ensure the men in the lives of these women are part of the project, discussions to address their fears and explain how their support is critical for her and their household in increasing production and sales thus more income to realise their individual and family vision. I will engage the different actors as mentioned by some of the women and have an understanding on what they offer and their interest to support other women. They could be among the private sector actors that we could work with in scaling up the project. They could be our starting point.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: With the understanding of the project, I would meet with key people at the ministry who are responsible for this policy and discuss with them on the possibilities of aligning it within the project. The meeting is aimed at having an understanding on how this ould better rich the project design and implementation. The meeting will involve the technical team, gender(explore Gender integration beyond this policy alignment) and MEAL(how it feeds into the MEAL plan or how we can align). After that meeting, we shall update the project partners on the proposals and hear their opinion but also provide strategic guidance on why this is critical for sustainability and government scale-up. We shall also engage with Kujenga to understand the entry points, how we can foster collaboration and working with government. Convene a meeting with the line ministry on Agro Parks together with partners, Kujenga Farmers Network especially women in agribusiness. In this meeting, the conversation will on the alignment of the policy. Government will present their proposal and each partner will present what they are doing while Kijenga and the women will share their experience. They will agree on areas of adaptation and how and a road map for the alignment will be drawn jointly so that this happens and a documented aligned guideline is developed and roll-out.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Explore digital marketing with one of the identified private partner which will reduce on travel time, cost of hiring business premises and more time will be invested to increase production and have enough products for the wider market. This could be as a collective or as individuals much as i would encourage collective to have a stronger negotiation power. How will you judge it: Based on reports from women or partner on whether there has been increased sales, reduced business cost, access to more business opportunities.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: • Supply chain engagement- Kujenga Farmers’ Network and World Vision team Bi-monthly • MEAL learning-World Vision- Quarterly • Community liaison- Women farmers/ leaders- Monthly • Escalation path- partners and Kujenga Farmers Network and other implementing partners- Bi-annually

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: Outcome 1: Partnership and stakeholder engagement- Outcome 2: Reviewed technical approach of delivery Outcome 3: Monitoring, Reflection and Reporting Milestones:  Sign MOUs/agreement with 3 implementing partners and 1 learning partners who will participate in the process- Head of Institutions. This will be supported and followed closely by the Project Manager at World Vision.  Community Feedback mechanism has been established to ensure the voice of the women are included in the ongoing implementation.  Quarterly reflection, review and planning meeting  Establish a MEAL plan and data management  Reach out to 5,000 women farmers in the communities through the pilot. I will expose the slippery through the FAM and meeting with the Project Management Unit to help align implementation and learning.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Addressing social norms and barriers that women farmers and entrepreneurs face making it hard for them to break the ceiling and explore opportunities for growth and expansion. In this case, we will support the partners do a gender analysis and develop a gender Action Plan where the progress of implementation will be monitored and reported on. Another thing that is critical is the skills gap assessment among the women farmer so that it informs the mapping of actors- finance literacy, digital literacy skills, entrepreneurship, business management or technical areas. The complexity around linkages to market actors could see partners letting farmers market their products on their won thus increased losses and wastage rather than increased productivity and income that the women expect. To close this gap, adopt the government policy and work with industrial parks to skill the farmers on the aspects around good quality produce and products and also create market linkage. The second aspect is mapping the market actors in the districts who can offer the different service required by the women.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Let Go: Since it is not part of the design, rather than align with an "Agro-Industrial Parks" strategy, I would create linkage for them to work with the partners to ensure alignment for even future programmes. Government is very bureaucratic and can delay implementation yet the project could be time-bound. Stay: Integration of gender and MEAL: To ensure the women are actively engaging in the Value Chains/ market with service providers, barriers that limit them should be addressed and monitoring of progress in the women’s lives, household and business should be tracked to enable adaptation and learning. Evidence learning and decision making. If anything is to change or stay, it be based on data which MEAL provides from time to time..

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Agenda: Morning session: a) Introduction to the pilot b)Sharing learning from the previous pilot c) Technical presentation from MEAL and Gender that will inform adaptations. d) Grants to make presentation on donor and CARE guidelines- Non-negotiable, disallowable and payment processes. Mid-morning: Group discussion on what is workable and not workable in the pilot and why? How the partner would have delivered it in their way without diluting the model: 3 groups is as per partner. The technical team to move in all the 3 groups to listen and also provide technical input. Plenary: Partners to present Afternoon: Developing action plan by each partner, include Responsibility, Accountability, Consulted, Support and Informed (RACSI matrix). Output:  Clear implementation model define and documented to guide each partners(Allowable areas of flexibles and non-negotiables) agreed upon by all team members.  Tools for delivery and monitoring agreed on.  Actions agreed upon per partner to inform implementation and adaptation of the pilot.  RACSI matrix developed

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Ensure the Gender Action plan is integrated in the DIP, monitoring plan and progress reporting is done with support from MEAL. Align them to the project indicator matrix so that MEAL provides updates. The training modules will integrate gender as one of the key modules with all technical teams trained in Gender. Implement Gender transformative MEAL- using tools such as the community score card, engaging men in climate-smart agriculture, and conducting a gender analysis to inform programming. Ensure there is budget for Gender and MEAL within the project with key personnel for Gender and MEAL.

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text:  Shared leadership- Each partner will lead their implementation and will report based on their targets. The other team members will hold a partner failing others accountable and successes that shall be celebrated.  Co-implementation and reporting: Rather than police the partners, we develop the model together and agree on roles of each partner including CARE in the implementation. Even within the organisation, everyone’s contribution will be recognised.  Team spirit- Reflection and learning meetings.

question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: Co-owned- Decision on the implementation model. This will be done by the project management team who do day to day running of activities. Not approved: Overspending/ underspending vs achieved results. This will be done by heads of institutions.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text:  Updates on progress by partner including target realization through weekly meetings with core implementation team.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: 1. Number of women farmers reached and linked to markets- Partners 2. Number of women led private sector partners supported- World Vision/Partner 3. % increase in women’s income-World Vision/Partners

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text:  Work with MEAL to establish the exact achievement verses the target  Convene a meeting with the implementation team to discuss key emerging issues and challenges in achieving the milestone. Based on the issue, I will discuss them with the responsible people within the organisation and agree a joint meeting to discuss and find solutions.  This will be documenting with clear timelines to resolve the key issues- if delayed disbursement, recruitment, sick staff, limited technical support from World Vision etc. Agree on the date to review progress and have this on a weekly basis to ensure its resolved and the partner is able to move on.  If it persist, involve the partner management in the conversation to ensure they are resolved.

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text:  Participating in field technical support and ensuring I have first hand information on what is happening rather than speculations.  Engage with decision makers and keep a record of the actions from each meeting or discussions for follow up.  Next meeting or engagements starts from the previous actions. Those resolved-how they were resolve, the unresolved- what is pending and how can it be resolved.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text:  Should we implement gender as a stand-alone module or integrate it across all the activities that are being done?  How can we keep this work going with the limited resources?  How can we scale this to other regions? Whom should we engage?  At what point do we bring on board the different stakeholders to ensure the scale up is beyond our partnerships, regions and country?

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: Convene a meeting with key technical staff to understand what could have happened. If the issue is a capacity gap, provide a training for the team and review the gender action plan together to renew the commitment to implement or modify some of the actions.

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: Community mobilization being done by partner staff and have the groups are continuing to mobilize other farmers to form cooperative to aggregate their commodities, marketing together and also do value addition. When farmers start marketing together, it will be easier to mobilise others in the same value chain

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Costs/benefits: Local government that is responsible for implementing government programmes are supported to include in their annual plans and supported to work with the communities to implement the modified model that integrates components from the pilot and Agro-parks strategy. Equity implications: Defining roles of government, partners(Women led and private sector) and communities, especially the women farmers. Execution risks: The Government is bureaucratic and may not be willing to invest it. There could be risk associated with poor conceptualization of the agro-parks that could affect alignment. What's your call—and why? Government and project team should sit together and discuss how the alignment process. This should be done with input from women farmers and community because all team members must be on the same page.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text:  Gender, Age and disability (Intersectionality)- Implementing and learning- MEAL  Market access- Number of linkages created for women to access market and other services- Partners

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text:  From the onset of the project, partners will be part of the decision-making. They will agree on the model and how it will be adapted.  Ensure there is a project Management committee that regularly meets and discuss progress and issues arising for support and guidance from the team.  Promoting open communication and being honest with each other as well respect as core value. This will build trust among the partners

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text:  Document and share the learnings that informed the divergence. This should be discussed and agreed upon between the partner and World Vision with input and learnings from Kujenga

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: To keep Kujenga grassroot strong the following need to put into practice. Centralization of farmers voice, aligning systems and Act on principles ,sticking on women leadership in project designing and governance by ensuring empowerment not participation ,Institutianalization learning circles to local partners that may lead to innovation.final train the trainers.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: All roles and decision marking for local farmers and women leaders should be well defined and detailed in the TOR. Loal led activities and community learning platforms should be allocated budget to have impact at grassroot.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: Risks. Program decisions shift to partner will reduce. Due to cultural Norms women groups may be excluded in planning and budgeting .Preventing community voices from being sidelined.Form regional Partnership committees for work plan and Budgeting,Collecting feedback from community and implementing community scorecard that will bring the clear picture at the grassroot.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: Geographical expansion aiming at covering big operational Area and beneficiaries.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
