question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: the farmers must recognize that there is a challenge, a problem that affects farmers and hence the need to form the cooperative. they define the issues and agree on the best way to address this , mobilize around the issues and reflect on how they can bs=est address the issue. they can choose to learn from others on what options they took to address the same problem, invite expert knowledge to share what options exist . They can design a prototype that takes into consideration the challenges and test it out - asking the various stakeholders what they would like to get from the designed intervention, see how it comes together . In co-creating with the various stakeholders, they will be ble to take into consideration consumers needs, understand the fears , address the gaps and propose a prototype. they can get back to the field and test this, and understanding whether it would address the different needs, finanlise and test it. they are them able to popularise this and get the processes, systems tested, intergrate feedback and continue to design incrementally against a designed prototype, allowing for failing, adapting and redesigning until a protype is designed.

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: Non-Negotiables - These can include World Vision Core Values or key aspects which world vision stands for that apply to the partners of world vision. 1. Faith i.e. ensuring KUJENGA staff serve all people in the community without segregating them based on faith backgrounds or religion but serve all religions equally. 2. Integrity- the staff of KUJENGA should ensure high level discipline, respect for the people and ensure grassroot accountability, and transparency, this includes accounting to the community members. 3. Inclusion- Where KUJENGA staff should be capacitated to ensure inclusivity while doing work, be supported to identify issues affecting all community members including children, youth, women, men, people with disability, refugees and align the project being scaled to ensure it provide solutions that address the challenges affecting vulnerable categories in the community. WHERE TO FLEX 1. Decision making -Ensure that Stakeholders and community members participate in decision making for specific interventions where necessary. 2. Culture -Every organization has its own culture but it’s important for world vision to support KUJENGA staff to be able to understand the cultural values of Teso, Karamoja and Busoga and be flexible enough to fit into those communities for people to easily own and participate in the project activities. 3. Partnership -KUJENGA Farmers network would be advised to collaborate with local partners in the areas of operation based on their vision and goal but also the world vision goal. KUJENGA has to get right partners to work with in relation to the project needs, those that add value to the project and both parties involved.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: Some risks may include the following. 1.Fraud -Over indexing partners may mean giving them higher targets to achieve while executing work, this may cause the partner to provide poor quality work but be forced to account for the same resources in order to meet the higher targets prioritized. 2. Micromanagement and Conflict between the Funding partner and Partner staff. -The Funding partner may end up micromanaging the formal partner because of pressure that may arise from failing to meet the project targets and can end up conflicting instead of cooperating and capacity sharing. 3. Health issues -Staff of the partner can develop stress at work in trying to struggle to higher targets that are not realistic based on the contexts they are operating in. Safeguarding Community voices would require the following. 1. Community engagement meetings and dialogues -Organize community meetings together with partners to ensure feedback is captured openly and responses provided back. 2. Design and share external feedback capturing tools which are accessible to management for review , and ensure action is done based on the nature of feedback coming to the organization.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: I would choose to trade local capacity building, i.e. invest in organizational capacity strengthening where capacity is developed with local communities based on context. Why -This is enables funding organizations to support systems strengthening at partner level and enable them qualify for the funding that would be provided to them in a locally led perspective, Local organizations lack systems related to Human resource, Finance management, Procurement, Gender and Safeguarding policies , administration, Monitoring and Evaluation including Feedback and accountability mechanisms , therefore investing in first building their capacity and supporting them to improve their management systems would prepare them to fit into the locally led initiatives .

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: Objective: Understand the challenges faced by 20 women led organizations in Tooro Region during business formalization processes Week 1-2 -14 days -Conduct meetings with women leaders and conduct interviews with key stakeholders involved in business formalization. Ensure interview notes are taken detailing the challenges, take photos of meetings and acquire evidence of the processes e.g. certificates, ensure meetings with the data team are held to discuss feedback and observations. Week 3-4 (15-28 days) : Do data analysis, listen to the interview audios, review literature and do further engagements with stakeholders to ensure proper data is captured, ensure first draft report is generated and engage with the women to discuss the findings and validate them Week 5.6 (29-42 days: Validation of the findings will be done and reflection with the team, reflection report will be developed and action plans for the women developed and final presentations made to the women to ensure adoption of proposed recommendations Week 7-8 (43-60 days): Implementation and follow up will be done, ensuring that the proposed solutions are put into action, orient the women to adopt the changes, if possible, Progress report will be generated, Review meetings with women will be organized to document lessons learnt. Signal: Women need to be brough closer and collaborate with formalization bodies especially URSB. Change: Formalization bodies should reduce bureaucracies that hinder women from accessing their premises for guidance and advice Development partners should Prioritize supporting women entrepreneurs to formalize their businesses so that they are too much bureaucracy involved are managed before.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: INTEGRATING GENDER TRANSFORMATIVE, PROJECTS IMPACT AND LEARNING WORKSHOP SCHEULED TO TAKE PLACE IN FORTPORTAL AA HOTEL ON 15TH DEC 2025. Proposed Agenda 8:00 to 9:30am: Arrival, Registration, Welcomes, Objectives, Expectations and Agenda Review: Led by Moderator /Convenor 9:30-10:30am: Review of Gender Transformative Approaches used by World Vision and how they can be used by Partners -Led by the Gender Advisor 10:30am-11:00am: Break tea -By the Hotel 11:00am to 12:00pm; Review of the Project Targets, Indicators and impact by MEAL Advisor. 12:00-01:00pm: Q & A for Session One and Two and Discussions 01:00-02:00am -Lunch Break: By the Hotel 02:00-03:00pm-Proejct implementation and Operational Support -Guidelines and Procedures -By Grants Manager or Coordinator 03:00-04:00pm: Review of the MEAL the Projects MEAL Framework and Learning Agenda Reflections and Reporting Guidelines: By MEAL Advisor. 04:00-05: Action plan development and Way Forward: Projects Advisor or Project Lead 05:00-05:30pm: Administration, Groups Photo and Departure at Leisure. Outputs Expected  Proper understanding and harmonized understanding of gender transportive approaches and tools to be used during project implementation.  Aligned grants and operations processes i.e. finance, procurement and administration of the project.  Defined partnership targets and impact pathways  Defined action plan for project implementation with defined roles and responsivities.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Integrating gender lenses from the start of the project i.e. Mainstream gender in MEAL Indicators eg ensure gender disaggregated data is captured, Involve the gender specialists and advisors in MEAL designs to align the project objectives, Build capacity of MEAL teams on gender sensitive documentation and analysis and Ensure to capture gender responsive feedback.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: What must be asked 1) What is the progress of the project based on the objectives and outcome areas 2) What were the challenges affecting partners or What did not work in the last quarter 3) What worked well or what are the best project practices and lessons learnt 4) How are the resources being utilized (Budget and utilization rate 5) How has partnership contributed to the partner objectives, vision and mission Converted Answers.  Priorities for the next quarter defined  Redefined roles and responsibilities for the partner  Documented best practice and lessons learnt, what works better for the project  Best approaches and strategies documented that work well for the partners  Agreed action plan for the next quarter

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text:  Will have enough time to listen to the partners or stakeholders sharing the negative findings  Maintain high level of confidentiality and safeguard those sharing the negative finding so more information can be acquired  I will not blame the person sharing findings but provide sufficient time to discuss the findings, understand them better and ask for any ideas or proposals for improvement or get some opinions.  Give an apology to the stakeholders or partners on behalf and explain to them why some things are done they way they are done but inform them about the organizational guidelines and value and where necessary will inform my supervisor or colleagues that are involved so that some negatives are avoided .

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text:  Reduce spending money on non-impactful meetings and workshops so that resources are used to do groundwork at community level  Leverage of existing resources (Staff, assets, workspaces, partnerships etc to deliver meaningful work.  Give staff targets to all be involved in resource mobilization activities so that more projects are attracted to increase funding for the organization

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Agro industrial parks are as well-known as common user facilities established by governments to support Micro and Small-scale Entrepreneurs to access space for production especially those into processing, they bring together innovators and technology owners together for easy access by entrepreneurs, Enable linkages to strategic business partners especially standard bodies like UNBS and , Enable access to business coaching and mentorship services and enable growth of small businesses thus very important for job and employment creation. Would call upon Development partners including CARE Uganda to start investing in supporting establishment of industrial parks and link women Entrepreneurs to those parks for expanded business growth in order to contribute to job and employment creation.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text:  Need to confirm the number of households members reached by the project with evidence from the MEAL team  Number of women that have increased income due to project participation.  Number of women adopting climate agriculture technologies with evidence from MEAL team. Failure to have the above Data will cause to write a report that does not include impact numbers needed for donor report and will limit resource mobilization, A report without data makes it hard to determine the level of effort, investment and impact per dollar

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: 1. Call partner meetings. Would start by Calling a meeting with the partners Management staff and discuss with them the progress made and appreciate them for the good work, during the meeting I will ask them to share their feelings about the current situation for example unpredictable donor land scape and what plans to they have for their organizations and staff, this well help to understand the partner interests and priorities . 2. Share experience with partners about the effects of the current situation of the donor landscape and ask for reactions to what will be shared, ask partners to give ideas on what they think can work better for them and my organization like CARE. 3. Building the above conversation, I will introduce the hard tradeoff, for example of reducing the partner budget by 20%, will go deeper to provide them with the context why it has to be done but reflect together on the implications it will have on the project and agree on the strategy of managing the implications. 4. Follow up will be made to capture feedback and understand the partner’s feelings about the hard trade off but create time to keep the conversations to ensure clarity and guidance is provided in relation.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: When Regions Merge, the following are the Key rules that keep Coherence  Defined roles and responsibilities of the teams from both regions with clearly defined goals and objectives.  Harmonized policies and guidelines /operational guidelines must be uniform to ensure the merger speaks to both objectives.  Standardized communication and visibility, Branding and visibility materials must be standardized so that uniform communication is shared with stakeholders.  Staff and partner briefing must be done to orient them about the merger and provide detailed explanation about the reasons for merging.  Maintain the organizational core values by both staff and partners under the merger

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: A big percentage of farmers depend on rain to do agriculture, with the impact of climate change the rains are no-longer predictable making it different when to plant. The Climate-smart, Women-inclusive agribusiness pilot has been successful in Serere and therefore should be scaled to other areas that are equally dealing with the effects of climate change. If we are to eradicate poverty, we must end hunger and economically empower households, one family at a time, one village at a time and one district at a time. The people that are most affected with issues of hunger and household incomes are the women; therefore this project should focus on including women in the programming. Without dismissing the challenges of keeping the project at the grass roots, to meet the actual need of the community, the closer we are to the target population, the more impact the project will have at a lesser cost.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: We need to hard-wire local leadership by making sure that there are activities that are included in the ToRs that will be implemented with the local leadership. These activities should be included in the budgets with clear budget lines.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: Over indexing on formal partners, we will miss out on the authenticity that comes with the informal partners. The informal partners often come from the community solving a real problem close to home. The formal partners also have a lot of bureaucracy, structures making decision making a lot more complex. To prevent community voice from being sidelined, it is important to involve the voice right from the design stage, also involve the community structures during the monitoring and evaluation of the projects.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: I would trade increasing the number of partners we work with, i would rather have an acceptable number to work with instead of very many. This is not about the budget transfer but the numbers. A selected number across all our thematic areas, by this there will be deeper capacity sharing and knowledge transfer.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: Month 1: Farmer Engagement: • Visit farmers observing the way they work. Listening to their stories. Take note of the challenges and any opportunities. • Categorise the farmers mainly focusing on the women, perhaps the youth. • Ask them about in-puts, easy it is to access and how they connect to the market • How have their lives changes over the project. Visit different groups per week, write a summary of opportunities, challenges, input and out- put linkages. Month 2: Community and Market engagement Week 1 and 2: Community Engagement: • Have structured questions to gauge: • Do they know about the project and what it is about – objectives, targets, budget- et all • Have they been involved in the implementation and monitoring of the project • What impact has the project hard in the community- sharing aby stories • What challenges have been experienced • What opportunities are there? Meet all the community structures, like the group leaders, Village leader and the district leadership. Week 3: Markets Engagement • How easy is it to access quality inputs at affordable prices. Are the farmers in organised groups? • Produce markets: What is the quality of the output? How reliable is the output? • How can the markets be improved? Week 4: • Consolidate information from the farmers, community and the market. • Come up with a dashboard indicating the key areas of opportunities, challenges and improvement. What would trigger a design sprint, if the focus of women has been lost and if the groups market linkages are failing. I would go back to re-organise the groups and make sure the women are well represented and have voice.

Milestones: • Fully mapped input suppliers in each the districts • A map on how the farmers will be grouped per location • Fully mapped potential buyers indicating what produce they are interested in. MEAL learning is owned by the PQL lead at world vision - James P Milestones: • Developed and approved indicators taking care of Gender involvement and climate smart initiatives. • FAM framework developed and circulated. • Community liaison is owned by Kujenga Farmer’s Network leader – Paul N Milestone: • A map on how the farmers will be grouped per location

text: 3 outcomes • Clear Market Pathway Established – Input suppliers, farmer groups, and buyers fully mapped. • MEAL structures operational: Indicators and FAM framework. • Delivery Model – partner led, women inclusive, climate-smart model replicated 5 milestones and owners, • Gender & climate-smart indicators approved (Owner: James P.). • Input supplier map completed (Owner: Paul N., Support: Pauline N.). • Farmer grouping map validated (Owner: Paul N.). • Buyer mapping completed (Owner: Paul N., Support: Pauline N.). • Field-first learning loop fully active (Owner: James P.) Decision gates: • Farmer groups do not include women • The climate change indicators are negative • Community structures are not involved in the implementation and monitoring of the project. • Feedback received is not followed through for closure. Spillage will be exposed early from the monthly review of the indicators and from the feedback received through the FAM.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: The discussion should involve the partner project manager and their senior management specifically the head of the organisation. You have missed 2 milestones regardless of the reminders, we are here to understand the challenge and come up with solutions The project milestones are clear and are time bound a delay in one will impact the timelines of the rest of the milestones and hence the timely implementation of the project. I will pass this over to you to hear what the challenge gas been and your intended solutions. Depending on the response: Identify where the accountability lies and hold them responsible. If it is a staff or is it the partner. If staff demand that they are held responsible. If they are organisational challenges and can be fixed, devise solutions ND A TRACKING mechanism. If they cannot be fixed, consider termination. Generally before you even call the meeting be sure we are not the ones frustrating the partner!.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Aligning with the Ministry's Agro-Parks put the farmers to connect with national priorities and will benefit with the available resources like trainings and the government organised market linkages, however the focus on the community interests and women inclusion will be lost in the bureaucracy and the grand plan. Protecting the grass root focus, will keep the community interests while including the women at the Center. To address the real community problem the grass root focus is the way to go. My call will be to design a project that is dual, aligns with the ministry agro parks while keeping the grassroots, so the benefits of both are experienced.

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: To scale the project to Teso, Karamoja and Busoga, I will need to first conduct field assessment to learn local contexts in the new locations and engage with local leaders, technical staff at district and sub-county levels and key community members. Additionally, I need to map Women-Led local Agencies who are engaged in climate-smart, women-inclusive agribusiness for possible partnership. Hence this approach will help me to scale the project in the mentioned districts in partnership with Local Women led NGOs that will work with Kujenga Farmers Network instead of replacing them and their ideas. The non-negotiables and where I 'd flex are; 1) implementation through local women-led agencies, gender integration/inclusion, engagement of grassroot organizations for instance Kujenga farmers network, involvement of farmers in the design and scale up, alignment of the project to government priorities, Kujenga principles and approaches should not be changed with seeking their opinions

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: 1) All TORs with the partners should include the roles, responsibilities and mandate of Kujanga and fund should be allocated to them to perform their roles in all the 3 districts 2) The Local NGOs should mainly support the initiative without diluting Kujenga model

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: • Reduced involvement and participation of project participants/farmers networks in the project resulting in community voices not being hard. Mitigation measures would be intentional involvement of project participants/farmers networks in project design, planning, implementation and M&E. Ensure that project governance structures have representatives of community members/farmers networks. This should be a provision in Partners ‘contracts • Livelihoods that gender integration and inclusion may reduced. Mitigation measures should include training of staff in GED and Gender inclusion and promotion know gender tools like GALS and EMB methodologies among partners. For accountability, this should be included in partners’ contracts. • Formal partners may implement their ideas and models best known to them rather scaling Kujenga approach. Mitigation measures are regular field monitoring by CARE technical leads, institution quarterly reflection and project review meetings • Late/delayed accountability and reporting by partners: Mitigation measures may include provision of in-house financial management and accountability training to partner staff, quarterly compliance checks by CARE, have reporting deadlines for all the reports. These should be included in the contracts for accountability. • Delay in implementation of activities by partners. Mitigation measures may include regular monitoring by Technical Lead, institution of weekly updates by technical lead, monthly and quarterly project review meeting • Burn rate issues: Mitigation measures may include monthly review of burn rates with partners staff including their senior management team

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: If I must trade one ambition, I would trade urgency in implementation. This is because locally led implementation approach takes time and requires mutual understanding and agreement between the two organizations and it requires learning. Secondly donor and other stakeholders prefer quality implementations that are anchored on following policies, guidelines and regulation. A rush in implementation may compromise integrity.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: First, learning starts will knowledge acquisition, application, feedback and reflection. To design a field learning loop for the next 60 days, I will start by exploring the community where learning will happen, that is understanding their current situations and needs and their local knowledge. I will then develop the knowledge product (prototypes) in consultation with community and test the knowledge protect in the community as well as get feedback from them for refinement. Finally, I review the product with different stakeholders for improvement before the launch. The signal that triggers a design sprint are the problems or challenges being faced by community. It is important that you come with an action based on the problems being faced by community otherwise you may not succeed. The first think to change is the community mindsets and perception.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: For instance, HQ assumptions women’s groups will restore depredated a project through tree planting and the groups’ leaders will exclusively be women themselves. The decision on which tree species to plant will be by group members who are women. What I expect that might contradict the assumptions of HQ are; women’s land rights regarding land ownership may limit their meaning participation, women may not directly decide on the tree species to planted even they have access to the land and the aspiration that the groups’ leadership should exclusively be women may not be realised. I would surface and act on these by engaging local leaders and clan leaders to sensitize community leaders on women land right and decision making. I will also engagement and boys in the project through gender

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: To balance policy alignment with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’, I will first conduct analysis of different government policies relevant to the action to generate an understands of the different policies and policy gaps that do exist. I will also conduct engagement meetings with policies implementers (government stakeholders and other stakeholders). Then ensure relevant policies are integrated in the project during project design and planning.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: I would customize CARE’ s VSLA methodology to include an innovative new saving product for women farmers to acquire smart phones called “women’s market information”. The savings is never borrowed or withdrawn until it is enough for the savers to buy smart phones. CARE will work with a digital service provider to train and upload an app that provides agricultural market information to the farmers. I will judge it acceptability by holding feedback meetings with groups members. Because time limitation, the innovation will be tested with 2 VSLA groups in the project area.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Supply-chain Management: would think it is managed by Procurement and Logistic Department. However, it is very critical that program team who are the initiators of procurements should as well part and parcel of procurement management. Milestone is number of procurements executed. MEAL learning: owned by MEAL team heading by PQL Manager. However, MEAL functions is as well a routine role of Project team, and this include financial management monitoring headed finance department. It is everybody’s responsibility. Milestone is number of monitoring visits Community Liaison: owned by program team including SMT. Milestones is number community meetings Escalation Paths: By everyone and milestone is number of escalation

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: Outcomes 1 and milestones: Facilitating project team with resources needed to implement the project (Strengthening supply chain) • Procurement planning by project team headed by the manager. • Sourcing of suppliers- Headed by Procurement Department with assistance of the project team. The project team provides specifications of the goods and services they require. The Lead is always the IMs. Sourcing includes all the procurement processes up to close of contract. Outcome 2 and milestones: MEAL systems and plans strengthened and effectively functioning. • Conduct baselines surveys to inform decisions to know the strengthen and weakness in the MEAL Department. • Develop meal plan, tools and system based on the baseline assessment and based on the gaps identified. • Seek approval of MEAL tools by SMT and provide training to the project team and partners. • Roll out implementation Outcome 3 and milestones: Project stakeholders are effectively engaged. • Inception meetings with relevant stakeholders to explain the project initiatives. • Involvement of the stakeholder in all stages of the project cycles Project owner: The first and main project owners are the Project participants, Local and Central Government leadership, the donor and the leadership of the NGO implementing the action. However, the owners are basically the project participants and the government. Decision Gates: • Seek opinions of Resilient Futures Program Manager, Operation Director, PD Diector and PQL Manager on the possibilities of continuing with the project implementation or alter or stop the project. I need to have justification for altering, pause and discontinue implementation • Meeting with CD and senior team to seek approval if and change or changes are to be made. • In case of any change call for meeting will all stakeholders including the final beneficiaries

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Livelihood of handoff failure between partners • Not understanding of roles and what should be delivered each partner • Delayed implementation of activities • Late reporting resulting to burn rate issues Artifact I will introduce are • RACI to define everybody roles and responsibilities. • Weekly meeting. • Introduce performance tracker for all the staff • Monthly field monitoring. • Quarterly review meetings

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: I would drop weekly meeting. The weekly meeting, it is time consuming and very little is going to be reported within a week. I would drop monthly monitoring visits for quarterly visits because it increases project cost and reduces on implementation time.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Goal: To identify and clarify roles and responsibilities of each sector (MEAL, Grant, OPs, Gender and Partners) for project delivery. Agenda: Opening remark by DP, Remark by the Technical Lead and stating the objective of workshop, presentation of roles of each sector by DP and overview of the project by the technical lead. Outputs: Roles and responsibilities of each sector defined, Better understanding of the project by all.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: • Roles and responsibilities definitions of everybody and each one should be assigned a specific role • Clear work plan and what needs to be delivered and when. Approximation of resources required should be stated. • Clear definition of deadlines • Reprimand nonperformers and ensure strict enforcement of compliance. • Clarity in outputs and activities. I will publish implementation updates based on the monthly and weekly work plans and commitment.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: The dashboard will include • % of project initiatives handed over to communities by partner manager. • # of milestones completed by implementing partner headed by the manager. • # of MEAL engagement conducted and adaptive actions implemented by CARE MEAL Department and Partner MEAL team. Escalation rule if a metric turns red: • Inform the project manager and all the staff implementing the project and discuss how to bring on track the off- track activities. • Participatorily develop a plan to fast- track implementation to bring the project on track. • Monitor the fast-tracking plan. • Take management decision if the plan is not being implemented

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: • Have the facts regarding the milestones missed, clearly state to the project team and management of the partners the risk associated with missing the milestone (e.g. discontinuation of the contract, reputational damage among others) and history of the partners performances. • Recover conversation and decision with the partners will include but not limited to the following: evident, what caused the delay and analysis of the reasons provided, development of recovery plan and monitoring implementation of the plan Decision options: Might include be limited to the following. Provide improvement plan for three months, withdraw implementation of critical activities and hire a consultant to implement those activities. If the improvement plan is not implemented within 3 months, discontinue the contract and consider options of either engaging a new local partner, consultants or direct implementation

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: • Partners should provide written updates on Friday if the meeting is scheduled on a Monday of the following week. This will provide time for the technical to validate the information reported. • Restrict the time each partner should present their update. Preferable 10 minutes to 15 minutes. • For every meeting, come up with action points clearly indication who is responsible for each action point and when they should be implemented. Review implementation of each action point in the next meeting. • With the support of the MEAL team, develop performance tracker for implementation of key indicators. This tool should be used during the update meeting. • Escalate if the underperformance persist and you think undermine achievement of the project goal and objectives.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: What is the % of achievement against planned target, what are the success factors for activities with high level of performance? What contributed to underperformance for activities that were not implemented within the timeframe and how can we improve moving forward? What are the key lessons learned and implementation challenges. How is the partnership between the local NGOs and CARE being managed? What are risk compliance issues that emerged during the implementation and how did you address them. Based on the responses, I would revise the workplan, budget and implementation strategies to respond to the new needs and problems because of learnings (Adaptation). There will be need to update MEAL system and risk register.

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: Firstly, I will investigate the reason for the negative finding, sit with partners staff and management to jointly propose solutions to address the problems and demystify the negative finding and come up with corrective action. Develop a plan, implement the plan and get feedback if there still negative feedback or there is an improvement.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?

This trade-off will allow the grassroot partners time to grow in their capacity under less pressure which in return will lead to achieving the regional expansion goal while achieving the government initiatives as well.

In this case, collect data from the women in the bi-weekly meetings to understand their challenges - and quickly adapt training sessions to mitigate. Allocate budget for childcare support during the training.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: I’d start by acknowledging the missed milestones and asking the partner to explain root causes—whether resource gaps, unclear roles, or competing priorities. Then, reaffirm non-negotiables like gender integrity, and co-create a recovery plan with clear actions, owners, and weekly check-ins. If recovery seems feasible, we proceed with support; if not, we consider scope adjustment or conditional continuation with strict decision gates. Persistent failure triggers escalation to the Steering Committee for reallocation or exit within 30 days

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: To prevent “update theatre” and keep meetings decisional, share all status updates through emails or dashboards before the meeting, and structure the agenda around specific decisions or questions that need resolution. Clearly state the meeting’s purpose, assign a facilitator to keep discussions focused, and redirect any off-track updates by asking, “What decision do we need to make based on this?” End every meeting by documenting decisions, action items, and owners to ensure accountability and clarity.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: To set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners, I will focus on asking questions that review performance and strengthen collaboration, such as: What worked well this quarter? Where did we face challenges and why? What changes are needed in roles, timelines, or processes? How satisfied are you with communication and support? After gathering responses, I will prioritize actionable items, draft a Change Action Plan summarizing agreed adjustments with clear responsibilities and deadlines, and formalize these through a signed addendum or action memo to ensure accountability and alignment moving forward.

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: I will acknowledge the finding transparently, share data openly, and invite partners to co-analyze root causes. Together, we’ll agree on corrective actions and document them in a signed plan.

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: Next quarter, I will stop hosting redundant status-update meetings and reduce low-impact reporting tasks, freeing time and resources to fund adaptive strategies that strengthen collaboration and improve program outcomes.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Adopt a hybrid approach: invest in Agro-Parks for scale and market access while earmarking funds for smallholder integration. Benefits: efficiency and competitiveness; risks: exclusion and coordination challenges. Equity safeguards—quotas and training—mitigate risks. My call: hybrid ensures growth without sacrificing grassroots resilience and inclusivity.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: I need updated Agro-Park cost projections from the Ministry and smallholder participation rates from regional partners. If they don’t arrive, fallback is using last quarter’s data with sensitivity analysis for decision-making.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: I’ll communicate the trade-off transparently, share data and rationale early, invite feedback, and document concerns. Framing it as a collective decision process ensures partners feel heard, respected, and valued—even amid disagreement.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: Allocate fixed budget ranges per region while allowing discretionary spending within those bands for context-specific initiatives.

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: Nonnegotiable strategies would include: Strategic realignment is required for Kujenga farmers Network to articulate its strategic direction which spells out its pathways for scaling up its impact and as well as engaging in strategic partnerships at the local and regional levels and align its choice of actions and partnerships to its new strategic direction. Secondly, Stakeholder analysis is very critical to redefine new strategic partnerships and key stakeholders to be included in the scaleup processes including stakeholder engagement and consultations. Realignment to existing Government, national, regional and local/district and sector policies, systems, frameworks and local action plans such as the AGRO industrial Park strategy to ensure relevancy and effectiveness of the course of action and actions for scaling up. Adopt a gender Transformative MEAL System that ensures participatory approaches and a gender lens in all the processes of program/project designs, results definition, measurement among others which recognizes participation of all people including women and girls men and boys, persons with disabilities and other vulnerable categories that will be affected by the program to ensure coherence, efficiency, relevancy, effectiveness and impact in the course of action. Conduct primary and secondary research for contextual analysis, gender analysis and program alignment of activities to respond to the pressing needs of the different people (disaggregated by age, gender, disability) in the different program locations for scale. conduct Risk assessment/analysis and design mitigation strategies. I would Flex on conducting Organizations SWOT analysis that would enable Kujenga to identify its weaknesses and threats as well as capitalize on its strengths and opportunities to address the weaknesses. Improving Coordination mechanisms, feedback, putting in place feedback and accountability mechanisms as well as Adaptive management and Learning approaches.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: Globally, there has been a shift in the donor funding space with an overarching need for INGO and NGOs to shift power, decision making/leadership and resources to local and national partners as well as increase collaboration with government and local leadership structures to ensure sustainability of development and humanitarian interventions as well as to increase impact in the community especially for the most vulnerable persons including women and girls. Therefore, to align with this global demand and reposition the organization/institution to increase its relevance, impact and increase/maintain its funding portfolio as a prefered and trusted organization by donors, the localization agenda must be adopted to shift power, leadership and resources for project management and implementation, while maintaining the oversight roles and technical Capacity transformation for the partners.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: Over indexing on Formal partners may lead to risks such as, misalignment of strategies and program interventions with community needs, leading to irrelevance and uninformed decisions, targeting wrong people for specific interventions, Fraud and mismanagement of funds, institutional abuse and damage, limited visibility and presence for the organization, limited impact, Lack of accountability to the impact groups, Lack of ownership and Limited sustainability of interventions, no shared responsibility and resources thus low efficiency, lack of program quality in terms of gender equality and inclusion in all aspects, among others. Safeguards would include standardizing stakeholder engagement and partnership processes, including a stakeholder management and partnership strategy, stakeholder analysis, Stakeholder and partnership engagement plan, define and strengthen Program quality principles to include accountability mechanisms where community voice is streamlined and gender equality and inclusion is institutionalized across programs.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: I would trade non; this is because taking locally led to scale requires a comprehensive and intentional shift in organizational systems and processes of which all ambitions for locally led approaches such as empowering local and national actors through shifting power, resources and finances, capacity strengthening among others should be strengthened to bring about sustainability, inclusiveness and effectiveness of the development and humanitarian impact to the impact groups.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: Using the scenario given above, a field-first learning loop to be undertaken in 60 days will involve a five phased learning approach which will include both primary and secondary sources of information with an aim of prioritizing grassroot voices, experiences and decisions. The first phase will include field learning visits to conduct surveys such as market assessments and Focused Group discussions and interactions with communities especially selected women farmers, local leadership and Government stakeholders such as the extension workers, Kujenga field officers, and other NGO and CBO partners involved in the scale up or in similar work as primary sources. The purpose of the primary sources of information will be capturing and observing live experiences from farmers engagements, risks, operational challenges and experiences related to gender integration and inclusion for all people especially the women and girls in the 3 districts of Teso, Karamoja and Busoga districts regarding the pilot and scale up of climate smart, women inclusive agribusiness. Learning events/ meetings will be conduct on a monthly basis with key stakeholders as key sources of information including Local and government actors such as extension workers, Community Development officers, Community social service officers, women farmer group leaders, to share learning and experiences on alignments with district and national sector priorities including the Agro-Industrial Park strategy, Market Actors will also be involved in the reflections to share learning regarding the changes in the demand, supply of agribusiness commodities, demand and pricing shifts. The third phase would be to triangulate, synthesis and conceptualize all the information generating to come up with key learning thematic areas and develop learning products to influence decision making and triggers for design sprints. The fourth Phase will be making use of the learning products and information to apply and integrate it in major adaptations for scaling up, trigger new designs or realign the ongoing design approaches including a design sprint. The last Phase will be to institutionalize and strengthen Feedback and accountability mechanisms for continuous learning and adaptations during the scale up. The Cadence for a field first learning loop would include weekly checkin meetings with kujenga's farmers network leadership, monthly short surveys with all key stakeholders, including the women famers, extension workers, field officers, etc. Quarterly learning and coordination meetings with all key players including market actors, district and government leadership, sector leads, CSOs and CBOs, Famer groups, extension workers among others for cross learning and develop quarterly or annual learning briefs or papers visualizing critical issues for adaptations and learning insights on best practices. Artifacts would include a learning agenda with key learning questions, learning metrics with clear indicators for measuring gender inclusion for all people especially women and girls, level of satisfaction, and alignment to key standards. Learning briefs/papers will be good artifacts to visualize what wors and what does not work in the scale up as well as suggested strategies for quality improvement. Lastly the triggers for a design sprint would include low performance against sectoral indicators and set targets across the implementing partners in the 3 districts, Diluted gender lens during implementation, Misalignment with sectoral targets and priorities including the Agro Industrial Park strategy, and major executional challenges causing role conflicts among implementors. I would first make changes in regard to role clarity amongst all key players including Kujenga network, clearly defining the organizations structures and information flow charts with key stakeholders mapped and aligned to the specific roles and well-defined decision-making points. Secondly a MEAL redesign will be very critical to adapt to the gender transformative MEAL processes were participation of all people is prioritized and a gender lens is integrated across the program cycle from design stage to implementation, MEAL and program closure, specifically gender specific activities, indicators and approaches are aligned into the program to incorporate a gender lens in all the processes.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: While scaling up a Climate-Smart Women-inclusive Agribusiness Pilot, the HQ assumption would have been to economically empower women by increasing their participation in climate smart agribusiness and adopting the agro-industrial park strategy were high value cash crops like coffee, sugarcane and sunflower especially in Teso and busoga are encouraged for farmers to invest in, however the women's groups may have a divergent insight on this assumption due to the high levels of malnutrition caused by food insecurity in the 3 regions, and thus they may believe that investing in high value cash crops alone would worsen the situation of food insecurity and increase malnutrition which could lead to death/life loss. Therefore, a section of women groups would be to be resistant and may not be willing to invest in high value cash crops as per the HQs assumption and would instead invest in nutritious food crops like millet, sorghum, bananas, while others in the high value cash crops like coffee, sunflower and sugar cane for improved livelihoods and boast nutrition at the same time. Given that this insight may affect the program design and limit achievement of project objectives, impact and results, it requires an informed and evidence-based project redesign, thus I would convene a meeting with key stakeholders including Kujenga leaders, women farmers leaders, MEAL staff from partners, government and district leadership, extension workers among others to review the project results framework, Theory of Change, indicators, targets as well as project activities to align them to the needs of the community by integrating both high value cash crops with food security crops and include results of economic empowerment as well as for food security and nutrition in order to ensure relevance and effectiveness of the project interventions and for increase impact. Secondly, I would adjust the Project indicators and results framework accordingly to ensure that they measure both results on nutrition and income enhancement. Lastly, I would communicate the adaptations to the project design to all relevant stakeholders including the HQ and PMU explaining all the processes undertaken, the insights, the proposed changes/adaptations and the rationale for the adaptations who would then approve the changes recommended and communicate upwards to the donors and relevant stakeholders including the community members, women farmer groups and kujenga leaders.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: Right from inception of the project design or redesign, I will develop a project framework paper/concept /strategy documenting the key pathways of scale clearly documenting the non-negotiables as core principles that will govern/guide the scale up, integration, partnerships, MEAL designs, research and implementation which will include key aspects of the policy alignment with existing national, local and sectoral frameworks such as the Ago-Park strategy to ensure coherence and relevance of the interventions, adoption of climate smart practices/businesses as part of the key results with clear indicators to measure impact and sustainability, strengthened community participation and involvement through accountability channels by maintaining the field-first learning loop as a critical pathway for learning, adaptation and scaling up interventions facilitated by informed decision making processes and lastly gender inclusion and integration as a key quality pillar for the scale up, that will ensure Gender Transformative MEAL processes are adopted and implementation with a gender lens to ensure delivery of a gender transformative program that builds the agency of all people especially the women and girls, strengthens relations at house hold level and community as well as transforms structures to address all negative norms, policies and practices that limit the attainment of development goals. I will then use the approved framework/guidelines to align the program according to the stated standards, including conducting stakeholder engagement with national and local government sector leads on policy frameworks especially the agro-industrial park strategy and the integration of Kujenga's model for scaling up, while positioning the climate smart women inclusive agri-business model by Kujenga at the center of integration. Secondly, I will institutionalize community participation in the process by forming coordination committees and working groups spearheaded by the grassroot actors such as the women farmer leaders, Kujenga staff, local leaders, government leaders, extension workers and other CSOs to steer the activity cocreation, implementation and learning processes. I will then conduct a joint MEAL redesign where key results including for gender inclusion and climate smart results, performance indicators, targets, will be agreed upon to continuously track performance, gender integration and the alignment with sectoral targets and indicators in general. I will budget, plan for and conduct participatory monitoring, evaluation and learning processes and maintain a program quality field footprint including monitoring and learning field visits, monthly online coordination meetings, quarterly review meetings with all stakeholders, mixed methods periodical studies or evaluations to measure progress against results and indicator targets, document participant most significant change stories, generate feedback, learning and apply adaptive management as well as informed decision making. I will also strengthen the Feedback and Accountability channels to continuously document participant voices especially the women to guide adaptations on the program.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Following the needs and recommendations from the field-first learning processes like the market assessment, In a week I would organize a 3days market exhibition or trade show, were I would mobilize and bring together all market actors and players including, regulatory authorities, financial institutions, suppliers, women and youth farmers and entrepreneurs, local and national traders, buyers, transporters, extension workers and CSOs among others. This would aim at delivering different results for the different target participants especially the target groups who are the women and youths. The regulatory authorities and CSOs would be targeted to provide information to the women and youth entrepreneurs as well as provide formal registration for their business during the market exhibition as a critical component of formalizing businesses and for growth of business , while the Suppliers and local and national traders will be targeted to create market access linkages and business partnerships with the women and youth farmers and entrepreneurs as well as create market for their products and increase the access to inputs for their businesses, Financial institutions will be targeted to create financial linkages for women and youth farmers and entrepreneurs to boost their businesses and enhance their capital. During the 3 days exhibition, I would register attendance of all stakeholders in their respective categories and ensure registry for all contacts especially those with what's app upon which I will seek consent to create a social media channel on what's app to continue with the coordination and linkages for the suppliers, producers, women and youth entrepreneurs, legal authorities, CSOs among others, upon which I would introduce the purpose of the group to be access to information, linkages and market access amongst the members, were members would be encouraged to post their products, traders would also share their the products on demand, price listing among others and would easily be provided in time using the existing contacts. I would judge it by tracking the physical attendance of all the target participants, including the outcomes, such as tracking the number of women and youths with formally registered businesses, the number of businesses registered, the number of women and youth formally linked to financial institutions and the number of business linkages and partnerships made. I would also utilize participant feedback surveys to assess the impact of the physical exhibition in terms of relevance, impact, effectiveness, gender inclusion, market access indicators among others. I would then monitor the social media channel activities to assess the linkages and access to markets and products during the group interactions among the suppliers, traders and other actors providing information. This would include tracking the number of females especially women farmers actively participating in the group and those accessing market for their products through the group linkages, encouraging members to provide feedback regading the effectiveness and relevancy of the channels regarding linking them to buyers and access to market products through short surveys, voice notes, or polls, among others.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The execution spine would include a 4 by 4 matrix, the horizontal access would include the function/role, the person responsible by name and title, the milestones with a specific timeframe and the escalation path. While vertically, it includes the specific roles/functions needed for the delivery of the program. Therefore, the details include; 1. Supply Chain engagement role, owned by the financial and market systems advisor-Molly, who will be in charge of 3 critical milestones, including conducting a market assessment in the first quarter, Mapping and profiling all market actors including suppliers, women farmers and entrepreneurs networks and other key players in the sector and formalizing the engagements by signing MOUs. Lastly the advisor would formulate women Agri-business farmers/entrepreneurs' groups in the 3 regions. The escalation path will be through the strategic initiative lead who is the direct supervisor who will then escalate to the program's director and to the executive director of World Vision. 2. MEAL learning will be the second role, owned by a MEAL advisor-Teddy who will lead on the critical MEAL milestones including development of a gender transformative MEAL system, with key priorities being, developing MEAL Plan, Performance measurement framework with clearly defined gender inclusive performance indicators and targets, support with Baseline measurement and Gender analysis as well as market assessment all conducted in a participatory and inclusive manner all done in the first quarter. Another milestone will be publishing of learning briefs and products like reports, stories from the monitoring and learning processes including research. Designing, rolling out and managing a functional Feedback and accountability mechanism for continuous learning and adaptation, the escalation paths would include the strategic initiative manager who escalates to the PQL/MEAL manager, to the Program director and then to the ED. 3. Community Liaison role, will be owned by the partner-Kujenga farmers networks field manager called Jennifer, who will lead on forming of community engagements and trainings of the women farmers following the integrated modular curriculums, receive and document feedback from the community through the feedback channels and produce activity and monthly activity reports. the escalation pathway will be through the supervisor, ED of Kujenga network to Okello the strategic initiative manager and to the PD and ED of World vision. 4.project and partnership management, policy influence and governance role, will be owned by Okello the strategic initiatives manager/lead who will deliver stakeholder mapping, analysis, profiling and develop as well as manage the stakeholder engagement plan, convene stakeholder engagement meetings for policy alignment and come up with a strategic alignment framework or strategy, convene coordination and review meeting and field learning visits with project teams and partners/stakeholders in the 3 regions for adaptive monitoring and learning, the escalation path will be the Programs Director who will escalate to the ED and SMT.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: Title: A 90 Day project work plan. 3 key project outcomes include1. Increase in income levels for women farmers/entrepreneurs as a result of their participation and involvement in climate smart agri-businesses in the 3 regions. 2. Increase in the number of policies, budgets and sectoral frameworks influenced including the agro-industrial park strategy as a result of integration and gender inclusive policy reviews. 3. Increased access to markets and finances by women farmers as a result of improved supply chain policies and systems in the three regions. The 5 milestones will include, designing an execution spine/plan clearly stating the roles, key milestones/deliverables/timeframe and the persons responsible including the governance and escalation pathways to be completed by the strategic initiative lead-Okello with consultations from the project teams and stakeholders and signed off by the senior management Team/ ED in 15 days. 2. The MEAL Advisor-Teddy will Conduct a MEAL design workshop to design a gender transformative MEAL system for the project with a gender inclusive performance measurement framework with SMART performance indicators and targets to be finalized in 30 days. 3. Supply chain stakeholder mapping, analysis and management strategy developed and signed off by the Operations director as well as signed MOU with all strategic partners and stakeholders like with kujenga network and district leadership in Teso, Karamoja and Busoga regions. The owners of this milestone will be Molly the Markey systems advisor and Okello the strategic initiative manager, and the decision gates will be Operations manager to be completed by the end of the second month, Kujenga network manager/coordinator-Jennifer to set up community liaison structures in the 3 regions Teso, Karamoja and Busoga including signing of agreements and setting up feedback mechanisms. to be completed in the third Month-30 days. Decision gates will be Kujenga Senior leadership and World Vision SMT. 5.The strategic initiative manager/lead-Okello will conduct a stakeholder engagement meeting especially with local and national government and sector leadership to review and align the program to the existing policy frameworks, including policy influencing to make them gender inclusive and community led. To be completed by the end of the third month with approval of the World Vision SMT and ED. Slippages will be exposed the functional Feedback mechanisms reviewed monthly for response and adaptation, Weekly and Monthly planning and check-in meetings with staff and task owners to review the progress and plan for acceleration actions with a clear action plan progress tracking matrix, implement and monitor the escalation pathways and lastly reviewing of activity reports to track completion and identify slippage for corrective measures to be undertaken.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: There is a high likelihood of handoff failure between partners due to the new proposed approach and mix-up of formal NGO partnerships with the local partnerships with Kujenga network which is more of field first learning and locally led. Therefore, I foresee a risk or failure in supply chain and market/business linkages management were the agribusiness and procurement processes and systems of the form NGOs may not align with those of the local partners and government such as Kujenga network and women farmer groups as well asl for government/districts hence posing challenges in aligning to or compromising the different processes for different partners. The other risk or failure would arise in the adaptation and adoption of gender transformative MEAL systems including formal processes and approaches like the mixed methods of learning loops, this may face challenges because the local partners like Kujenga, are used to very simplified MEAL systems unlike those for the formal NGO partners, hence being perceived as diluting the gender lens and sometimes limiting the first-field learning loops and adaptive management hence causing role confusion and system overload for local partners like kujenga. Lastly, the risk of missing out on community feedback and voices through the feedback channels which are managed through a structured process by the Formal NGOs like world vision, as opposed to those managed directly by the local partners in the community. the levels of escalation and feedback management may fail to yield adaptions as senior management may not have access to the particIpant voices given that feedback good directly through the field staff, kujenga network, strategic initiative manager to the senior management, which is the most likely situation in the scale up process. Therefore, I will introduce multiple alternatives to maintain the first field learning loop for generating participant and stakeholder feedbacks for increased accountability and joint decision-making processes through Monthly or quarterly project review and learning meetings including all stakeholder, partners and community representation monthly virtual meetings and quarterly physical or semi virtual meetings to deliberate on key achievement, lessons, execution drifts and solutions for adaptive management and joint decision making. I would produce and publish jointly cocreated knowledge management products from the learning processes like knowledge/learning briefs, highlighting analysis of all non-negotiables such as achievement towards project results, gender inclusion and integration, execution drifts, participant stories of change and feedback, recommendations for adaptations among others which will be disseminated to the different audience including senior management, local and NGO partners, Local and National government leadership for informed decision making and to close on the gaps identified.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: I would slow down or delay the full transition/shift from grassroots delivery to larger NGO partners following the global trend of localization agenda to transfer resources and leadership to local partners and also because this has caused tension, pressure and role confusion to the scale up amongst partners as well as risks of diluting the gender lens which is critical for impact to scale. Secondly, I would propose a partial not full alignment with government policies especially the agro-industrial park strategy as the review processes for the same policies are adopted in the project activities to ensure that they are gender inclusive, and do not limit field first learning and local driven approaches that may hinder the project from achieving its goals, and thus policy influencing activities would deal with these gaps during the implementation. What will stay, includes, MEAL redesign to adopt gender transformative MEAL systems that intergrate a gender lens in programing and define the results and performance measurement indicators while maintaining a field first learning loop like Kujenga's network is aligned too and Promoting a field first learning mechanisma nd approaches as well as strengthening the Feedback and accountability mechanisms for continued learning, improvement and adaptations that will lead to a successful delivery of the project.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: The main goal for the one-day alignment workshop is to socialize staff and partners with the new scale-up project and create a harmonized understanding of project results, donor requirement and redesign the key project implementation strategies with alignments to the donor requirements and government policies. The specific objectives will include to orient all staff and partners on the core objectives, principles and donor requirements of the scale-up project including delivery of climate smart women inclusive agribusiness models, integration of gender lens and field first learning approaches, as well as alignments to government policies. Secondly the workshop is intended to jointly redesign a Gender Transformative MEAL system, agree on the project results, key performance and gender inclusive indicators, project targets, design MEAL tools that will track sex age, gender and disability disaggregated data, and develop a Feedback and accountability mechanism. The third specific goal will include planning and role disaggregation for all staff members and partners, to clarify on the roles and responsibilities for each team members, including their reporting and escalation pathways. The fourth goal will be to conduct a SWOT analysis and stakeholder analysis to define the key stakeholders to be involved in the scale up as well as review policy frameworks such as agro-industrial park strategy to clearly define and map out the alignment and integration needs, aligning them to the donor expectations. Lastly to come up with a project costed work plan which will spell out key milestones with clear actions and responsible staff and the resources/budget required as well as identifying key assumptions and risks and define mitigation measures. The agenda blocks will include from 8:00am-8:30am, arrival and registration by Operations staff, 8:30-9:00am, Introduction, ground rules and welcome/opening remarks by the Strategic initiative lead, 9:00 to 10:00am; Introduction and background of the scale-up project, donor requirements, principles and standards, by the Initiative lead plus a plenary session. 10:00 to 10:30 am: short break and networking. 10:30am to 13:00pm: Gender Transformative MEAL systems redesign, review of project results, refine gender inclusive indicators, define project targets, define the MEAL Plan, and develop MEAL tools to track Sex Age Disability Disaggregated data and design a feedback and accountability mechanisms as well as the learning agenda and field learning loop led by the MEAL advisor. 13:00 to 14:00pm: Lunch break and networking. 14:00 to 15:00pm: SWOT analysis, Stakeholder mapping and review and alignment with existing policy frameworks and donor requirement such as the agro-Industrial park strategy and gender inclusion/ integration and alignment to the standards or requirements led by the gender advisor. 15:00 to 16:00pm: Developing of a Costed project workplan with key activities and milestones indicated with the actual timelines, costs/budget and responsible staff including partners including other critical actions and recommendations mapped out for integration, policy influence and advocacy led by Grants and the initiative manager. 16:00 to 17:00pm: Risk assessment and mitigation plan, Governance and partnership management/ communication structure or flow chart development by the operations or grants lead. 17:00 to 17:30pm: Action planning, AOB, and closing remarks by the Senior management leadership. The outputs expected will include a project implementation strategy developed and submitted for approval by senior management, a stakeholder analysis and management strategy developed and submitted for approval by senior management, 15 project and partner staff gain a common understanding of the project goals, results, and donor requirements. A project MEAL system designed with clear results, SMART and gender inclusive performance indicators, project targets defined, project tools developed, FAM tools and learning agenda in place, a costed work plan submitted for approval by senior management, procurement plan and budget reviewed and submitted for approval. Risk management plan developed, project governance structure and communication structure developed among others.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: I will conduct a joint MEAL redesign workshop and invite the participation of all project staff of word vision and of Kujenga farmers network, with a purpose of jointly co designing the Gender Transformative MEAL System for the project.
