The workshop will start with a training or orientation of what a gender transformative MEAL system is and looks like, the importance of this system, and why gender intergration to ensure a common understanding of the concepts, standards and expectations of the donors and other stakeholders, but also to realign the expectations and define similarities and differences in the parallel MEAL systems that may require alignment and a common decision for adaptations. Upon coming to a common understanding and agreement for the need to harmonize the systems, the team will then jointly redesign the projects MEAL Framework, reviewing and redefining project results with a gender lens upon which the team will also jointly agree to gender inclusive project performance indicators and clearly define them on how well they will measure gender integration and project results, jointly agree on project target groups and target values as well as define the disaggregation needs. The team will also agree to, develop or adopt existing MEAL tools and digital dashboards and databases that will jointly be used to track project implementation and reporting needs t be used by all partners and staff. A joint MEAL plan will be agreed upon to include joint MEAL activities such as joint field first learning activities like joint field monitoring visits, joint studies such as Market assessments, gender analysis, baseline, Midline and endline evaluations all conducted jointly and the Feedback system designed jointly to feed into the joint MEAL system at all levels with all parties having user rights to the MEAL systems, tools and software. Joint MEAL training for all staff and partners as well as Research assistants will be conducted especially on the Gender transformative MEAL principles, gender training, concepts and standards, tools, indicators among others to ensure a common understanding of the MEAL system, gender integration to enable them use similar proposed approaches, tools, standards and the single MEAL system in general. Agree on a joint MEAL plan which will mapp all staff and partners with clear responsibility of delivering specific results and milestones as aggregated in the single MEAL system to be used for tracking completion. Jointly develop a learning agenda and with clear joint feedback loops and mechanisms such as jointly monthly planning ad reflection meeting, joint quarterly review meetings and joint annual learning events were in all forums peformance review for progress made and with a gender lens will take place and provide room for feedback, accountability and adaptation by all staff and joint decision making. Develop and product joint learning products, reports, briefs, and papers to avoid duplication of efforts and harmonized project implementation. Agree to a joint communication and reporting flow structure to ensure that there is coordination and collaboration in all institution for accountability. With all this done there will be a single functional MEAL system.

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text: According to this scale-up scenario, the successful climate smart and women inclusive agribusiness pilot was anchored some core principles to which led to the scale-up as benchmarks and should be adopted by the scale-up including gender inclusion and integration, thus applying a gender lens in all project processes right from design, inception, implementation, measurement and tracking of results and reporting to avoid the risk of diluting the gender lens, the second will be adopting the field first learning approach across partners and function to ensure informed decision making, centering of the participant/ women voice in all decisions made as well as incorporating feedback into all adaptations and management decisions to enhance project impact, accountability, relevance, effectiveness, sustainability and efficiency of the project as well as document project results and change stories with participant voices being at the center. Lastly, the fact that single systems will be operated and not parallel such as the MEAL system, role clarity and definition for all players is critical, where clear milestones, targets and expectations are defined and documented for all the partner staff in the implementation charter/guide, in the workplan and MEAL plan to eliminate the role confusion. To test adherence to the first principle of gender inclusion, I will design performance measurement indicators and metrics to assess adherence and integration of gender through the surveys and track progress against targets, equally the MEAL tools will be designed to monitor gender integration by reporting on sex, age, disability, nationality (SADD) among other variables for measuring gender integration, thus I would review reports to ascertain whether staff are reporting of Sex, age and disability disaggregated data and ensure that all staff are trained to do so if not reported on. for principle two on field first learning, I would review monitoring reports and activity reports and learning briefs or products, also during review meetings I would review and assess whether participant voices, decisions and community views are captured, such as verbatims, participant stories, recommendations feedbacks are included and if not, there should be a corrective measure to train the staff on how to integrate this principle in real work. Lastly the principle on role clarity will be tested during planning and review meetings, where respective staff are responsible and will be accountable for the specific milestones, during progress tracking, the role clarity will be tested by the number of staff aware of their roles and milestones as compared to those who will not be aware or have clarity on their roles and responsibilities for the respective milestone upon which corrective measures will be adopted.

question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: One decision that must be co-owned will be to redesign a gender transformative MEAL system with gender inclusive MEAL result frameworks, were all partners and staff must be involved in the redesign of the MEAL results framework to define clearly the desired results, agree to and clearly define the SMART performance measurement indicators, define target groups and come up with target numbers jointly as well as develop the MEAL tools necessary for trucking progress and gender inclusion, agree to the reporting frequency and timelines, develop feedback loops, learning agenda and other MEAL processes. This decision is usually not approved because its a single MEAL system for all partners and requires a continuous process of adaptive monitoring and management were periodically the MEAL plan and results chain is reviewed to ensure consistency, coherence and enable corrective actions or adaptations to be made usually aligned to donor reporting timelines and evaluation processes. I would structure it in a way that it all starts with a joint redesign workshop with all project staff in attendance including partners like kujenga staff to redesign the MEAL system and define all the gender inclusive results and indicators and other MEAL processes and deliverable including training. The final products will then be shared with all partners and staff for continuous reviews, joint signoff and use, Joint implementation and monitoring of implementation for the MEAL plan through using it to track progress and communicate jointly on the progress and any lessons or challenges using the systems and joint actions, recommendations for adaptations are made, and I will lastly share progress towards meeting the set targets and standards on gender inclusion during periodic review processes to ensure monitoring of progress towards joint and specific targets, milestones and gender integration, and in case of any execution drifts joint actions would be agreed upon and implemented.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: An executable promise is a commitment/result or a deliverable agreed upon by all stakeholders including the donors, World vision, Kujenga and all other partners and well documented and signed off with clear objectives, milestones, results, targets and SMART performance indicators to measure success, including clear timelines or delivery and with clear roles stipulated for specific staff and partners to enable accountability for delivering results. A weekly commitment I will publish is a weekly progress report/bulletin/brief jointly cocreated with all staff and partners sharing weekly progress on achievements of outputs and outcomes against the set targets and workplans. Secondly it will cover sex, age, disability, nationality disaggregated data against performance indicators, gender inclusion targets. will also include participant voices in verbatims, stories of change and feedback from the field. Key recommendations, adaptation needs and pending actions will also be publish for further planning and decision making by senior leadership. I will enforce right from the start by jointly adopting this commitment as a consortium and agreeing to the timelines for data sharing and aggregation as well as the assigning the roles to specific staff like the MEAL staff or field managers, the follow it up with reminders with the relevant staff ahead of the timelines with onsite support and capacity strengthening for the staff at the start until it becomes a practice. Use of shared tools especially digital tools for timely data capture and analysis with visualized dashboards embedded for easy tracking and reporting. I would also share the products across all shared spaces like emails, what'sApp channels and teams, to facilitate management decisions.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: The light dashboard would include a couple of fields/parameter/metrics including, Date, Location, activity, indicator, Number of people reached per indicator against target, Sex disaggregation by female and male, age disaggregation as per the age of target groups of the project, disability status, Feedback received, feedback categories and feedback status (open or closed), Participant level of satisfaction, staff responsible and completion rate (completed, ongoing , not started) and lastly color coded activity delivery status (delayed-red, on course-yellow, completed-green). the three leading indicators to be trucked on the dashboard will include the number and percentage of women farmers/entrepreneurs enrolled into the scale-up project in the 3 location, project target is 75% must be female participants. The second indicator will be Number of feedback received on the project from field participants disaggregating the feedback by sex and age categories and % of feedback responded too and closed. and the third indicator will be the level of satisfaction with project interventions categorized by 5 factors (very dissatisfied, dissatisfied, neutral, satisfied and very satisfied). The owners will be market systems advisor-Molly, Kujenga network coordinators in the respective regions, the MEAL staff providing oversight roles during project implementation and reporting, and the Strategic Initiative manager/lead. If a Matric turns red on the delivery status, the escalation rule, will be to flag it to the next level of escalation path for the respective staff including Kujenga network ED/ senior leadership in charge of first filed project delivery and learning processes, the Strategic Initiative manager in charge of overall project delivery, the Program quality and MEAL manager in charge of program quality and lastly the World Vision senior leadership in charge of overall oversight to ensure management decisions, enforcement and actions.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: A partner missing out on two milestones, is indeed a project oversight error which all parties must take accountability for as both the partner and World Vision leadership and staff have a shared responsibility for delivery project activities and providing a technical oversight to all project interventions to ensure quality and timely delivery, therefore I would structure the recovery conversation in a twofold manner starting internally with staff to truck loop holes leading to the misalignment of the milestones and then hold discussions with the partner staff fronting a collaborative and shared accountability position to reflect on the progress of agreed upon milestones, results, activity objectives and how these may affect the project timely delivery and hinder attainment of project goals. Thus the conversation would include facts and figures of project progress, agreed upon plans and agreements, costs and budget realignments and a reminder of the distinct roles of each partner and staff. Would then jointly reflect openly on the execution drift/challenges, disect role clarity for the partners and map out support needs for the partner to get back on course and design corrective actions as next steps with clear timeline. The decision options would include, providing the partner an opportunity to correct the gaps in implementation with defined milestones and timelines as well as with close monitoring and technical oversight support from world vision management and staff, provided there is adequate time, resources and capacity for the partner to deliver on the key milestones. The second decision would be to reassign the pending milestones to another partner or to directly take on the implementation while the partner plays a supportive role given the circumstance especially when there is no capacity and resources to deliver the milestones for this partner. The last option would be the worst-case scenario especially if it involves fund mismanagement, fraud and safeguarding risks reported by the community, would be to terminate the partnerships as per the standards and clearly and respectfully communicate to all stakeholders the changes as well as take-on the implementation directly or get into another partnership for continuity.

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: Firstly, I would clearly tailor the purpose and outcomes of the meetings to be decision driven and communicate these ahead of time to the staff and target stakeholders targeted to attend the meetings during the planning phase and include it in the invitation emails and letters, secondly, I will identify the rightful participants who are responsible for decision making and who can confidently voice out especially among the community members, partners leadership and World vision staff and management to attend the meeting. Thirdly, I will also structure the agenda to have decision making sessions after every agenda item to ensure that all discussions and reflections from the field end with key actions and decisions for corrective action. Fourth, I will hold a session at the end of every meeting to review and agree on a plan of actions with all key actions and decision made in the sessions reviewed and agreed upon for actioning which will form a decision log/tracker for the project upon which will be widely shared and archived to inform next steps of implementation and corrective action by management, partners and project teams.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: The first ever quarterly review and reflection meeting with Kujenga and regional partners will be focused on checking progress and alignment to the agreed upon standards and implementation principles/donor expectations, therefore all questions will be aligned to the principles and standards as structured on the agenda. 3 critical questions will be asked across the 3/4 priority areas; including Maintaining a field first learning approach, redesign of a gender transformative MEAL system and ensure gender inclusion and integration during project implementation with a gender lens, role clarity and task segregation and lastly alignment to existing policy frameworks and ago-industrial park strategy among others; so the 3 key learning and reflective questions would include open ended questions like; What is working well (practices, innovations, tools, approaches, etc) and should be sustained in each of the 4 areas of focus? the second question will be what is not working well that needs to stop or be adapted? the third question will be, What can we do differently to change the situation and do better in the remaining period of implementation/ what needs to be done and what support is needed? The questions will be answered in groups, and thus different groups will prepare cards for all the responses which will then be presented and sticked in the respective decision categories on the wall upon which all insights will be jointly reviewed, categorized and prioritized depending on the most commonly shared views and most pressing issues/needs per discussion area. upon prioritizing the most pressing needs/issues, a presentation on the solutions and recommendations will then be completed and categorized accordingly as well as a discussion on the most needed adaptations and decisions will be held to prioritize the plans of action and agree to the most important or pressing decisions that should be made as corrective measures in the short term, midterm and long term. I will then come up with an action plan and map all the agreed upon decisions and actions for change categorize in the short term, midterm and long term with clear timelines allocated and the team will asign roles and responsibilities for the specific decisions or actions to respective staff- name and role also indicated on the plan which will then be signed off by the world vision strategic initiative manager, Kujenga leadership, and other partners leads as a sign for agreed upon joint action for change. This decision log or action plan signed off will then be share with everyone for continued implementation and tracking in the decision log/tracker of action.

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: In an event that I identify a negative finding like the gender outcomes stalling, I would perform an analysis of the project progress against set targets and indicators, and prepare a presentation on the progress across the result areas and key deliverables for the project. I would then utilize one of the learning spaces/meetings like a monthly or quarterly review meeting to present the findings to all project staff and partners highlighting the areas with low performance color coded red and pointing our accountable staff for delivering on these activities or actions, after which I will pose and hold a reflective session to diagonize the major execution challenges and gaps affecting performance, areas of support, review feedback from participants and grassroots, as well as come up with corrective measures to improve performance in all the areas flagged while recognizing the joint and shared accountability and roles for all staff. Therefore, both the partner staff and Technical leads from world vision will be assigned roles and responsibilities including capacity strengthening in gender programing and integration, re orientation on performance indicators and measurement as well as on the tools by the MEAL advisor which will enhance implementation by kujenga staff all mapped on the plan of action for improvement which will be jointly tracked to protect the momentum and build trust.

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: Next quarter to save funds for adaptations needed, I will hold a joint review of the budget and workplan to prioritize activities, where possible merge activities in similar locations so as to use same budget lines for more than one activity where possible to save money for required adaptations. Secondly, I would make use of virtual spaces/meeting for review and reflection to minimize staff costs on travel for physical review meetings and utilize future physical meetings planned to save money next quarter for adaptations. Lastly, I would jointly review the budget to minimize field travel costs organizing physical trainings in central locations to holding partner specific training sessions on site which would reduce the budgets for travels and workshop expenses and fund the adaptations needed.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: The costs for aligning with ministry Agro-park would include high compliance costs to both partners and women farmers including legal registration and alignments, while the costs for protecting grassroot focus will include high transactional costs by the women farmers trying to comply illegally and meet the market standards for trade and may be hard for them to attract large investors, suppliers, traders without operating and recognized licenses or legal registration. The benefits for aligning with ministry would be leveraging on existing government infrastructure, resources, markets and systems, Increased buy-in by government, and local stakeholders for the project interventions that may increase synergies and high-level support and influence/advocacy, while for grassroot focus the benefits would include local ownership of the project interventions and processes and first field learning an informed decisions for impact and sustainability. Equity implications for ministry alignment would include, women farmers will easily be linked and integrated into government programs such as value chains and other financial programs lime PDM for enhance capital and livelihoods once partnerships with the ministry are formalized and negotiated, although it may risk critical focus on gender integration and gender lens since women may be left out in setting up the Agro-industrial Park strategy which may lack a gender lens and no women women voices to inform priorities hence missing a first field learning and alignment hence affecting the project principles. While the equity implications for grassroot focus may include maintaining a field first learning approach were voices of women are incorporated into decisions, and hence a gender lens integrated into implementation and scale-up, may facilitate capacity building for building women's agency to participate in decision making processes, take up leadership and co own and implement the project activities, although may limit government linkages for women to benefit from government programs. Execution risks tagged to alignment with ministry may include a lot of delays as a result of bureaucracies involved in the alignment processes and approvals, may face politicization which may affect implementation fidelity and momentum, may limit first field learning and adaptive management due to the rigidity in the models and approaches as well as policies, that may not be the best fit for different contexts and localities hence hindering adaptations and affecting results. However, positively it may simplify standardization in the processes, quality and approaches. While execution risks for grassroot focus may include slowed or delayed scale-up due to limited resources, infrastructure and markets as there may not be leveraging on existing government resources due to the misalignment hence the project may incur more costs than projected for linkages, limited coordination collaboration and oversight management across the 3 regions as it may be costly for monitoring project implementation and there is no government oversight roles which can affect the quality and timeliness of implementation by partners. Although positively it enables maintaining a gender lens and field first learning an adaptation. My call would be to embrace a mixed approach instead of a full scale of alignment with ministry to enable effective, efficient and sustainable project delivery. Because both approaches are relevant and have opportunity cost in one way or another for instance would tap into government resoiurces and infrastructures as well as enable linkages for women to government programs and enable coordination and oversight role of government , while maintaining the fielf first learning momentum adaptive management and gender inclusion and integration contributed to by both approaches to deliver a quality and successful scale-up.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: The first data point would be key alignment standards/requirement and targets for the Agro-industrial park strategy and other frameworks from Ministry liaison officer or any other ministry staff. The second would be performance results on indicators for gender integration metrics by Kujenga farmer's network for benchmarking from the Team leader or MEAL staff of Kujenga these would help in strategic direction formulation. The fallback position would be secondary data reviews from the Agro-industrial park strategy source documents, Ministry reports and briefs as well as documentation from Kujenga farmers for the previous implementation that is being scaled-up, in addition to basic assumptions and hypothesis.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: Start from the basic, remind them about the signed-up commitments by the donor and partners, the agreed upon standards, principles, results, targets, budgets and shared roles and responsibilities. Provide overall technical guidance, and definitions of all the relevant concepts to generate a harmonized understanding of the results, quality standards and set targets and requirement for informed discussions. I will then present to them project evidences of performance with facts and figures including field first learning voices, feedback, and proposed adaptations, implications and oportnities, this will enable informed and evidence-based discussions. I will then hold an open discussion to reflect on the presentations, pick insights and discussions on the non-negotiables and critical views on the tradeoffs and adaptations required. This would then lead to informed and jointly agreed upon transparent decisions with clear communication and consensus agreed upon for alignment. This will demonstrate transparency, respect, accountability and involvement in important decision-making processes.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: Focus on the defined non-negotiable principles and standards and Flexi on the approaches and processes of project delivery. For example, gender integration must be coherently crafted, Field first learning and localizations is another rule across the regions, alignment and collaboration with existing government, and national systems and policies cuts across since it's a donor requirement, as well as role clarity and definition. The non-negotiables must have an implication to adherence to donor requirement, commitments, and must have a stake to the quality, impact and sustainability of project interventions hence should be coherently managed while other aspects like the delivery mechanisms, systems such as Feedback and accountability, learning and review processes can be adapted to fit the context in the three regions.

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: Non-Negotiables • Understanding context, through Gender & Context Analysis for each of the regions. • Beneficiary centered design, Implementation & Feedback from participants, partners, stakeholders etc. • Stakeholder Analysis for each of the different regions • Use of lessons learned from the pilot, especially what worked, what did not work and why? • Documentation of best practices and obstacles to maintain quality of execution • Two-way effective communication- bottom up and up-bottom. • Strategy and delivery guidelines and requirements. Flex areas • Implementation plan and approaches • In budget & work plans because these are circumstantial • Delivery timelines, but keeping within the overall delivery timelines • Government involvement & Input depending on the need.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: • The partnership should be gender responsive and equitable with role clarity and responsibilities. • Gender Inclusive joint planning, participation and shared decision-making platforms and processes should guide the partnership to avoid big brother syndrome.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: • Resistance from local communities and local organizations • Exbhition of big brother syndrome and bossy partnership arising from I know it better than you, I lead and you follow, thus killing local empowerment and sustainability. • Program misalignment due to pre-conceived ideas of the formal partners • Missed opportunities to learn from the lower partners and the programme participants/beneficiaries themselves as their formal partners seek to be perfect. • Lack of trust from the local partners communities.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: • Working with formal NGOS to deliver the scale up that is eye catching • Why? Their knowledge of the local voice, interests and context is limited, so leaving them out does not kill the scale up.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: 1. In line with the Gender transformative scale up indicators designed, and the communication strategy developed, the learning loop will be guided through. 2. Capacity assessment and capacity enhancement in the identified gaps for the scale up team and stakeholders involved. 3. M&E tools designed and capacity building of partners and implementing teams helps in gathering information relevant 4. Conducting Joint monitoring including MEAL, Gender, regional scale up intervention leads formal and informal stakeholders, also seeking community feedback about the scale up. 5. Reflection meetings plan- Weekly to Quarterly to understand progress, and cab obstacles to the scale up initiative. These would be online and physical 6. Documentation guidelines and production of learning briefs and materials about what is working 7. Designing time bound actions to address the identified scale up gaps What I would change is not having routine update meetings but having actionable and decision-making meetings and reflections.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: • Women have no time to spend in workshops because of the heavy workload, so others may not be happy/ okay with weeklong trainings.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: • Engage women groups to find out and learn from them the appropriate time schedules that works for them and priorities so that these can be aligned to the HQ plans.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: • Equipping women with business literacy, digital skills and awareness on market systems to manage business operations and finances well and grow their business. Then collaborate with other strong networks and institutions to connect women to new markets, using digital platforms like WhatsApp and other mediums to market and sell their products. • I would judge it through feedback as evidenced by women who piloted these approaches

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: 1. MEAL Learning: in charge of the M&E framework and development of tracking tools, including organizing and calling learning and reflection platforms. 2. Community liaison: Engagement with communities, implementing interventions and documenting what is working and any anticipated risks and obstacles. Engaging stakeholders to support the scale up initiative. Timely Reporting 3. Program Manager: Owns the implementation plan to guide the implementation across the regions, Stakeholder analysis and engagement plan, monitoring plan, budget holder and Risk Matrix owner, scale up communication strategy plans 4. Manager in partnership with the Procurement Depart: handles procurements and asset related inventory etc 5. Safeguarding Advisor: owns the safeguards and escalation of any anticipated risked and harms through the stipulated channels in the policy 6. Gender Advisor: owns and ensures gender integration plans and works in partnership with the MEAL to ensure the transformation is tracked and documented

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: OUTCOMES: 1. Increased capacity of 30 women groups in Agro business literacy, value chain and access to markets to enhance economic empowerment for women and HH food security. 2. Women and their groups have access to financial opportunities through gender transformative Digital platforms and are adding value to their products. 3. Women and their groups able to access market opportunities through collectives and digital platforms 5 MILESTONES 1. a). Conduct a gender analysis to establish gender and social Norms affecting women’s participation in agribusinesses value chain and access to and control of productive resources. 1st month b) Inception workshop to bring everyone on board to understand the genders norms to be addressed and the approaches to be employed. 1st month 2. Mobilize communities’ women farmers to form groups, to be able to meaningfully benefit from collective financial and market access to agro their business. 1st month 3. Conduct capacity assessment in the mentioned areas to establish capacity gaps and needs to be able to tailor capacity building for women and their groups on climate smart agro business, financial access, value addition, digital literacy and markets access etc 2nd Month 4. Conduct assorted trainings for women and their groups 2nd and 3rd Month 5. Use women friendly digital platforms to provide information on linkages, financial services, etc all 3 months 6. Empower women have access and control to the agro business assets and products to be able to increase their Household yields and value-addition to their products. 7. Collection of evidence through data collection to inform what is working well about the scale up. OWNERS 1. Gender Advisor- lead on Gender Analysis, inception and gender integration 2. Project implementing teams: implementing activities 3. Specific Technical teams based on identified capacity gaps 4. Financial inclusion expert: technical guidance to women financial inclusion 5. MEAL Advisor: delivery of M&E framework DECISION GATES 1. Design phase 2. Stakeholder engagement phase 3. Implementation planning and execution phase 4. Monitoring and evaluation- reflections

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: • Lack of timely milestone delivery, Action is hands on support to partners and drawing acceleration plans

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: • Inception workshop to bring everyone on board to understand the genders norms to be addressed and the approaches to be employed. • Conduct capacity assessment in the mentioned areas to establish capacity gaps and needs to be able to tailor capacity building for women and their groups on climate smart agro business, financial access, value addition, digital literacy and markets access etc

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Workshop Goal: To ensure all key departments understand the objectives and their role in delivering the scale up. 8:8:15 am Introduction and welcome remarks- by 8:15 to 9:00am Background to the Climate Smart women inclusive Agribusiness pilot and Agro industrialization parks, why the alignment and expectations and goal clarity, decisions on intervention priorities by Program Manager 9-10:30am: Refining the goal, objectives and interventions per partners per region – Group work guided by BD Manager, Program Manager and technical leads and partners Break Tea 11-1:00pm refining continued. 1-2:00pm Lunch 2-3:30pm Understanding the different departmental roles and responsibilities Procurement needs and requirements M&E framework and guiding tools 3:30-5:30pm Gender integration- and women and Girl’s assessment tool snapshot, Approaches Grants; guidance and understanding of the grant’s agreement Requirements and obligations, budget provisions and funds allocations. Recap of engagement OUTPUTS • Draft copy of the alignment document including draft M&E framework. • Engagement report with completion follow up actions • Partners and technical team understand alignment purpose and expectations.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: • Putting the two teams together and building their capacity on Gender Transformative MEAL aspects such as gender transformative indicators and milestones. what norms to address and what shifts to look at. • Anchoring everything on how to deliver the goal of the scale up, all staff must always go back to that. How do we achieve the goal as a team. • Joint planning, monitoring and reflections.

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text: • Application of the gender marker at all design, implementation and M&E phases, • All should be ambassadors of gender transformative integration across implementation phases. • Joint planning, Documentation of gender transformation changes in line with the norms being addressed and the gender transformative indicators

question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: • Individual leadership and accountability, it is a responsibility of everyone to ensure that the team achieves the scale up delivery. The structure will be based on time bound and actionable delivery work plans

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: • Following implementation workplans and budgets, • Enforcement: Weekly meetings online and but also phone follow-ups, explore offline budget tools to track budget absorptions.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: INDICATOR 1. Number of women groups identified and trained in climate smart agribusiness, financial literacy, value addition, digital literacy and markets access INDICATOR 2 % of women and their groups who have accessed finances to boost their business through increased yields and value addition. INDICATOR 3 • Number of women using online platforms to market their products like Whatsapp and report increase in their income. OWNERS PROGRAM MANAGER: ensure that the interventions are implemented based on the implementation plan and resources are budgeted for and all quality control measures are in place. MEAL ADVISOR -enure m&e frame is in place and data collecting tools are developed and socialized, documenting is happening GENDR ADVISOR: ensures that gender transformative approaches are integrated at every stage and that identified gender norms are being addressed, and all safeguards are adhered to by all implementing teams FINANCE/GRANTS ensures the budgets are aligned to the interventions and implementation plans are being followed, absorptions are checked If the Metric turns red; The first action is to identify the issue and investigate it to establish the status, cause and impact • Once the issue has been identified with clear channels established, I would first try to engage the respective centres, if this fails to be resolved then I can think of escalating to higher levels, through a well-documented evidence detailing the entire process and efforts so far taken

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: • Cause a meeting with the partner (implenters and management) to find out the cause, • Brainstorm alternative approaches to address the issue and identify support needs • Draw acceleration plan, with no additional funding but encouraging integration in the ongoing activities. • Conduct partner hands on support.

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: • Action oriented and time bound meetings and engagements, strengthening individual accountability mechanism

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: What worked in the pilot? And mentioning at least that one thing that stood out. What surprised them during the pilot period? What did they learn about themselves as a community during the pilot? What did not work well? And what would they want scrapped off completely ? What community structure stood up in support of the delivery of the scale up? Who else would they like to join the pilot. What will they be taking a head as they plan for scale up What would they do differently if given another chance?• Converting answers into signed changes: Documenting and compile a learning report informing next actions and future programming.

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: • Negative findings: Looking at what caused the gender outcome to stall together with the implementing teams and partners, review the approaches and intervention used and suggesting alternatives, rethink of the strategies and Gender norm change influences. But of course, not forgetting the fact that Gender norm change is a process, but documenting process change is equally important.

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: • Rethink interventions that may not yield many results, and consolidate resources where value is envisaged.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: COSTS/BENEFITS • Ministry's agro-parks are well skilled to do deliver the intervention without a lot of need in capacity building, achieve longer term sustainability whereas grassroots will require capacity enhancement to deliver • Ministry's agro-parks are costly to implement due to its use of expert skills while the grassroot focus is cheap and uses local skill set to deliver. • Ministry's agro-parks require big budgets to deliver as compared to grassroots that can run a flexible budget. • Involves a lot of administrative costs that would otherwise be channeled to community needs while the grassroot focus minimizes these high administrative costs, they are based on ground. EQUITY IMPLICATIONS • There is no fairness in terms of Power in resource distribution and decision making over the same, grassroots tend to adhere to power from above and this compromises effective delivery on intervention. • Ther is a tendence of dictating what should be done without facts on ground, the grassroots are on ground and understand the dynamics to be addressed EXECUTION RISKS • A lot of politics is evident in the Ministry’s in agro perks, decisions are delayed which affect the delivery timelines whereas grassroot may have less bureaucratic processes to move things. • Noncompliance with financial accountabilities, many hands involved, whereas the grassroot will try to be accruable although they are also faced with delayed accountabilities and delivery. • Limited trust of the Agro Perks by the communities, as compared to the grassroot focus, they are available within the community. So bottom line the grassroot focus has more lighter points to go by because of their implementation cost implications, limited risks, trusted by communities thus promoting ownership and sustainability. It is important to build local community efforts to take lead in their own development. • In this era where funding for Ministry’s and INGO is shrinking, local organization can keep the fire burning with merger resources. • Equality and justice are realized

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: As we scale from small community initiatives, it will be important to introduce the necessary systems, processes, procedures and standards to support growth. At the same time, we must maintain the original vision by contextualizing and localizing it to new regions, remaining open to learning and integrating practices that strengthen rather than change the core ideas. The guiding principle is to act as local as possible but as global as necessary, adopting global standards only where they enhance the model without diluting it. Clarity of purpose is essential; understanding why Kujenga succeeded should anchor every decision so that scale extends the model’s impact instead of weakening it. Strengthening the system will also require leveraging formal partners for policy alignment and resource mobilization while protecting the grassroots layer that drives behavior change and gender transformation, and ensuring that local institutions contribute meaningfully to decision-making. Successful scale further depends on understanding the stakeholders and communities we are entering and bridging the language between community realities and institutional expectations. Throughout this process, several non-negotiables must remain central: Kujenga’s farmer-led structures and mechanisms for women’s agency must be preserved and strengthened; the gender and inclusion lens must continue to recognize the roles of both women and men; and climate-smart agricultural practices must be upheld and adapted to the environmental conditions of each new location.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: 1. Effective resource allocation to local partners is essential to ensure they become not just implementers but true owners of the process. 2. Open and flexible policy environment that empowers local actors to make informed decisions on how resources are allocated and utilized.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: Over-reliance on formal partners can create several risks, including reduced community motivation and ownership, as local actors may feel sidelined in decision-making. In a climate-resilient project, it also increases the risk of overlooking crucial local knowledge such as seasonal patterns, indigenous coping strategies and locally adaptable farm inputs when formal regulations, procurement procedures, and supply-chain standards take precedence. To prevent community voice from being overshadowed, safeguards should be built into the design, such as structured community consultations, mandatory representation of grassroots leaders in decision making forums and co creation processes that require integrating local knowledge into technical and procurement decisions. These mechanisms ensure that formal systems reinforce, rather than replace, community expertise and leadership.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: Over the next 60 days, Okello should have Lead Farmers provide weekly voice-note updates capturing seasonal shifts, input suitability, gender participation, and emerging challenges. Kujenga field officers should also submit brief weekly updates highlighting what is working, what is not, and the level of partner responsiveness. In addition, community cooperatives and producer groups should join bi-weekly check-in calls to validate early adoption and identify emerging risks. Finally, Okello should hold monthly debrief meetings with leadership to review risks, and at the end of the 60 days the team should determine the adjustments and next steps required for scale-up.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Supply-chain engagement will involve completing supplier vetting within the first 20 days, followed by input distribution aligned to seasonal timelines within 25 days after vetting. This process will be led by the Agribusiness Lead. MEAL learning, headed by the MEAL Specialist at Kujenga, will ensure that gender performance indicators are validated by Day 30 and that weekly field-driven MEAL updates are consistently produced.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: The three priority outcomes are: first, establishing clear ownership of the supply chain, MEAL learning, community networks, and escalation pathways; second, stabilizing the scaled model in Teso, Karamoja, and Busoga while maintaining a strong gender lens and ensuring partner performance; and third, fully operationalizing the rapid learning cycle. The five core milestones include: Activating field networks within the first 15 days, with rollout proceeding only after Lead Farmers and community groups confirm readiness. Validating gender indicators by Day 30 and initiating redesign where the gender lens shows gaps. Achieving supply-chain alignment by Day 45, ensuring supplier timelines fit seasonal signals. Reviewing progress by Day 60 and making necessary adjustments based on partner roles and field feedback. Securing approval and sign-off of the refined scale-up model by Day 90.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: By introducing bi-weekly one-hour field reviews, Kujenga, formal partners and Lead Farmers can jointly assess what has changed in the field and agree on the actions needed, ensuring all decisions remain grounded in frontline experience.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Monthly long-form reports and reviews would be discontinued and replaced with a concise one-page update. In addition, partner planning meetings would be dropped and integrated into the regular review sessions. What remains essential is the tracking of gender indicators and continuous field monitoring of partners and Lead Farmers.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Background & Rationale World Vision Uganda is scaling a successful climate-smart, women-inclusive agribusiness pilot implemented by Kujenga Farmers Network in Serere to Teso, Karamoja, and Busoga. As scaling begins, key tensions have emerged like pressure to shift from grassroots delivery to large formal NGO partners, redesigning of the MEAL system , role confusion and weakening field-first learning. This workshop is meant to realign all actors around the core principles that made the pilot successful while enabling disciplined and executable scale. Objectives 1. Clarify roles, decision-making authority and accountability across MEAL, Grants, Operations, Gender Advisors and partners. 2. Agree on a partner engagement model that balances formal NGOs with grassroots farmer structures. 3. Have a 90-day cross-functional execution and learning reset plan. Expected Outcomes • Clarified Roles across all functions • A partner engagement framework outlining the complementary roles of formal NGOs and grassroots farmer organizations • A 90-day execution and learning action plan with named owners and timelines. Estimated Budget (UGX) Item Unit Quantity Freq Rate Amount Venue & conference package Day 1 1 500,000 500,000 Meals & refreshments (35 participants) Persons 35 1 60,000 2,100,000 Participant transport (regional partners & farmers) Persons 35 1 80,000 2,800,000 Accommodation (up-country participants) Persons 35 2 300,000 21,000,000 Stationery provision 1 1 350,000 350,000 Communication & coordination provision 1 1 50,000 50,000 Total Estimated Budget 26,800,000

text: By designing a MEAL framework which is gender inclusive

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text: Field-First Decision Making: All key decisions must be grounded in the real conditions of the areas where the program is scaling, informed by lived farmer experiences and on-the-ground evidence. Adherence will be tested by requiring documented farmer feedback and field verification to support major decisions. Gender as a Core Design Principle: Gender inclusion and women’s economic empowerment must be embedded at the heart of all program design and implementation, not treated as a stand-alone or add-on component. One Integrated Execution Plan: All functions will operate from a single, unified execution plan that aligns MEAL, Grants, Operations, and Gender around shared priorities, timelines, and accountability.
