question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: The specific risks are: 1. Not paying attention to local voices yet they matter. 2. Dependency syndrome 3. Lack of growth. Safeguards include: 1. Working with local actors across the project life cycle from design to implementation to monitoring to evaluation. 2. Designing and implementing a community friendly feedback and accountability mechanism, and acting on the feedback timely. 3. By giving them a seat at the table. 4. By embracing both their strengths and weaknesses knowing that improvement is possible. 5. By avoiding biais

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: I would trade going rapidly wider for going deeper This is because pushing a Farmers' network like TUJENGA to scale too quickly regionally risks severing the vital connection to local context and the key insights that emerge from it. Instead, scale must be guided by their capacity to learn and unlearn over time with mentorship. Sustainable growth is not measured by speed but rather by resilience.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: Sources: Both qualitative and quantitative sources including secondary data sources. Cadence: Weekly and monthly meetings, field observations and feedback, as well as a comprehensive review after the six months period. Artifacts: Weekly and monthly reports, learning objectives, performance summaries and dashboards.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: Women's groups do not implement large scale projects because such are for men. I would conduct focus group discussions to explore priorities, attitudes, expectations and challenges.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: 1. By regulating the speed of scale putting into consideration the maturity level of the village. 2. By co-designing projects/programs together. 3. By creating awareness at village level about government programs and how they can collaborate and benefit from them. 4. By having villages supply labour and raw materials for the Agro-parks.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: I would test the 'Women Katale' approach by developing an APP similar to that of Uber and Safe Boda in different languages spoken by the women where buyers and sellers can connect. Additionally, I would have a physical Katale where women buyers and sellers meet physically to buy, sell and connect. 'Katale' means open market.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Supply Chain Management owned by the Supply Chain Manager at World Vision working alongside the Procurement Officer of Tujenga. Milestones include sending out a request for pre-qualification of suppliers in week one that runs for a month, shortlisting the applicants and interviewing them in week five and onboarding the suppliers in week seven. Orientation of suppliers happens in week seven too followed by receiving samples of inputs and tools and the actual receiving and distribution of supplies in week eight. MEAL Learning is led by both the World Vision MEAL Advisor and TUJENGA'S MEAL Officer. In week one, they develop a MEAL framework and have it reviewed, plan for and conduct data collection and analysis in week two, three, four and five. They write the report and disseminate the findings in week six and seven. They reflect and act on the actions from the dissemination meeting in week eight. Community liaison is led by the Partnership Advisor and Field Officer of World Vision and TUJENGA respectively. In week one, they develop a community liaison and engagement startegy and have it reviewed and approved. In week two, they conduct stakeholder mapping, visit the community physically and conduct an inception meeting in week three. They gather feedback from stakeholders and act on it in week four onwards. Escalation Paths owned by Okello-the Strategic Initiatives Lead includes developing a communication tree and disseminating it in week one and two respectively. Monitoring how and what happens takes effect from week three onwards.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: Supply chain management • Week 1: Send out requests for quotations to potential suppliers. (Owned by: Supply Chain Manager & Procurement Officer) • Week 5: Pick the best candidates and do interviews. (Owned by: Supply Chain Manager & Procurement Officer) • Week 7: Welcome the chosen suppliers and give them a quick introduction. (Owned by: Supply Chain Manager) • Week 8: Get samples from suppliers and start handing out supplies. (Owned by: Supply Chain Manager) MEAL & community engagement • Week 1: Draw up the MEAL plan and make sure everyone’s on the same page. (Owned by: World Vision MEAL Advisor & TUJENGA’s MEAL Officer) • Weeks 2-5: Collect data, analyze it, and write up reports. • Weeks 6-7: Disseminate the findings and plan next steps. • Week 8: Look back, see what worked, and tweak things if needed. Community liaison & engagement • Weeks 1-3: Come up with a community liaison plan. (Owned by: Partnership Advisor & Field Officer) • Week 4: Conduct stakeholder mapping, visit communities and meet stakeholders. • Weeks 5 and beyond: Listen to community feedback and adjust your approach if needed. Escalation & communication • Weeks 1-2: Set up a communication plan. (Owned by: Okello) • Weeks 3-8: Keep an eye on how well it is working, get feedback, and make improvements. Key milestones • Finishing supplier onboarding and getting supplies in. • Approving the MEAL plan and sharing the results. • Finalizing the community engagement plan. • Testing the communication system and making it smooth. Early warning signs • Weekly check-ins to see how things are going. • Use shared dashboards to keep track of progress.

text: I would thank the partner and congratulate him for the milestones achieved and request him to keep it up. question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: By principle, NGO/all community interventions should align with government programs. Actually, all interventions should be informed and guided by the National Development Plan and other relevant policies. In instances where a certain policy is not clear, unrealistic, expensive, or otherwise, both parties should meet and do a modification that mirrors and speaks into national priorities. This process should be documented.

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: I think here we are scaling a successful methodology, not just a program. It would serve well to position Kujenga farmer's network as the master grassroot hub and mentorship centre responsible for training, quality assurance and field-first learning centre for Teso, Karamoja and Busoga. We should identify local CBOs or Social Enterprises with a strong grass root presence to become regional delivery agents but their work should be constantly quality checked by the Kujenga delivery model. Non-Negotiables include: 1. Deep Gender Lens in MEAL: MEAL must emphasize women's empowerment outcomes like: control over income, decision-making power, access to productive assets e.g. land, etc. and not just acreage or yield numbers. 2. Kujenga’s mentorship role should be adopted by all the partners during the scale-up phase. 3. Emphasize field first learning loop i.e. insights from women groups should immediately inform implementation. Areas of flexibility include: 1. Partner type – we can work with either CBOs, NGOs or Social Enterprises depending on their grassroot reach. 2. While we must align with Government Agro Industrial parks strategy for political expediency, we should protect experimentation and local relevance in the Kujenga context. We should stay flexible and not consider the strategy as a blueprint on how work is done at Kujenga. 3. Core data coming from MEAL framework should remain unchanged but we can adopt different reporting formats for different stakeholders or funders.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: 1. Be explicit and allocate 60% decision making power, especially in program design and resource allocation, to local partners steering committees. This means that final approval authority is relegated to the regional or local level and not controlled by Kampala. 2. Include a line for local adaptive learning and system strengthening in all partner budgets. This should be at least a minimum of 10%b of grant overhead.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: Over-indexing on larger, more formal partners can accelerate scale but usually sacrifices the relational quality and local ownership that made Kujenga's pilot successful. The key risks are: 1. Abandoning grassroots innovation, which emanates from a field first learning and local experimentation approach in preference for compliance focused and standardized systems akin to more formal partners. The focus quickly shifts to bureaucratic execution rather than adaptive design. • Sidelining the gender lens as large partners with established MEAL systems may lack the sensitivity to capture gender specific outcomes, risking the dilution of the gender focus flagged in the scenario. • Loss of contextual relevance as larger, more formal partners apply standardized programming (one-size-fits-all) across diverse regions, ignoring unique local market conditions, agricultural needs and social dynamics. • The formal partners, powerful and influential as ever, build a transactional relationship where local partners are treated as mere sub-grantees rather than strategic leaders. Recommended safeguards to protect community voice include: In order to be effective, recommended safeguards should be embedded into the decision-making structures, resource flows, and operational procedures. For decision making structures, • Introduce a joint decision-making body or partners steering committees that include representatives from Kujenga, the formal regional partners, and community leaders. This committee holds the authority to approve the use of the budgeted, making their buy-in essential for change. • Embrace quick and straight reporting lines, ensuring that issues from the community are channeled straight to the Strategic Initiatives Lead (Okello), bypassing bureaucratic layers. Operational safeguards suggested include: • Mandatory quarterly reflection sessions. Kujenga is resourced to travel and attend these reviews in the new regions. • Emphasize evidence-based decision making using e.g. photos, or minutes from women's group meetings as evidence before progressing to the next phase, not just standard programmatic reports. • MEAL should prioritize collecting data that is useful and verifiable by the community. Data should be collected, analyzed, and reported back to the community in local languages before being translated for use by other stakeholders.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: I would clearly trade the ambition of rapid growth and maximal regional coverage for the protection of deep, gender-focused learning and adaptive capacity at Kujenga. When we prioritize adaptive capacity, we empower local partners and women's groups to genuinely own the design in their context, making the scale sustainable, not just widespread. If we lose the gender lens, the core purpose of the successful pilot is lost, regardless of how many regions we reach.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: Sources: Women groups - they provide feedback on market access challenges and usability challenges on technology in place. Kujenga Field Mentors provide feedback on adoption rates and implementation huddles observed. Cadence: Weekly by women groups (during weekly meetings) and bi-weekly by mentors. Artefacts: Kujenga receives short voice recording and photos submitted by field mentors highlighting a a particular win or concern. These are reviewed in bi-weekly synthesis meetings and appropriate course of action or interventions agreed and feedback provided to the mentors and women groups to implement agreed course of action.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: HQ will most likely favour the alignment with the Agro-industrial parks strategy promoted by Government yet these formal parks, just like large supermarkets, delay payments sometimes up to 30 or 60 days which creates cash flow problems for the women groups. Because of their micro nature, women groups prefer cash up front, even if margins are small. They may thus reject larger and more formal markets and continue selling to the unscrupulous middlemen who provide lower prices but pay immediate cash which contradicts the assumption that formal market access results in economic empowerment. I would recommend setting up a revolving fund with one of the partners to act as an aggregate and to pay for the produce from women groups upfront or on delivery, and the partner then carries the burden of waiting for better market prices or waits for the 30 to 60 days for the Agro-Park payment to mature.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: The agro parks policy defines the quality standards and target volumes (market) which should be the target or end position the activity at the women groups should seek to achieve. Innovation at the women groups level should thus be to fine tune the means to achieve this end, e.g. innovations around collective aggregation, collective transportation or common user facilities for post-harvest handling. These innovations should ensure access to the Agro-Park is easier or more profitable for the women groups.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: The women group open a WhatsApp page, share pictures with 3 potential buyers, negotiate a price and ship only to the one who agreed to pay the negotiated price. I would judge success by tracking number of buyers who pay the WhatsApp agreed price upon delivery of the goods.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: For supply-chain engagement, owner should be a Regional Formal Partner (Lead), milestone should be securing 3 buyers who agree to checking and confirming order via WhatsApp. Escalates to the Strategic Initiatives Lead (Okello) if buyer adherence to WhatsApp price drops below 80%. The MEAL learning is led by the MEAL Coordinator and the key milestone is finalizing the gender transformative MEAL scorecard. The community liaison is an Adaptive Learning Lead, responsible for launching and documenting the revolving liquidity fund" protocol in two pilot villages in the new region. The community liaison escalates to the Strategic Initiatives Lead (Okello) if women's groups report low satisfaction with the revolving fund. The Strategic Initiatives Lead (Okello) chaitrs the bi weekly synthesis meeting and escalates the SMT in case there are issues that requires immediate attention.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: Outcomes: 1. Implement revolving fund, Milestone 1: Partner to manage the fund onboarded, Milestone 2: Revolving liquidity fund (RLF) Launch. Owner: Adaptive Learning Lead. Decision gate: SMT signs off on the Co-Ownership of Adaptation Funds structure. Outcome 2 - Secure market acceptance of farmer led innovations. Milestone 3: Price agreement via WhatsApp in place, Owner: Regional Partner Lead. Decision gate: 3 buyers sign an MOU to honor WhatsApp agreed pricing for a 60-day trial period. Outcome 3: Decide next scale-up path. Milestone 4 - M5: Regional go/no-go decision: Owner: Strategic Initiatives Lead. Decision gate: Final SMT approval to commit resources to a second new region based on M1-M3 results.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: The highest likelihood of handoff failure is the transition transitioning from informal qualitative learning from the grassroots (Kujenga's strength) to the structured, bureaucratic systems of the larger formal partners. Introduce 3 parts introduce the three-part validation artifact: 1 - or voice note from the women's group proving the adaptation's success, 2 - A one-page instruction set on how to execute the change. and 3 - a one-sentence explanation of the specific formal partner's system barrier.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: Drop all activities that create noise but do not significantly impact the core objective following the 80 - 20 rule. Activity to DROP - Mandatory bi-weekly all-staff update meetings, because these activities consume time and reduce focus. Activity that STAYS: bi-weekly synthesis meeting with Kujenga & Lead Partner:

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: The one-day alignment workshop is designed to shift CARE Uganda's functional teams (MEAL, Grants, Ops) from a compliance mindset to an enabling mindset, forging a single, shared reality with partners for the scale-up. The workshop is focused on establishing market acceptance, mapping handoffs, and launching the adaptation fund to enable rapid, decentralized local funding.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: Resolving this without creating parallel systems requires integrating the gender lens into the MEAL framework.

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text: Principle 1 - The Local Partner is the default owner. How to test: A grants officer must explain why they took a decision (e.g., grant modification) without consulting the local partner first. Principle 2: Risk is an investment, not a failure This SMT defends failure as necessary experiment rather than a loss. Principle 3 - prioritize learning quickly over compliance, e.g., procurement approving an off contract purchase in less than 72 hours. Failure to meet this speed mandate is an immediate red flag.

question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: The Decision: A mid-course programmatic redesign, e.g., shifting focus from one crop to another, or changing the core financial service provided should be co-owned, each partner having veto powers.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: An executive promise could be: Commitment to Adaptive Speed, The weekly commitment to publish: local revolving find allocation status -published every Monday. Enforcement Mechanism - Grants/Ops Lead to email the SMT and partners every week, explaining why no revolving funds was disbursed that week.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: Leading Indicator: Women's Group Responsiveness (% of groups submitting weekly feedback/Voice Notes); Owner: Adaptive Learning Lead; Escalation Rule (If Metric Turns Red): If a women group responsiveness drops below 65%, the Adaptive Learning Lead should allocate part of the revolving fund to cover Kujenga Field Mentor time in that region, rather than hiring new staff.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: The conversation should be centred around discovering the root cause of the problem of missed milestones rather than addressing the symptoms. Ask about what was the bottleneck. If we had UGX 2 million, how would we spend it to resolve the bottleneck.

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: Focus on the issues, and do not digress. Identify the single most critical failure, and agree simple straight forward decisions which can be either YES / No or A / B

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: Which of the 3 planned gender outcomes do we feel we may not be able to achieve? This question targets the core program purpose and forces identification of the 'unknown unknowns' . Under fidelity and partnerships, you could ask: Could the formal partner's system (e.g., procurement, finance) block Kujenga's grassroots success this quarter, and why did Kujenga not use their veto power? This question forces honesty about systemic barriers and exposes the fear factor or power dynamic that hinders local leadership.

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: 1. Protecting Trust: organise a No-Fault Learning Session with the team and Kujenga. For the case of protecting momentum , avoid halting the entire project. Instead focus energies i critical areas where progress is stalling

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: Stop things like physical partner capacity assessments and audits unless these activities are legally mandatory. Funds Re-Allocated: The money and staff time saved from this activities should fund the Revolving Liquidity Fund to bridge payment delays and increase the budget for Kujenga's Grassroots Fidelity Checks, ensuring they have the fuel and time to travel to new regions.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Cash Flow Risk: The ministry's agro parks options means that women must wait 30–60 days for payment vis a vis selling to local off-taker even if at lower prices in cash, leading to loss of autonomy, and hindered by requirement to meet standardized, rigid quality/volume demands. My call is to align with the Agro-Parks for market access but to consider the grassroots Focus (Kujenga's methodology) as the non-negotiable execution spine that funds and enforces the link. Why: The grassroots model, even when well executed, will fail if it does not lead to a sustainable, large market.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: % of Adaptation Fund requests approved by Formal Partner coming from Grants/Ops Lead; and Score of new Formal Partner's fidelity to gender lens from Kujenga Field Mentors.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: You should be creative, innovative and open about the decisions you take, for example, direct funds saved from the slowdown (the traded ambition) into the partner's most challenging area (e.g., funding the Revolving Liquidity Fund). This action will demonstrate that the delay is actually a resource injection for quality, rather than a punitive measure.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: The decision rule that shall keep coherence without killing local initiative are: Fixed Mission (Coherence): i.e. the three non-negotiables (Gender Lens in MEAL, Kujenga Mentorship, and Field-First Learning) remain non-negotiable in all three regions. This rule ensures that divergence is evidence-based and driven by success, not by preference. It rewards local initiative (the flexibility) but keeps the overall program aligned to core goals (the coherence).

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?" Element Description Cadence Artifacts / Output Sources Women’s Groups: Direct feedback from the beneficiaries on technology usability and market access challenges. Kujenga Field Mentors: Observations on adoption rates, execution fidelity, and implementation hurdles. Market Actors: Feedback from local buyers/processors on supply chain quality and volume predictability. Weekly (Women's Groups) Bi-Weekly (Mentors) Monthly (Market Actors) Voice Notes & Photos: Short (2-minute) recordings and photos submitted by Field Mentors highlighting a single "Win" or "Worry." "3-to-Act" Summary: Kujenga distills all weekly feedback into 3 critical, high-priority issues/insights for leadership. Supply Chain Scorecard: Simple metrics on consistency, quantity, and quality from local market partners. Cadence Regular, structured collection and synthesis ensures agility. Weekly Check-ins with Kujenga Field Mentors for raw insights; Bi-Weekly Synthesis Meeting with the core Strategic Initiatives team.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: Function Owner (By Role) Milestone Escalation Path Supply-Chain Engagement Regional Formal Partner (Lead) / Kujenga (QA) Securing three buyers who agree to the "WhatsApp Quality Seal" protocol in the new region (Day 60). Escalates to the Strategic Initiatives Lead (Okello) if buyer price-fidelity drops below 80% for two weeks. MEAL Learning MEAL Coordinator Finalizing the Gender-Sensitive MEAL Scorecard and conducting the first bi-weekly "Reverse Accountability" session with Kujenga (Day 30). Escalates to the Ag. Human Resource Manager (Emilly) if data input from formal partners is delayed by more than three days, compromising learning cadence. Community Liaison Adaptive Learning Lead (Within Formal Partner) Successfully launching and documenting the "Revolving Liquidity Fund" protocol in two pilot villages in the new region (Day 45). Escalates to the Strategic Initiatives Lead (Okello) if women's groups report low satisfaction (below 6/10) with the partner's responsiveness via the Community Feedback Channel. Escalation Path (Overarching) Strategic Initiatives Lead (Okello) Chairing the Bi-Weekly Synthesis Meeting and actioning the "3-to-Act" items within 72 hours (Continuous). Escalates to the Senior Management Team (SMT) if a critical "Non-Negotiable" (e.g., the gender lens) is breached and requires a structural partner conversation (Monthly).

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: Outcome I. Validate Partner Capacity & Trust II. Implement Local Financial Bridge III. Secure Market Fidelity IV. Verify Program Quality V. Decide Next Scale-Up, Milestone M1: Partner Onboarding & Trust Protocol M2: Revolving Liquidity Fund (RLF) Launch M3: Price Fidelity Agreement M4: Grassroots Fidelity Check M5: Regional Go/No-Go Decision

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: The highest likelihood of handoff failure is the transition of deep, nuanced qualitative learning from the grassroots (Kujenga's strength) to the structured, transactional systems of the larger formal partners. Specifically: The Handoff Failure: Kujenga identifies a critical, successful local adaptation (e.g., a new farming technique or market approach), hands it to the formal partner, but the partner's system either dismisses it as "unscalable" or tries to mandate it globally without local adaptation, thus killing the learning loop.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: When faced with complexity, the most effective execution leaders cut activities that create noise but don't drive the core objective. The core objective is Locally Led Scale with Gender Fidelity. Activity to DROP: . Quarterly Donor Reporting on Minor Program Indicators 2. Mandatory Bi-Weekly All-Staff Update Meetings. Activity that STAYS 1. Bi-Weekly Synthesis Meeting with Kujenga & Lead Partner 2. Kujenga's Grassroots Fidelity Checks

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: The goal of this workshop is to shift the functional teams (MEAL, Grants, Ops) from a compliance mindset to an enabling mindset and forge a single, shared execution reality with partners. Expected outpits would be 1. Signed Adaptation Fund Protocol: A one-page flow chart approved by Grants, Ops, and the Strategic Initiatives Lead outlining the rapid approval process for local funds. 2. Shared Fidelity Charter: A one-page document listing the three non-negotiables and the agreed-upon three leading indicators for the dashboard (for the next section). 3. Handoff Risk Register: A list of the top three highest-risk handoffs

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: The tension arises when MEAL (compliance, quantitative metrics) clashes with Gender Focus (qualitative change, empowerment outcomes). Resolving this without creating parallel systems requires integrating the gender lens into the MEAL framework, rather than having the two run separately.

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text: 1. The Local Partner is the Default Owner. Test: Test: A Grants Officer must explain why they took a decision (e.g., a grant modification) without consulting the local partner first. 2. Prioritize Speed of Learning over Perfect Compliance. Test: Test: A Procurement/Ops team must approve a small, off-contract purchase (e.g., a local storage innovation) using the Adaptation Fund protocol in less than 72 hours. Failure to meet this speed mandate is an immediate red flag. 3. Risk is an Investment, Not a Failure.

question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: The decision to make a significant programmatic change must be co-owned by three parties, each representing a critical perspective, giving each effective veto power: 1. Kujenga Farmers Network (Fidelity Veto): Veto based on whether the change breaches the Grassroots Success DNA or the gender lens. They ensure the change is locally appropriate and maintains the integrity of the approach. 2. Regional Formal Partner (Execution Veto): Veto based on whether the change is logistically feasible to implement in the field given current resources and capacity. They ensure the change is executable at scale. 3. Strategic Initiatives Lead (Resource/Policy Veto): Veto based on whether the change aligns with funding agreements and CARE's organizational risk tolerance. They ensure the change is responsibly managed.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Executable Promise Weekly Commitment to Publish Enforcement Mechanism Commitment to Adaptive Speed "Local Adaptation Fund Allocation Status." (Published every Monday by 10 AM) Enforcement: If the total available balance in the Adaptation Fund for a region has not decreased from the previous week (meaning no new learning was funded), the Grants/Ops Lead must email the SMT and partners a "Zero-Adaptation Justification" by Tuesday noon, explaining why no learning was funded that week. This forces visibility and creates accountability for inaction.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: Leading Indicator Owner Escalation Rule (If Metric Turns Red) 1. Kujenga's Fidelity Confidence Score (1-10) Kujenga Field Mentors If score drops below 7/10 for two consecutive readings, the Strategic Initiatives Lead freezes all new expansion decisions (M5 is postponed) until a Recovery Conversation is held.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: 1. Reflect (Diagnosis, not Blame), 2. Resource (Re-enabling): Ask a question like: "If we could allocate UGX 2 million from the Adaptation Fund right now to solve that specific bottleneck, how would you spend it? 3. Reroute (Trade-off Decision): Goal: Force a realistic trade-off and demonstrate we respect their capacity limits

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: Check if anyone in the room objects to the proposed decision, and based on which of the three Red Metrics; then if there is no objection, the decision is instantly approved, and the meeting moves on to the next decision or ends early. Lastly: The Commitment: The owner of the decision (from the Execution Spine) publicly states one executable commitment they will deliver by the next meeting and signs off on the meeting minutes during the session. This links the decision directly to action and accountability.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: Focus Area: Fidelity & Partnership. Question: Where did the formal partner's system (e.g., procurement, finance) actively block Kujenga's grassroots success this quarter, and why did Kujenga not use their veto power? Why this Question? This question forces honesty about systemic barriers and exposes the fear factor/power dynamic that inhibits local leadership.

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: Protecting Trust (The Ritual): hold learning session with the team and Kujenga, with no intension of finding faults. Also, for protecting momentum (The Action): avoid halting the entire project. Instead, focus resources on a manageable problem set and demonstrates a commitment to immediate action.

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: Stop: Physical partner capacity assessments and audits (unless legally required). Stop: Producing comprehensive, quarterly, donor-branded narrative reports.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Cash Flow Risk: Women must wait 30–60 days for payment resulting into Loss of Autonomy.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: Data Point Still Needed: % of Adaptation Fund requests approved by Formal Partner (Grants/Ops Lead) and Score of new Formal Partner's fidelity to gender lens (Kujenga Field Mentors)

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: Frame the Decision as a Fidelity Choice, Not a Failure. Direct the funds saved from the slowdown (the traded ambition) into the partner's most challenging area (e.g., funding the Revolving Liquidity Fund). This demonstrates that the delay is a resource injection for quality, not a punitive measure.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: Decision Rule: Fixed Mission, Flexible Protocol. The three non-negotiables (Gender Lens in MEAL, Kujenga Mentorship, and Field-First Learning) are non-negotiable in all three regions. These cannot change. • Flexible Protocol (Local Initiative): Any divergence is allowed, provided it is provably effective against one of the three red metrics in the local dashboard and is documented via the Three-Part Validation Artifact.

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: We will scale a climate - smart, women-led model that takes into account those wins and experiences of farmers. Strong partnerships are needed across Teso, Karamoja and Busoga however, we must put a lot of value into learning with Kujanga's community centred approach. This will build trust among key stakeholders like famers and women, and they will feel part of the process as it scales up. My non-negotiables are: 1. Kujenga's role in field-based learning cannot be tempered with. 2. Women inclusion and leadership are a non-negotiable pillar, wihout it the model becomes the usual generic ones.

question_text: Draft two sentences you’d use with senior leadership to hard-wire local leadership into partner ToRs and budgets.
text: TORs and budgets should integrate the ideas of local women and community led approahes like the ones of Kujenga in a ay tha they are part of the design. Resources should be channeled after commitments have been made on budgets and solid decision making that protects local/grassroots leaadership.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: The big formal partners mostly operate on fixed templates like timelines and pre-determined tools that may have the donor first instead of that last mile woman and farmer as a priority. Formal partners sometimes push local actors like Kujenga into subcontractor positions without shifting power and in so doing they lose originality and trust. Safeguards include: 1. Making local partners part of the design process like TORs in order to build trust in a way that they don't get iferior. 2. Clear Feedback and Accountability Mechanisms like those we have at CARE shoul be put in place with clear reporting lines that protect whistleblowers.

question_text: If you had to trade one ambition for one protection, which would you trade—and why—in service of a locally led scale?
text: I would trade the high flying ambition of expanding the reach of a project in terms of area covered to for protecting community-led approaches like those of Kujenga because real work is in the field with peole like the smallholder farmers whose honest feedback on what is working and failing can guarantee sustainabiliy.

question_text: Design a field-first learning loop for the next 60 days (sources, cadence, artifacts). Which signal would trigger a design sprint—and what would you change first?
text: The guiding principles for the loop are field-first decision-making, women-led ideas, and practical tools that work in real community settings. We learn from the people closest to the action therefore women leaders will be the primary source, sharing weekly stories about changes in power, trust, and behavior; mixed-gender farmer groups who tell us about teamwork, adoption, and practical challenges; field staff who track daily behavior changes, shocks, and problems; partner organizations who identify structural barriers to local ownership; and market and climate experts who base decisions on real demand, pricing, and weather conditions. The teams are kept grounded, innovative and close to the field with simple weekly routines: gathering observations and insights at the start of the week, testing small changes and checking patterns in the middle of the week, and reflecting and writing down what has been learned at the end of the week. One of the things that would trigger a design sprint is decline in women’s decision-making power, indicated by lower participation, men reclaiming decisions, women feeling “spoken for,” or groups moving from co-creation to compliance. What I would change first is strengthening women’s leadership and participation, aligning facilitators on key behaviors, simplifying tools and processes, adjusting activities to fit community pace and restoring direct feedback channels with women leaders.

question_text: Share an example of an insight you expect from women’s groups that might contradict HQ assumptions. How will you surface and act on it quickly?
text: One assumption from HQ is that that integrating men(EMB) into agribusiness groups may naturally boost productivity and positively impact women and girls, but in reality, men may dominate decision-making, reduce women’s autonomy, and create stress that lowers adoption of climate-smart practices. In order to surface and act I would quickly shift certain activities into women-only decision-making spaces, train men to take supportive rather than controlling roles, and reduce joint tasks when they create overload.

question_text: How will you balance policy alignment (e.g., Agro-Parks) with experimentation at village level without creating ‘pilot theatre’?
text: A balance can be arrived at by letting villages shape what actually works. Policy sets the overall direction, but communities drive the real learning through small tests, weekly check-ins, and decisions led by local groups—especially women.

question_text: Name one frugal innovation you’d test in a week to strengthen women’s market access—and how you’d judge it.
text: Pairing of women to sell together in order to strengthen their negotiating power with no added cost or new tools. Its success can be measured after seven days by whether women secure equal or better prices, show stronger negotiation behavior, feel safer and more confident at the market, find the practice easy to maintain, and express in their own words that partnering improved their experience. If it boosts confidence, safety, and prices with minimal effort, it becomes a strong candidate for scaling.

question_text: Map the execution spine: who owns supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and escalation paths—by name and milestone.
text: The execution spine has four lanes which include Supply-chain engagement, MEAL learning, community liaison, and regional coordination—each with one clear owner and one escalation path. Supply-chain leads manage traders and protect women’s market power; MEAL leads run the learning loop; community leads anchor women’s leadership and weekly huddles; and regional leads keep partners aligned. A simple rapid-escalation flow routes issues from field teams through the relevant lane to a single coordinating lead, ensuring fast response and protecting clarity, speed, and model integrity.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: Slippage can be exposed early by using simple, fast feedback loops that keep the field visible every week. Women leaders share weekly pulse checks on attendance, confidence, and decision-making.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Handoff failures are likely to occur when partners don’t receive insights in time to adjust their activities, and important field details such as gender norms, group fatigue, and local politics. When these together with proper accountability are left out of reports, there is always a challenge. Each partner states one adjustment they will make for the week, these commitments are confirmed any red flags or arising issues are highlighted, and together they build a culture of steady weekly adjustments instead of reacting only when crises emerge.

question_text: What essential resource will you ring-fence and protect from budget cuts, and which less critical element will you offer up to the consortium as a trade-off?
text: I would drop the a number of workshops and capacity building sessions from my radar because they mostly create less insight but have more noiseand this slows decision making. What stays are the weekly checkins on partners and mostly the women because this gives a sneek peek in what they are doing and action can be taken in real time.

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: 1. The main focus of the workshop is for all the stakeholders mentioned here to integrate and have all there roles aligned to a more field centred approach. 2. The major goal is to ensure that all teams get a common understanding of for instance when a project or model is being scaled like the one on locally-led at CARE, our values on Transformation, Integrity, Diversity, Excellence and Equality are guarded and non-negotiable together the special focus towards women and girls. 3 Agenda will focus morem on learnings, why the alignment is critical, discussion on the realities in the field and hoew to diffuse any friction(power dynamics). 4. Since CARE puts feedback at the centre of it's work, clear Feedback and Accountability channels will be clearly defined and amplified. 5. At the end of the workshop the teams will leave with clearly defined roles, shared view on how the project or model will scaled.

question_text: How will you resolve the MEAL vs. gender-focus tension without creating parallel systems?
text: I will create an environment of unified purpose between MEAL and Gender by clarifying and dividing roles that do not overstep each other's authority: MEAL leads system design, data quality and reporting while gender defines meaningful change and interpretes power dynamics. They afterward share responsibility on adaptation and things like field visits and check-ins.

question_text: What are three shared principles you want all functions to adopt—and how will you test adherence in real work?
text: Principle1: The field comes first, meaningful voices come from women and what facilitators have observed in the communities and this can be tested through spot checks on group activities weekly and monthly. Principle 2. Women leadership is the core and must be protected in all decision making.This can be tested through tracking decision making trends in monthly meetings by the facilitators. Principle three: Adaptation in a way that for instance plans are based on real time learnings rather than having pre-set ideas and schedules dictate what has to be done.

question_text: Describe a decision that must be co-owned, not approved, and how you’ll structure it.
text: One decision that can be co-owned is on group facilitation strategy where for instance women may decide on a particular time for group meetings to take place such that they don't clash with household duties. I would structure it in a way that the facilitator's observations and women's feedback is summerized, then followed by what can be traded off and what is acceptable remains.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: Capturing atleast three updates from women leaders in each group and aligning them in the weekly meetings and thereafter acting on them in between three to five days. A weekly summary will be shared with all teams

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: A simple dashboard can be described this way: The dashboard tracks three early signs of how well things are working: whether women’s voices are being heard, whether teams act on issues quickly, and whether groups are showing up and functioning well. If any of these stay in the red for two weeks, the team meets within 48 hours to understand the problem and fix it. The dashboard uses simple colors, is checked every Monday, and is shared with all partners so everyone stays on the same page.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?
text: A recovery conversation simply resets the focus: remind everyone why the work is important, name the missed milestones, understand together what caused the delay, and agree on a clear 14-day plan with a few actions and one owner. If delays continue, offer practical options like narrowing tasks or shifting roles to keep progress moving. The conversation closes with a firm two-week plan, a weekly check-in, and a shared reminder that milestones are promises to the women and communities being served.

question_text: How will you prevent ‘update theatre’ and keep meetings decisional?
text: I would keep meetings focused on decisions that protect women’s work in the field by using an agenda tailor made to suit them and also reviewing top signals from women’s groups, making one concrete decision per signal, and assigning owners with deadlines. I would keep meetings short, action-oriented, and under 20 minutes. This approach makes meetings active problem-solving sessions, ensures women’s views drive decisions, and holds partners accountable without extra bureaucracy.

question_text: Set up a quarterly pause-and-reflect with Kujenga and regional partners. What questions will you ask, and how will you convert answers into signed changes?
text: The quarterly pause-and-reflect session is a chance to step back, see what’s working, spot problems, and plan practical changes without weakening women’s leadership or field insights. Teams review the model, partner roles, learnings, policy alignment, deadlines, and signed commitments. All changes go through rigorous checks to protect women’s leadership for instance.

question_text: Name one strategic hypothesis you hold today. What evidence would change your mind, and what would you do the day after it changes?
text: I would pause first and validate the findings and engage that last mile woman and facilitators in the design process while asking the why and what questions.

question_text: Describe how you’ll handle a negative finding (e.g., gender outcomes stalling) while protecting trust and a momentum.
text: Making decisions without engaging women and the local partners especially in the design process.

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: I recommend keeping the grassroots focus while working with the government in a limited way. Women’s leadership and field-first learning are essential and cannot be compromised. The Ministry can support through advice or providing resources, but should not control day-to-day decisions. We can test the model in Agro-Park areas, but government timelines should never override what works in the field. This way, communities stay in charge, trust is preserved, and scale happens without losing the local focus.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: We will need to know if women are making decisions in their groups and if partners are completing their work on time. If this info isn’t ready, we’ll rely on facilitators’ observations and quick check-ins with women. We’ll keep scaling carefully, limit partner roles to support, and meet quickly to fix any gaps. The priority is keeping women in charge and learning from the field while acting fast.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: Mostly through conversations and reflections with partners.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: Flexible tactics that are locally adapted.

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: • Competition in funding. Grassroots risk to be outcompeted for funding because formal partners have established systems and more experienced. • Over-indexing on formal partners risks sustainability because most of these are not on the ground to tackle the issues that affect the communities and lack the innovative models that solve the issues of women. • Formal partners tend to be bureaucratic, risking the projects on delivery timelines which has an impact of impact and scale. Safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined include: • Designing feedback and accountability mechanism (FAM) tools that allow all stakeholders to voice. • Establish program steering committee with membership from Kujenga, Grassroots, Former NGOs and government and ensure that all these have leadership representation on the committee. •Capacity building of the communities to voice their concerns.

question_text: Draft a 90-day plan on a page (3 outcomes, 5 milestones, owners, decision gates). How will you expose slippage early?
text: Outcome 1: -Protect the Model’s Spine A clear, non-negotiable operating model (gender lens, field-first learning loop, community-embedded delivery) is codified, adopted, and used across all regions. Outcome 2: - Aligned & Capable Delivery Partnerships Fit-for-purpose partners (community groups + selective formal partners) onboarded using a transparent selection rubric; roles clarified and signed off. Outcome 3: -MEAL & Government Alignment Without Drift A MEAL framework that protects gender outcomes and learning is redesigned and validated; government alignment achieved without compromising the model. 2. Key Milestones (5) Milestone 1 (Day 1–15) Codify the “Non-Negotiables” Playbook • Owner: Okello + Kujenga • Content: Gender spine, farmer-first principles, execution standards, partnership boundaries. • Decision Gate: Leadership signs off on 6–8 non-negotiables before any scale action begins. Milestone 2 (Day 15–30) Partnership Mapping & Role Clarity • Owner: Strategic Initiatives + Regional Leads • Community groups + grassroots networks mapped; larger NGOs vetted using the playbook (not vice-versa). • Decision Gate: Approve only partners scoring ≥80% on alignment rubric. Milestone 3 (Day 30–45) MEAL Redesign Sprint • Owner: MEAL Lead + Gender Advisor • Co-design indicators with Kujenga + women farmer groups; embed rapid learning loops. • Decision Gate: Gender integrity check—if ≥2 gender indicators are weakened, design goes back to sprint. Milestone 4 (Day 45–70) Field-First Pilot in One Location per Region • Owner: Regional Coordinators • Test delivery roles, learning loop, and MEAL tools with real farmer journeys. • Decision Gate: Proceed only if >70% fidelity to the playbook is observed. Milestone 5 (Day 70–90) Government Engagement & Scale Protocol Finalization • Owner: Gov’t Engagement Lead + Okello • Align with Agro-Industrial Parks strategy without absorbing its top-down delivery logic. • Decision Gate: Ministry agrees to “co-existence” terms; no operational control shift. 3. How Slippage Will Be Exposed Early A. Weekly “Fidelity Dashboards” (Field-First Signals) Track 6 fast indicators: 1. % activities delivered by grassroots actors (drop below 60% = red flag) 2. Time lag between field issues and HQ response (>10 days = drift) 3. Number of weekly women-led insights integrated into design (flatline = gender dilution) 4. Partner compliance with non-negotiables (any breach triggers correction) 5. MEAL tool usage rates in field (>20% gap = redesign failure) 6. Escalations from Kujenga on execution drift (any repeat issue triggers leadership review) B. Bi-Weekly “Truth from the Field” Calls • Direct line from women farmers, extension staff, and Kujenga to Okello • No managers allowed to filter reports • Any trend of “role confusion,” “delays,” or “missing gender lens” is logged as drift C. 45-Day Midpoint Learning Review • Independent, rapid review with farmer groups • Compare practice vs. playbook; publish integrity score • If <75% fidelity → freeze expansion until corrected D. Red-Flag Triggers Immediate pause if: • Gender indicators removed or weakened • Government pushes for centralization of delivery • Any partner tries to substitute field presence with desk-based delivery • Kujenga flags “loss of spine” twice in a row 4. Owners Summary • Okello: Overall lead; protects model integrity • Kujenga: Custodian of the “spine” and grassroots feedback • MEAL Lead: Gender-protective MEAL redesign • Regional Coordinators: Field pilots & weekly fidelity tracking • Gov’t Engagement Lead: Manage alignment without drift

question_text: Design a one-day alignment workshop for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender Advisors, and partners: goals, agenda blocks, and outputs you expect to leave with.
text: Workshop Title: Staying Grounded at Scale: Alignment for Field-First, Gender-Inclusive Execution The goal is to align key staff and partners on roles and decision-making, preserve field-first learning and gender lens, identify handoff gaps with co-designed solutions, and agree on concrete outputs to guide ongoing collaboration. Agenda will include: - Welcome & Context Setting, Field Reality Deep Dive, Handoff Mapping, Roles & Responsibilities Alignment Exercise, Problem-Solving Scenarios, A rtifacts & Rituals Agreement: - Co-design recurring mechanisms (e.g., Field-to-Partner Learning Loop, Handoff Playbook, reflection rituals). Agree on formats, cadence, and owners. Expected Outputs / Artifacts will include:- Handoff Map – Visual showing where execution handoffs happen, with risk points flagged, Roles & Responsibilities Matrix – Clear ownership of activities for MEAL, Grants, Ops, Gender, and partners., Field-to-Partner Learning Loop Plan – Including cadence, responsible persons, and content to share, Scenario Solutions Document – Decisions on how to resolve common execution or gender-lens challenges and Action Tracker / Follow-up Plan – Who does what by when to keep alignment alive post-workshop.

Gender Lens in Every Action, this includes ensuring women’s inclusion and gender-sensitive practices are embedded in design, implementation, and MEAL processes.3. establishing clear accountability & adaptive Collaboration, ensuring roles, responsibilities, and handoffs are explicit, and teams adapt together when challenges arise. I would test this through, tracking whether decisions in scale rollout reference actual field data or learnings; review during bi-weekly reflection sessions. ii. Use the “Handoff Playbook” and shared action tracker; monitor if teams follow agreed roles, escalate issues, and co-design solutions when execution drift occurs.

question_text: Where is the highest likelihood of handoff failure between partners? What artifact or ritual will you introduce to close that gap?
text: An executable promise is a small, time-bound, field-verified commitment that every partner can see, measure, and hold each other accountable to—without requiring new approvals or bureaucracy. It turns the “field-first, gender-strong scale” vision into a weekly, observable action.A one-page ‘Field Signal of the Week’ summarizing one insight from Kujenga, its gender implication, and the action taken by MEAL, Ops, or Grants within that same week.

question_text: Describe a process for vetting partners' stated capacity against their actual follow-through discipline (e.g., punctuality, timely budget revisions, willingness to adapt).
text: Leading Indicators (Weekly) Field Signal Responsiveness (Target: 100% signals acted on within 7 days) Owner: MEAL + Ops What it measures: Whether insights from Kujenga translate into concrete action quickly. Why it matters: Prevents execution drift and protects field-first learning. Gender Integrity Score (Target: All activities score “strong” or “acceptable”) Owner: Gender Advisor What it measures: Whether weekly decisions, adaptations, and partner activities maintain the women-inclusive lens. Why it matters: The gender lens is at risk in the MEAL redesign and during partner handoffs. Handoff Clarity & Completion (Target: 90% of planned handoffs completed without confusion) Owner: Grants + Partner Leads What it measures: Whether roles, responsibilities, and documentation are clear between Kujenga and larger NGOs. Why it matters: This is the highest-risk failure point in the scenario.

question_text: How will you re-engage a partner who has disengaged due to low trust or fear of political risk (i.e., too many cameras off)? What’s your first move?

question_text: Lay out a side-by-side of aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks vs. protecting grassroots focus: costs/benefits, equity implications, execution risks. What’s your call—and why?
text: Aligning with the Ministry’s Agro-Parks offers benefits such as stronger institutional backing, access to larger infrastructure, and potential for faster regional scale. However, it comes with significant costs, including the risk of top-down influence diluting women-led and grassroots priorities, uneven benefits that may favour better-resourced farmers, and execution delays tied to bureaucratic processes. In contrast, protecting a grassroots focus ensures deeper community ownership, stronger inclusion of women and youth, and more adaptive, context-specific solutions, though it may limit immediate scale and require more fragmented coordination. From an equity perspective, Agro-Parks could unintentionally widen gaps by privileging commercially ready actors, while a grassroots pathway maximizes reach to the most vulnerable. Considering these trade-offs, my call is to prioritize a grassroots-first scale strategy while selectively aligning with Agro-Parks for complementary value—such as market linkages or policy support—without allowing them to steer design or beneficiary targeting. This hybrid position protects equity and trust while tapping institutional leverage only where it strengthens, rather than substitutes, local leadership.

question_text: You must decide by Friday: which two data points do you still need, from whom, and what is your fallback if they don’t arrive?
text: By Friday, I need two critical data points to guide the next decisions: first, weekly gender participation metrics from Kujenga Farmers Network field teams via MEAL, to confirm that women remain actively engaged in decision-making and adoption of climate-smart practices; second, partner handoff compliance data from larger NGO partners and Ops teams, to verify that agreed roles, responsibilities, and field-to-partner handoffs are being executed as planned. If the gender metrics do not arrive on time, I will conduct rapid qualitative checks through phone interviews or mini focus groups with representative women in each region, led by Kujenga. If handoff compliance data is delayed, I will rely on direct partner self-assessments with supporting evidence, cross-verified by MEAL team observations. These fallback measures ensure that we can still make timely, informed decisions while protecting the field-first, gender-inclusive model.

question_text: How will you socialize a hard trade-off, so partners feel informed and respected, even if they disagree?
text: To socialize a hard trade-off while maintaining trust, I would first frame the decision in terms of shared goals and evidence, making it clear that the trade-off is about maximizing impact—not assigning blame. I would convene a brief, transparent discussion with all partners, presenting the options, the consequences of each, and the rationale for the chosen path, using data from Kujenga’s field signals and MEAL metrics. I would invite feedback and questions upfront, acknowledging dissenting views and showing that concerns are heard, while also clarifying non-negotiable constraints such as gender integrity or field-first principles. Finally, I would document the decision and rationale in a shared artifact, such as the “Field-to-Partner Playbook” or weekly update, so partners have a reference they can revisit. By combining transparency, evidence, and inclusive communication, partners feel informed and respected even if they ultimately disagree with the decision.

question_text: If regions diverge, what decision rule keeps coherence without killing local initiative (i.e., when do you let them diverge, and when do you mandate coherence)?
text: To maintain coherence across regions while preserving local initiative, I would implement a “principles-first, context-adapted” decision rule: all regions must adhere to non-negotiable core principles—field-first learning, gender inclusion, and climate-smart practices—while allowing flexibility in how they implement activities locally. When divergences arise, the rule is: Document the divergence with rationale and expected outcomes. Share across regions in the weekly Field Signal loop for peer review. Escalate only if divergence risks breaching core principles; otherwise, treat it as an adaptive learning experiment.

question_text: How will you articulate a scale vision that keeps Kujenga’s grassroots strengths at the core while enabling regional reach? Name the non-negotiables and where you’d flex.
text: What makes Kujenga a partner of choice is its deep community roots and proven technical expertise and wide regional reach. I would articulate it by presenting the approved proposal and project charter being used to implement the project, highlighting that Kujenga is a climate-smart, women-inclusive agribusiness interventions and its operational footprint beyond Serere into Teso, Karamoja, and Busoga. I will share the scale strategy: emphasizing that scaling is not about abandoning grassroots delivery but amplifying it through a localized networked partnerships and systems strengthening, voicing and ensuring that Kujenga Farmers' Network remains central and core to the project. Non-Negotiables: Kujenga Farmers Network remains a core partner-its local and at the grassroot and can not be replaced by large formal NGOs; MEAL must have gender lens; locally led mplementation and decision-making. Flex Points: Alignment/adaption to the government agro-industrialization strategy; strategic partnerships with larger formal NGOs for technical expertise identified and linkages—provided they are locally grounded and reinforce Kujenga's localization agenda; explore operational innovations or models embrace grassroots leadership for regional coordination across Serere, Teso, Kamonja and Busoga .

Strategically making localization an integral part of project design is non-negotiable for impact and accountability

question_text: What specific risks arise if you over-index on ‘formal partners’? How would you design safeguards to prevent community voice from being sidelined?
text: Specific risks that would arise if I over index on formal partners- high operational costs, suppression of grassroot voices, MEAL redesigning diluting the gender lens, limited reach across the regions. To safeguard community voice and leadership, I will embed localization principles into partnership agreements and budgets. For instance, provision of mandatory grassroots representation in governance structures, involvement of community actors in designing MEAL gender lens inclusive systems- clear targets are important. Partner ToRs prioritize locally led delivery and accountability, ensuring that formal partners serve as technical allies rather than primary implementers. These measures guarantee that scaling efforts remain rooted in community-driven solutions while leveraging strategic partnerships for specialized support.
